The patient provides a classic case of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  presenting with acute onset of chest pain following severe emotional stress  physical signs consistent with heart failure  and the absence of significant coronary artery disease to explain her symptoms.  Treatment & Follow-up: Acute management of the patient included angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE inhibitors) and beta-blockers. The patient will be required to attend regular follow-up appointments for physiologic assessment and to verify the complete resolution of left ventricular dysfunction. It will also be recommended that she seeks counseling or support to manage her emotional stress.   Prevention strategies should be focused on controlling risk factors  including her hypertension and cholesterol  through medication and lifestyle alterations such as regular exercise and a healthier diet. Also  future avoidance of intense emotional stress can help prevent recurrence of this condition.   Conclusion: This patient embodies a typical presentation of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  which predominantly affects postmenopausal women and is often triggered by intense physical or emotional stress. Though often self-resolving  the condition may require ongoing management to prevent a recurrence. Studies have shown excellent prognosis if adequately recognized and managed.

Patient Presentation  I am presenting Mrs. Eileen Nolan  a 64-year-old Caucasian female with a primary diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also commonly known as “broken heart syndrome.” She lives in Albany  New York with her husband of 43 years and was recently retired from her job as a schoolteacher.  Mrs. Nolan has a past medical history that is fairly significant and indicative of chronic stress and anxiety. She was diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) a decade ago  and has been on regular medication since then. She was additionally diagnosed with hypertension 5 years ago  which has been fairly well managed with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors.  Most recently  Mrs. Nolan experienced the sudden death of her eldest son in a car accident 3 weeks ago  which has served as a significant stressor. After his funeral  she reported symptoms of severe chest pain and shortness of breath  following which she was rushed to the hospital and subsequently diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Mrs. Nolan is a non-smoker but admits to being a moderate drinker over the course of many years. She does not have any reported drug allergies. There is also no known family history of coronary artery disease  heart failure  or sudden cardiac deaths.  In conclusion  with the high-stress event of her son's passing  her medical history of anxiety and hypertension  we suspect that these factors triggered the onset of Mrs. Nolan’s takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The plan moving forward includes both management of her new condition and assistance in managing her emotional and mental health.

Slide 1: Introduction Our patient today is a 65-year old Caucasian female previously enjoying good health  but recently experienced an extremely stressful life event.   Slide 2: Health History The patient has no past medical history of heart disease  diabetes  or high blood pressure. She is a non-smoker and only consumes alcohol occasionally. Family history reveals her mother has hypertension  but there are no reports of any familial heart diseases.  Slide 3: Presenting Symptoms A week after her husband’s sudden death  the patient presented with alarming symptoms similar to a heart attack  including severe chest pain and breathlessness. She also reported feelings of extreme anxiety and depression due to her recent bereavement.  Slide 4: Clinical Presentation Physical exam defines her blood pressure at 160/90  heart rate at 90 beats per minute  and O2 saturation at 93% on room air. Her EKG revealed ST-segment changes and her Troponin levels were slightly elevated. However  her coronary angiogram did not exhibit any obstructive coronary disease.  Slide 5: Diagnosis Given the patient's intense emotional stress  symptomatology mimicking myocardial infarction  absence of significant coronary artery disease  and transient wall-motion abnormalities involving the left ventricular apex on echocardiography  she was diagnosed with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as broken-heart syndrome.  Slide 6: Treatment & Prognosis The initial treatment comprised of relieving the patient's heart failure symptoms with beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors  coupled with psychological support for her bereavement. The prognosis for Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy is generally good  and complete recovery is expected in weeks to months with appropriate medical management and psychological support.  Slide 7: Conclusion This case exemplifies the significant impact of emotional stress on myocardial function  presenting as Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy. This condition  although rare  can be life-threatening  thus requiring early recognition and appropriate management.  Slide 8: Q&A Let's take any questions or discussions.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 68 year old Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension  well-controlled type 2 diabetes  and is post-menopausal.  Clinical Presentation: She presented to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain  shortness of breath occurring for 3-4 hours. The chest pain was severe  radiating to her left arm and was associated with profuse sweating.  Relevant Medical History: Her hypertension is controlled with daily medication (Lisinopril) and she has adherence to Metformin for her Type 2 diabetes. She has a 10-year history of smoking but quit 15 years back. She reports no familial history of heart disease.  Recent Stressors: The patient experienced a major emotional stressor one day ago: the sudden passing of her husband. She had been under severe emotional stress since then and admits to difficulty sleeping  lack of appetite and frequent crying spells. The stressor coincided with the timing of her chest pain.  Clinical Examination: She exhibited tachycardia and high blood pressure upon admission. Initial ECG showed ST segment elevation suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome. Troponin level was considerably raised. Echo cardiogram showed contractile dysfunction  mainly in the apex of the left ventricle  consistent with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Further Management: After stabilization  she was admitted to the cardiology ward for further management and observation. Cardiac catheterization revealed no significant obstructive coronary artery disease  which further points to Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   This clinical picture was suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  commonly known as ""broken heart syndrome "" induced by severe emotional distress.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Identity: Ms. Barbara Snow Age: 65 years old Gender: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Country of residence: United States Occupation: Retired school teacher Marital Status: Widowed  Presenting Condition: Ms. Snow presents with signs and symptoms suggesting takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   History of presenting condition:   Ms. Snow's symptoms started a week ago with chest pain  breathlessness  palpitation  and excessive fatigue. She recalls experiencing acute emotional stress contributing to her husband's death two months ago. There are no similar episodes in the past. Her chest pain lasting for a few minutes is generally located in the middle of the chest  exertional  and relieved by rest.   Past medical history:  Ms. Snow was in good health until her recent bereavement. She has a past history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which were well-controlled with medication. She does not have a history of ischemic heart disease. She denies any major surgical procedures and has no known allergies.  Family history:   No history of premature cardiovascular disease and sudden cardiac death. However  her mother had type 2 DM and HTN  and her father had died of old-age-related diseases.  Social History:  Ms. Snow is a non-smoker and has no history of substance or alcohol abuse. She was physically active and maintained a balanced diet before her husband's passing. Recently  however  she has been relatively inactive due to emotional distress.  Currently  Ms. Snow lives alone  and reports having a strong emotional and logistical support network  including her daughter's family living nearby and her circle of friends.  Summary:  Ms. Barbara Snow  a 65-year-old retired schoolteacher widow with a history of hypertension and diabetic  has recently presented with chest pain  breathlessness  palpitation  and excessive fatigue following a major emotional stressor  pointing to a potential incident of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.

Patient Presentation  Patient's Demographics: We present the case of Mrs. J  a 68-year-old Caucasian female from rural Nebraska. She is retired  a widow  and lives alone. She does not smoke  with a body mass index (BMI) of 27  denoting that she is slightly overweight.   Medical History: Mrs. J has a past medical history significant for hypertension (HTN) and generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) for the past ten years  managed with hydrochlorothiazide and diazepam respectively. She also has osteoarthritis with occasional pain relief medications but no history of diabetes  dyslipidemia  or any known cardiovascular disease in the past. She reported no known drug allergies during previous consultations.  Present Illness: Her grandson found her at home  in acute distress with a complaint of sudden  severe chest pain radiating to her left arm. The pain started approximately two hours earlier after she received the news about her sister's unexpected death. Given her age and symptoms  myocardial infarction was initially suspected  and she was transported to the Emergency Department.  On arrival  her vitals were as follow: BP 155/90 mmHg  Pulse rate 110/min  respiratory rate 22/min  temperature 98.6 ˚F  and oxygen saturation 95% on room air. Her electrocardiogram (ECG) showed unusual ST-segment elevations  and lab tests showed mildly elevated cardiac troponins. No significant occlusion was found on coronary angiography. Echocardiography showed typical apical ballooning with reduced ejection fraction  suggestive of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TC). She was admitted to the cardiac intensive care unit  where her symptoms were managed conservatively.  In Conclusion: Mrs. J's case is consistent with TC  often triggered by emotional stress and presenting similarly to an acute coronary syndrome. TC or ""broken heart syndrome"" predominantly affects postmenopausal women  as exemplified in Mrs. J's case. Her major risk factors include her postmenopausal status  history of GAD  and the acute emotional stress of her sister's death. Prompt recognition and supportive treatment are key to a positive prognosis.

Patient Presentation:  Good morning everyone  I present Mrs. Amelia Rodriguez  a 70-year-old Hispanic female presenting with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   Mrs. Rodriguez is a retired school teacher  a widow  living alone in the city  and her two adult children stay in close proximity. She is a non-smoker and has been moderately physically active until recently. She speaks both English and Spanish fluently and is widely traveled.   Her past medical history is remarkable for well-controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes. She has been compliant with her antihypertensive medications  and her diabetes is well controlled with metformin. She also completed surgery for a non-metastatic form of breast cancer five years ago  and all recent screenings indicated that she remains cancer-free.   Mrs. Rodriguez presented complaining of sudden chest pain persisting for around 2 hours. It's reported that she has recently experienced a significant amount of emotional stress related to the sudden death of her younger brother from an unexpected stroke one week ago. Electrocardiography revealed t-wave inversions with prolongation of the QT interval. The left ventricular angiogram depicted apical ballooning consistent with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome"".   The patient has no known allergies and is not currently on any form of hormone therapy. Her diet is mostly plant-based  but she enjoys seafood and poultry at times.   Her family history reveals her mother died at 86 and had Alzheimer's in her later years. Her father  who died at 78  suffered from heart disease. Her mentioned brother was 66 and had undiagnosed high blood pressure.   That concludes the presentation for Mrs. Rodriguez.

Patient Presentation:  Good day ladies and gentlemen  today we have a case of Mrs. Kimura  a 68-year-old Japanese woman who presented with symptoms suggestive of acute myocardial infarction. She is a widow  has two grown children and lives alone. She is retired and has been living a socially isolated life.  Past Medical History:  She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. She doesn't have a personal past medical history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus  dyslipidemia  heart disease  or other cardiovascular risk factors. Family history is unremarkable for early heart disease or sudden death.  Presenting Symptoms:  Mrs. Kimura experienced an abrupt episode of severe chest pain and shortness of breath after receiving the news of her only brother's sudden death. She was brought into the emergency department of our hospital with these complaints. She showed signs of distress  emotional upset and anxiety.  Clinical Examination:  Her vital signs upon arrival were Blood Pressure: 130/85mmHg  Heart Rate: 110 beats/minute  Respiratory Rate: 20 breaths/minute and SpO2: 98% on room air. Auscultation of the heart revealed normal S1 and S2 without any added sounds. Lungs were clear to auscultation and percussion. The rest of her physical examination was unremarkable.  Given the clinical presentation and her recent emotional stress  we suspected a case of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as 'broken heart syndrome'. To confirm this  we decided to further investigate with additional laboratory tests and imaging studies. Moving forward  we will need to closely monitor Mrs. Kimura and provide her with the necessary emotional and medical support.

Presentation Title: A Clinical Encounter with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Profile:  Name: Mrs. Rose Henry Age: 63 years old Gender: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Receptionist Residence: Rural Upstate New York  Medical History:  Previously healthy  Mrs. Henry's medical history reveals she is a non-smoker and moderate alcohol drinker. She has no major surgeries and no known allergies. However  her family history reveals cardiac disease on her mother's side with both her maternal grandparents and mother experiencing heart-related conditions. Her only regimen is a daily multivitamin  and she is not currently on any prescription medications. She is moderately active and her diet is generally healthy with a focus on whole grains  vegetables  and lean proteins.  Presenting Condition:  Mrs. Henry presents with acute onset chest discomfort combined with shortness of breath  which began suddenly after receiving the news of her elder brother’s sudden passing. She had a resting blood pressure of 140/95 mmHg and a heart rate of 90 bpm. It was noted that she showed signs of mild anxiety and distress.   After swift admittance to the ER  EKG results revealed ST-segment elevations  while lab results revealed increased cardiac enzymes. The immediate suspicion was Myocardial Infarction. However  an emergency coronary angiogram revealed no evidence of coronary obstruction  suggesting a different diagnosis.  Based on her recent emotional trauma  her symptomatic presentation  and the results from the angiogram  Mrs. Henry was ultimately diagnosed with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome"". This condition  often induced by extreme stress  presents like a heart attack  but is the result of a temporary disruption in the heart's pumping function while the remainder of the heart continues to function normally or with even more forceful contractions.   To summarize  this presentation described a case of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy that offers a clear demonstration of the ways in which intense emotional stress can result in significant cardiac symptoms and the importance of a thorough patient history and diagnostic imaging in formulating a precise diagnosis.  This also provided a potent reminder that despite being previously healthy  acute emotional stress could potentially present severe physiological responses  particularly concerning the cardiovascular system.

Patient Presentation:  I am presenting a case of a 65-year-old Caucasian female  who has been diagnosed with a medical condition named Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy or 'broken heart syndrome'. She is a retired principal  widowed for 3 years  and lives with her daughter and grandchildren. She has been previously diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and she is a nonsmoker. She quit drinking alcohol 5 years ago. There is a family history of coronary artery disease; her father had a myocardial infarction at age 64 and mother had chronic heart failure.  Her presenting complaint is severe  acute chest pain which she rated as 10 on a scale of 0-10  along with mild shortness of breath after receiving sudden  shocking news about the death of a very close friend  which she found extremely distressing. She states that the pain radiates to the left upper limb and neck region  which mimics the symptoms of a heart attack. However  there is no actual heart damage or changes usually associated with a heart attack. Her blood pressure was elevated at 180/100 mmHg  heart rate was 110 beats per minute and blood tests revealed slightly elevated cardiac enzymes. An EKG showed T-wave inversion but no ST-segment elevation.  After these initial findings  further cardiac testing was ordered. Echocardiography and ventriculography confirmed the diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  revealing apical ballooning and contraction abnormalities implicating a stress cardiomyopathy  and a lack of coronary artery obstruction which effectively ruled out a heart attack.   Her past medical history which includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  along with her acute emotional stress could have potentially contributed to this condition. To conclude  her physical examination  lab tests  and imaging studies confirmed the diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy. Her treatment is being planned accordingly  but she will need careful long-term management with a focus on stress management and treating her pre-existing conditions.

Patient Presentation:   Patient is a 66-year-old female  who presented to the emergency room with acute complaint of severe chest pain radiating to the left arm. The pain started suddenly two days ago and was perceived as a heavy  squeezing sensation. She describes the episode as related to intense psychological stress due to the recent death of her husband.  Demographic Information:  The patient is a Hispanic female  born and raised in Texas. She's retired and was a school teacher. She is a widow and lives alone  but close to her two daughters. She is a non-smoker  a social drinker and is not involved in any substance abuse. Her diet consists of home-cooked meals and she exercises moderately  typically going for a brisk walk every day.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  controlled through medication  diagnosed about 10 years ago. She also has hyperlipidemia and is on a low-dose statin. She has no prior cardiac history and no family history of cardiovascular disease. She is on oral medication for type 2 diabetes and has suffered from moderate anxiety disorder. She had a hysterectomy about 20 years ago due to fibroids. She reports no allergies to medications nor any prior surgeries other than the hysterectomy.   Current medications: Lisinopril for hypertension  Metformin for type 2 diabetes  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.   Based on her symptoms  EKG changes  elevated cardiac enzymes  and the presence of left ventricular ballooning on echocardiography  she was diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Given her recent bereavement  this may have been the trigger for this stress-induced cardiomyopathy. Patient was stabilized and managed conservatively with medications and was advised to undergo a supervised cardiac rehabilitation program.

Subject: Patient Presentation – Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  1. Demographics:  Our patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female of Italian descent  retired school teacher  married  non-smoker  and with a regular alcohol consumption of 1-2 glasses of wine per week. She has 3 children and 6 grandchildren. The patient lives with her husband in a suburban neighborhood and they both are very active in their community.  2. Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both adequately controlled with medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively). She experienced early onset menopause at the age of 42. Moreover  the patient had a hysterectomy at the age of 47 due to benign fibroids. She has no known allergies and no family history of cardiomyopathy or sudden cardiac death.   The patient has been largely sedentary over the past year due to COVID-19 restrictions. She maintains a balanced Mediterranean diet and was physically active before the pandemic restrictions  with a regular exercise regimen involving brisk walking and yoga.  3. Current Clinical Presentation:  The patient presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain  which began earlier the same day. The pain was described as a heaviness in the center of her chest. Upon questioning  she reported that the pain did not radiate and was not associated with physical exertion or meals. Further  the patient mentioned she was feeling unusually stressed due to a recent family bereavement.   The initial electrocardiogram revealed non-specific ST-segment changes and her troponin levels were elevated  indicative of acute myocardial injury. The patient was admitted to the hospital for monitoring and further diagnostic evaluation.  Her subsequent echocardiogram showed a classic signs of apical ballooning and relatively preserved basal function  characteristic of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. We ruled out an acute coronary syndrome as her coronary angiography was normal  confirming the diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome.""  Management comprises of supportive care while regular follow-up appointments have been arranged to monitor her recovery and to adjust her medications. Referral to a psychologist has also been placed due to the precipitant seeming to be emotional stress.

Patient Presentation:  The patient we're discussing today is Ms. Donna Craig  a 65-year-old Caucasian female who resides at 1978 Fairview Avenue. She is a retired primary school teacher  living alone following her husband's passing 8 years ago. She is non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. She has a BMI of 22 indicating a healthy weight range. She is fluent in English and has no disability.   Her past medical history includes: 1. Type-II Diabetes diagnosed 10 years ago  well controlled via oral hypoglycemics. 2. Hypertension for the past 8 years  managed with lifestyle modification and medication. 3. She successfully underwent right knee arthroscopy 5 years ago and made a complete recovery. 4. Menopause at 54 years old  occasionally takes hormone replacement therapy. 5. Currently she has no known drug allergies.  Recently  Ms. Craig presented with chest pain and dyspnea following a high-stress event. On evaluation  her EKG showed ST-elevations  and her troponin levels were elevated  all indicative of an acute coronary syndrome. However  a coronary angiogram was done which showed no significant obstruction. But the left ventriculogram demonstrated an unusual pattern suggestive of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (broken heart syndrome)  with apical ballooning and preserved basal function.  Initial diagnosis is supported by a lack of angiographic evidence of acute plaque rupture. Further  disproportionally modest increase in cardiac troponin alongside her recent emotional stress also strengthen the early diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.   Further diagnostics and appropriate treatment plan is being proposed to the patient to help manage her condition.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Mrs. Beatrice Clark Age: 75 years old Gender: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian  Mrs. Beatrice Clark is a 75-year-old Caucasian woman  retired school teacher  and a non-smoker  who initially presented to our medical center with intense chest pain following an emotionally stressful event involving the death of her spouse.   Past Medical History:   Mrs. Clark has a known history of hypertension  which has been managed with lisinopril 20 mg daily for the last 10 years. She also has a history of hyperlipidemia  controlled well with 40 mg of atorvastatin daily. Mrs. Clark has a presence of osteoarthritis and is occasionally taking ibuprofen as needed. She has a notable absence of diabetes mellitus and any known heart diseases in her medical past.   In addition  she was screened for breast cancer annually and was negative to date. She has no known allergies to any medications. Mrs. Clark is moderately active  takes daily walks and does garden work at her home. Her alcohol intake is limited to occasional glasses of wine during social events  and she has a balanced diet.  Based on the recent onset of the symptoms following a significant emotional event and an absence of coronary artery disease  she has been diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy or broken-heart syndrome. Her emotional stress may have been a trigger leading to changes in heart muscle cells or coronary blood vessels  or both. The pattern of left ventricular dysfunction seen on echocardiogram is consistent with this diagnosis. Efforts will be taken to manage her symptoms and underlying emotional stress  and to prevent any complications like heart failure or serious arrhythmias.   In conclusion  early identification of this condition is crucial as most patients recover fully within days to weeks if provided with appropriate care and management.

Patient Presentation  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female who presents with symptoms similar to an acute myocardial infarction. The symptoms came on suddenly immediately following the unexpected death of her husband. She reported feelings of severe chest pain and shortness of breath and her EKG suggested acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction. However  the cardiac biomarkers were only moderately elevated showing a discordant EKG/Marcum ratio prompting a further evaluation leading to diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome"".  The patient has a past medical history of well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She also exhibited intermittent asthmatic symptoms  which are managed through a combination of rescue and maintenance inhalers. She follows a healthy eating plan  does light physical exercise on a regular basis  and has a moderate alcohol intake. She has never smoked and there is no family history of heart disease.  Upon further investigation  the patient admitted she had been experiencing heightened stress and anxiety due to her husband's illness and subsequent sudden passing. She has two adult children and lives in a suburban neighborhood. She retired five years ago from a managerial position in a well-known corporation. She has a strong community and familial support system.  Further echocardiography confirmed the expected findings of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  with apical ballooning of the left ventricle and reduced ejection fraction. The patient was treated accordingly  with Beta blockers and ACE inhibitors  and is being closely monitored in the hospital till the condition stabilizes.   Additionally  we will arrange for counseling and support to help her manage the recent emotional stress. Such supportive therapies  in conjunction with medical treatments  have been shown to improve outcomes and reduce future recurrence of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Title: Presentation of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Middle-Aged Female Patient  Patient Information: Ms. Karen Miller is a 54-year-old Caucasian female who presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain radiating to the left arm similar to a heart attack. Pain started abruptly a couple of hours ago. She is a non-smoker and maintains a healthy diet.   Medical History: Ms. Miller has been generally healthy throughout her life  with only a primary history of hypertension controlled with medication. She reports being under an extreme amount of stress lately due to a recent personal loss - her husband's death two months ago. She states she has been experiencing occasional palpitations but did not seek medical attention as she attributed them to her stress and grief.  Clinical Manifestations: Upon admission  Ms. Miller is in apparent discomfort. She describes her chest pain as severe  left-sided  and crushing in nature. The pain is positional and does not decrease with rest. Additional symptoms include shortness of breath  weakness  and profuse sweating.   Mental Health: Further exploration of the patient's emotional health reveals she is experiencing severe psychological stress  suffering from significant anxiety and panic attacks  all symptoms of acute stress disorder following her loss.  Summary: The above symptoms and the patient's sudden onset of chest pain amidst high levels of emotional stress  point towards the possible diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome."" This condition often mimics symptoms of a heart attack and is known to occur as a result of severe stress or emotional trauma. It will be crucial to rule out coronary artery disease with further testing such as an electrocardiogram  echo  and cardiac enzymes. The patient will also benefit from a psychological consultation considering the levels of stress and anxiety reported.

Patient Presentation  We are discussing the case of Mrs. Verona  a 69-year-old female of Asian descent  who is presenting with clinical signs consistent with a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. She is a retired school teacher  has been widowed for two years  and currently lives alone.   From her medical history  it should be noted that Mrs. Verona has a known history of anxiety disorder and hypertension  for which she takes prescribed medications. This includes amlodipine 5mg daily and an as-needed hydroxyzine prescription. No known allergies to medications are documented. Her past surgical history is notable for a cholecystectomy 15 years ago. Mrs. Verona quit smoking 20 years ago. Additionally  there is no recorded history or familial history of heart disease.   Prior to this hospitalization  Mrs. Verona was last seen by her primary care physician 6 months ago for a routine check-up. At that time  her hypertension was well-controlled and she was up-to-date on all recommended health screenings for her age.   Mrs. Verona presents today with symptoms onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath  initially suspected as acute coronary syndrome. However  upon further investigation  her EKG and cardiac catheterization findings show abnormalities more consistent with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome"".   In conclusion  the sudden intense stress and emotional trauma of losing her husband  her previous anxiety disorder  coupled with her sex and age  are likely contributory factors to her present condition of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Patient Presentation  Name: Iris Thompson Age: 64 Gender: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher  Presenting Complaint:  Ms. Thompson presents with sudden  severe chest pain that started immediately after receiving devastating news about the passing of a loved friend. She explains that the chest pain felt like a blunt force assurance on the center of her chest and radiated towards her left arm  resembling symptoms she generally associates with a heart attack  despite never experiencing one. She also reports feeling light-headed  short of breath  and experiencing a sensation of impending doom. The pain did not alleviate when she rested but eventually eased later in the day.  Past Medical History:  Ms. Thompson has a history of hypertension for which she takes Metoprolol and has a BMI within the overweight range  but otherwise has no other significant health issues. She is a former smoker but quit 10 years back. There is a history of coronary heart disease on her father's side. Her blood pressure and cholesterol levels are usually well-controlled with medication. She has no personal history of angina  myocardial infarction  or any other heart diseases.  Emergency response:  Given her clinical manifestation  an acute myocardial infarction was initially suspected  but further testing including EKG and cardiac biochemical markers suggested irregularities in her left ventricle without severe coronary artery disease – a classic presentation for Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  commonly known as 'broken heart syndrome'.  Conclusion:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is a temporary heart condition that's often brought on by stressful situations  like the death of a loved one. Although Ms. Thompson's clinical presentation initially indicated a possible heart attack  her history of recent severe emotional stress and specific diagnostic inconsistencies pointed towards Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy. Further treatment and management of Ms. Thompson's condition will aim to manage her symptoms and mitigate the effects of her disease.

Patient Presentation   Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female who currently lives in an urban district. She is a retired school teacher  has been widowed for three years  and lives alone. Her only child is a daughter who resides out of state  and she has two grandchildren. She does not smoke or drink alcohol.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  managed with Lisinopril 20 mg daily. She was diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus five years ago  controlled with Metformin. She has no history of cardiac diseases. She has maintained a healthy lifestyle  with regular exercise and a balanced diet. She has been under chronic stress since the death of her husband.   Presenting Issue: The patient presented to the Emergency Department with severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and palpitations. She reported that the symptoms started abruptly a few hours after hearing about her best friend's unexpected death. On examination  she appeared anxious and diaphoretic  with a blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air.   The patient was diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced or ""broken heart"" syndrome  based on symptomatic presentation  elevated cardiac biomarkers  and characteristic wall motion abnormalities on echocardiogram  in the absence of obstructive coronary artery disease. This condition is often precipitated by intense emotional or physical stress and is more commonly seen in postmenopausal women. The prognosis is generally good with appropriate supportive care and stress management.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female who presents to the cardiology clinic with symptoms suggestive of acute heart problems. These complaints include angina  characterized by intermittent chest pain  frequent episodes of shortness of breath  fatigue  and syncope. The patient reports that these symptoms have been progressively worsening over the past two weeks and were triggered by an extremely stressful event when she lost her spouse.  Past Medical History:   The patient has had an uncomplicated medical past without any major surgical or medical conditions. Her medical history is significant for hypertension  which is well-controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. There is no reported history of coronary artery disease  diabetes  or any other systemic illness. She does not have a history of smoking or alcohol abuse. Family history suggests her father had myocardial infarction at the age of 75.   The overall symptomatology  recent emotional stress along with her age and gender  make takotsubo cardiomyopathy a strong differentiating diagnosis. Further diagnostic tests including EKG  echocardiography  and cardiac catheterization will be pursued for confirming the diagnosis and guiding management.

Patient Presentation:  I present to you a 72-year-old female patient named Mrs. Sullivan. She is a Caucasian from Austin  Texas. She has been living an active lifestyle all her life  currently residing with her spouse and enjoying a post-retirement life. She is a non-smoker and refrains from alcohol consumption.   Her past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been controlled with medication for the last ten years. She also has a history of well-controlled type 2 diabetes.  Today  she presents with a sudden onset of severe chest pain that started an hour ago. She describes it as a crushing sensation which radiates to her left arm. She also reports feelings of nausea and light-headedness. This episode came during a period of intense emotional stress due to the recent passing of her sister.   Given the clinical features and her recent emotional stress  she has been provisionally diagnosed with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  often referred to as 'broken heart syndrome'. This is a type of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy in which there is a sudden temporary weakening of the muscular portion of the heart  leading to heart failure with symptoms similar to a heart attack.   Current treatment plan aims at relieving her symptoms and preventing complications using angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  beta blockers  and diuretics while assessing for any possible psychosocial interventions to manage her emotional stress.  In conclusion  with appropriate treatment and stress management strategies  the prognosis for Mrs. Sullivan is expected to be generally good as recovery is usually complete within a few weeks to months.

Patient Profile: Name: Ms. Emily Morgan Age: 66 years  Sex: Female Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired school teacher Residential information: Lives alone in a suburban area in Massachusetts  Description: Ms. Morgan is a 66-year-old Caucasian female who has presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and light-headedness. She has been experiencing these symptoms since morning  which she initially brushed off as a consequence of her active lifestyle and attributed to the recent death of her husband  considering its emotional impact.  History: She has a known medical history of controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past ten years. She reports that she quit smoking fifteen years back and drinks alcohol occasionally. She is currently on antihypertensive (Lisinopril) and cholesterol-lowering medications (Atorvastatin).   The patient also has a history of severe anxiety disorder and has been under treatment with a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (Escitalopram) for more than eight years. This is her first encounter with such intense chest pain.  Diagnostic Imaging and EKG: An echocardiogram revealed akinesis of the mid-ventricular and apical segments with preserved function at the base  commonly known as ""apical ballooning""  suggesting a potential diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. EKG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads concerning for acute coronary syndrome.  Given her recent emotional trauma  coupled with severe anxiety  her symptoms and the diagnostic findings strongly suggest a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Ms. Morgan's case is an example of how mental health conditions and excessive stress can present themselves with the symptoms of a heart attack. It emphasizes the importance of recognizing and managing emotional stress and anxiety  alongside hypertension and hyperlipidemia  as significant factors in cardiovascular health.  The patient will need further evaluation to confirm this diagnosis. Management will involve treating and managing stress levels  adjusting medications  and closely monitoring her cardiovascular health.

Patient Presentation:  We are discussing the case of Mrs. Garcia  a 68-year-old Hispanic female from North Central Texas  who has been admitted into our hospital due to sudden chest pain resembling a severe heart attack. She is 5’3” and of average weight with a BMI of 27.  Her past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which she takes Metoprolol and Rosuvastatin  respectively. Other than these  she has no history of any cardiovascular diseases  diabetes  or any major surgeries. Her records show no history of smoking or alcohol abuse. With a low-daily-activity lifestyle  she is moderately physically inactive.  The characteristic symptom of heart attack-like chest pain rose abruptly after she got the news of her eldest son's tragic sudden demise yesterday evening  which created a tremendous emotional stress and shock. She was hasty to visiting the emergency services considering the severity of the pain.  On admission  a rapid EKG was performed which revealed ST-segment elevation suggestive of a heart attack. An urgent coronary angiogram was done which showed that her coronary arteries were free of blockages. Ultrasound of her heart revealed an abnormal movement in the mid and apical segments of the left ventricle  creating a balloon-like appearance.   Following these results  she was diagnosed with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy or ""Broken Heart Syndrome""  a temporary cardiac condition often caused by intense emotional or physical stress. Mrs. Garcia has been admitted for further monitoring and supportive care including medications to manage her pain and vitals.   Her condition will be reviewed by the cardiology team for further evaluation and management plans. Currently  the prognosis in general is good with proper treatment though long-term management to prevent recurrence will need to be addressed taking into consideration her emotional health and stress management.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian female named Mrs. Smith who presents to the Emergency Department with symptoms of acute chest pain and shortness of breath. The onset of these symptoms occurred abruptly this morning  after she received news of her sister's sudden death. She rates her chest pain as an 8 on a scale of 10  describing it as a crushing sensation radiating to her left arm and jaw  similar to her past myocardial infarction.  Demographic Information:  Mrs. Smith is a retired primary school teacher. She lives with her husband in their private house  and they have two adult children who live out of town. She has a 20-pack-year smoking history but quit about ten years ago. She consumes alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use. She reports an active lifestyle  with daily morning walks and light yoga exercises.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Smith had a Non-ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI) five years ago  for which she underwent Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) and was started on Aspirin  Beta-blockers  Statins  and ACE inhibitors  which she is taking regularly.   She also has well-controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes diagnosed ten years ago and currently controlled with metformin. Mrs. Smith has no known allergies. Her family history is significant with her father and a brother dying of myocardial infarction at the ages of 68 and 62  respectively.   The patient’s symptoms  combined with her previous history of coronary artery disease  initially suggest acute coronary syndrome. However  the sudden emotional stress she experienced this morning and her demographic profile raise the suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  given that it commonly presents in postmenopausal women following severe physical or emotional stress. Early recognition and supportive treatment for this transient  non-ischaemic cardiomyopathy are critical to a positive prognosis.

Patient Profile:  Name: Barbara Streisand   Gender: Female   Age: 65   Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired schoolteacher   Living Situation: Lives alone   Source: Self-reported    Presenting Complaint:  Patient Barbara Streisand  a 65 year-old Caucasian female  presents with sudden severe chest pain and shortness of breath after hearing her son got in a severe car accident. The pain is situated at the centre of her chest and radiates to her left arm. The pain started suddenly a couple hours ago and is not relieved by rest.  Medical History:  Barbara reports a past medical history of hypertension and mild anxiety disorder  for which she has been well-managed on medications prescribed by her Primary care physician. She is not a smoker and does not consume alcohol. She maintains a healthy diet and walks frequently. She has no previous history of heart disease herself  but her father had a heart attack when he was in his late 70s.   Examination and Investigations:  On examination  her BP is elevated at 170/95mmHg and her heart rate is tachycardic at 120 bpm. Her ECG shows ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads and there is a moderate elevation of cardiac troponin. However  upon emergency angiography  there is no evidence of obstructive coronary artery disease  diagnosing her with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (Broken Heart Syndrome).  The severe stress preceding the onset of symptoms and confirmation of a significant cardiac event in the absence of coronary artery disease is indicative of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  a condition often provoked by severe stress triggers.

Patient Presentation:  A 67-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain radiating to her left arm. Pain was sudden in onset and associated with shortness of breath and nausea. She describes it as a heavy  crushing sensation. She mentions she has been under significant psychological stress over the past week due to the death of her husband.   Past Medical History:  The patient’s past medical history is significant for hypertension controlled with medication (Lisinopril 10 mg OD) and mild depression for which she takes fluoxetine 20 mg daily. Her surgical history includes hysterectomy due to fibroids at 40 years old and appendectomy at the age of 14.  She quit smoking 20 years ago and denies any alcohol or drug use. She is retired  lives alone since her husband passed away and has two adult sons who live out of town.  Family history reveals her father died from myocardial infarction at 72 and her mother had a stroke at the age of 75. She denies any family history of sudden death or genetic heart diseases. She is up to date with checks for breast and colorectal cancer.  Clinical Examination:  On examination  she appears anxious. Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 165/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia and a regular rhythm. No murmurs or additional heart sounds are heard. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Angela Martinez  a 65-year-old Hispanic female  presents to the emergency department reporting a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to her left arm. The pain started approximately two hours ago while she was attending her husband's funeral. Ms. Martinez describes the pain as similar to ""an elephant sitting on my chest.""   She also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  nausea  and lightheadedness. She rates her pain at 8-9/10 on the pain scale. No changes in consciousness or responsive behavior were reported. She denies any recent illnesses  recent surgery or trauma.   In terms of her medical history  she has been generally healthy with only a diagnosis of well-controlled hypertension. She was diagnosed with hypertension 5 years ago and currently manages it with a daily dose of Lisinopril. The patient does not have any previous history of cardiovascular diseases  diabetes  or high cholesterol level.   She has no known drug allergies. She is a non-smoker and reports occasional alcohol use. Her family history is significant for coronary heart diseases; her father had myocardial infarction at age 72.   Upon examination  she appears anxious and in distress due to the pain. Vital signs show blood pressure 150/90mmHg  heart rate 102 bpm  respiratory rate 20 breaths per min  and oxygen saturation of 96% in room air.   Based on her symptomatology  history  and current emotional stress related to the recent loss  a differential diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (stress cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome) is considered. This will need to be confirmed via further diagnostic testing such as echocardiogram and cardiac enzymes.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian female  Mrs. Karen McAllister  presents to the emergency department with acute chest pain that is similar to angina  radiating to the left arm. The pain started suddenly a few hours ago during a heated argument with her daughter. It is described as severe  crushing pain  rated 8 out of 10. The patient also reports shortness of breath  palpitations  and a feeling of impending doom. Her past medical history includes treated hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She is a nonsmoker with no history of drug or alcohol abuse. She lost her husband a year ago and lives alone  leading a relatively sedentary lifestyle.  Family history is significant for coronary artery disease; her father died of a myocardial infarction in his late 60s. She has no personal history of coronary artery disease. She denies any recent illnesses  surgical procedures  or trauma. She takes daily Lisinopril for her hypertension and Simvastatin for her cholesterol.  On examination  her blood pressure is slightly elevated at 150/90 mmHg  heart rate is 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Clinical examination is otherwise unremarkable except for tachycardia and mild distress due to chest pain.   Given her sudden onset severe chest pain and personal risk factors  her presentation is suspicious for acute coronary syndrome  but takotsubo (or ""broken heart"") cardiomyopathy should also be considered due to the emotional trigger  her demographics (post menopausal woman)  and the absence of personal history of coronary artery disease despite her risk factors.

Patient is a 65-year-old post-menopausal Caucasian female  presenting to the emergency room with complaints of chest pain  shortness of breath  and lightheadedness  that initiated suddenly. The pain was described as severe  radiating down the left arm. The patient has no known coronary artery disease but has a significant history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  well-managed on medication for the past 18 years. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs  but admits to regular  moderate alcohol intake.  She was recently bereaved  losing her husband two weeks ago  and since then has been experiencing severe stress and overwhelming emotions. Her medications include simvastatin and lisinopril. There is no known drug allergy.  On examination  she was found to be tachycardic with a heart rate of 120 bpm  blood pressure of 145/95 mmHg and oxygen saturation of 94%. Physical examination revealed a worried  anxious looking woman in acute distress.  Electrocardiogram findings were showing ST segment elevation in the precordial leads. Initial troponin T levels were elevated. The picture pointed to a possible acute coronary syndrome. However  a coronary angiogram performed showed no significant coronary artery disease. The left ventriculogram showed apical ballooning with a preserved basal function  which is consistent with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.+

A 63-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency room with acute onset severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and significant fatigue. The pain is reported to be substernal in location  radiating to the left arm  and began suddenly three hours prior to admission. She characterizes it as a pressure-like sensation that is 8/10 in severity. She denies any change in pain with position or activity. The patient also complains of associated diaphoresis and nausea.  There is history of a recent stressful event; her husband passed away two weeks ago. She has no known personal history of cardiovascular disease but has been on medications for hypertension and diabetes. Her other medication includes aspirin 100 mg daily  metformin  and atorvastatin. She denies any alcohol  tobacco  or drug abuse. Family history includes her mother who had a myocardial infarction at the age of 70.  Physical examination reveals signs of mild distress due to chest pain. Blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  pulse is 110 beats per minute  and respirations are 22 breaths per minute with an oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Cardiac auscultation reveals an S4 gallop. Chest examination  abdominal examination  and neurological examination are all within normal limits.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with significant chest pain  intermittent nausea  and a brief episode of syncope. The pain is described as severe  crushing in nature  radiating to her left arm along with a shortness of breath.  The patient reports having a stressful week due to the death of her husband. She admits drinking moderate amounts of alcohol. She smokes a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. There's no significant family history of cardiac diseases.  Her vital signs showed blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg  heart rate 110 bpm  respiratory rate 22 per minute  and oxygen saturation 95% on room air. She appears anxious upon physical examination.  Her medical history includes post-menopausal status  hypertension that's fairly well-controlled on ACE inhibitors  and hyperlipidemia managed with statin therapy. She reports having medication adherence issues. Her BMI is 31  falling in the obese range.  No prior history of myocardial infarction has been recorded and she has never previously undergone any major cardiac procedures. Her EKG  however  currently shows diffuse ST segment elevation concerning for acute coronary syndrome.  In light of her history and presentation  the possibility of a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome""  is being considered. Further investigations  including cardiac enzymes analysis and echocardiography  are planned to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Pruitt is a 67-year-old Caucasian female of average height and weight brought into the ER by her adult son. She reported a sudden onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath  which started unexpectedly while she was delivering a eulogy at her husband's funeral earlier in the day.  Past Medical History:  - Ms. Pruitt is a retired school librarian with no history of heart disease. - She has been managing well-controlled hypertension for the last 10 years and is currently on Lisinopril. - She has no history of diabetes or other endocrine diseases  and no renal or respiratory diseases. - She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially. - She recently suffered the loss of her husband three weeks prior  and since then  has struggled with sleep disturbances and depressive symptoms in addition to the grief process.  Family History:  There is no family history of significant heart disease except her father having a heart attack in his late 80s.   Relevant Information:  The pain she describes is sharp and constant situated in the center of her chest  extending to the left side. Although she doesn't have any known cardiac history  due to the symptoms and the severity of her emotional stress  she was suspected to be suffering from takotsubo cardiomyopathy  often referred to as ""broken heart syndrome"". This was later confirmed through cardiac imaging leading to a diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:   A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents with the sudden onset of severe chest pain mimicking a heart attack. She reports the pain started early this morning and describes it like a ""tight knot"" in her chest  often radiating to her jaw and left arm. Associated symptoms include difficulty breathing and a feeling of overwhelming anxiety. The symptoms began after she learned of her husband's sudden death last night.   Past Medical History: The patient has a medical background of well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She is a retired schoolteacher living with her daughter and her husband. She has never smoked and only drinks alcohol occasionally. She reports no known drug allergies. Her mother had a history of coronary artery disease. The patient reports she has been feeling more stressed and anxious since her husband became ill a few months ago.  Her medications include hydrochlorothiazide for blood pressure control and simvastatin for cholesterol management. She has no prior history of heart disease and has not been experiencing any chest pain or exertional dyspnea prior to the episode.   Based on her characteristics and the context in which the chest pain appeared  takotsubo cardiomyopathy is highly suspected.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Maria Rodriguez is a 69-year-old Hispanic female who presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe chest pain and shortness of breath that started suddenly about 2 hours ago. She describes the pain as a crushing sensation that radiates towards the left shoulder. Alongside  she has been experiencing palpitations and episodes of lightheadedness. Her symptoms started at home after she received a phone call informing her of her brother's sudden death. She denies any cough  fever  or recent infections. She has no known drug allergies.  Past Medical History:  She has a history of HTN and hyperthyroidism  controlled with Lisinopril and Methimazole. Apart from these  she is non-diabetic and has no prior history of heart diseases. She is a former smoker who quit 10 years ago and drinks alcohol socially. There is no familial history of premature coronary artery disease.  Family History:  Mother died of stroke at age 75.  Social History:   She lives alone after her husband’s death 2 years ago. She experiences intermittent stress due to her loneliness. She does not use illicit drugs but admits to occasional alcohol use. She is a retired teacher.

Patient Presentation:   Ms. Caroline Burnett is a 71-year-old Caucasian woman who presents to the emergency department with intense  sudden onset chest pain. She describes the pain as severe and crushing  similar to symptoms she's heard people use for heart attacks. She says the pain radiates through to her back and also notes having difficulty breathing. Physicians note that she appears extremely anxious and panicked during the initial examination.  Ms. Burnett is a widow  lives alone  and states she has experienced high levels of stress recently due to the sudden passing of her only son. She is a retired school teacher and reports being physically active and regularly engaging in walking and light exercises.   She has been managing hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the last 10 years and has been taking medication (losartan and atorvastatin respectively). She quit smoking 20 years ago and drinks alcohol occasionally. She reports no known allergies.   She has no history of heart disease but her medical history includes a hysterectomy 15 years ago  hypothyroidism  and an appendectomy during her 20s. On her father's side  there is a history of heart disease and both her parents passed away in their late 60s due to cardiac related issues.  The physical exam reveals tachycardia with a heart rate of 110. Blood pressure is slightly elevated at 140/90 mmHg. She appears distressed  and her skin is diaphoretic. No other significant findings were noticed on physical examination.   Given her symptoms and strong family history of heart disease  there is a high index of suspicion for an acute coronary event. However  the EKG reveals precordial T-wave inversions concerning for takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Further investigations including echocardiography and coronary angiography are recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

A 68-year-old widowed Caucasian female presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain and difficulty breathing that began suddenly while engaging in a heated argument with her son. The patient rates the pain as an 8/10  describing it as a crushing sensation in her chest. She endorses associated nausea  weakness  and palpitations.   The patient’s medical history is significant for controlled hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. She denies any personal or family history of heart disease  however she suffered a significant emotional trauma recently  the sudden death of her husband eight months ago. She admits to be under a high level of chronic stress since then.   She's a non-smoker  reports mild alcohol use  and denies any illicit drug use. Her medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. The patient’s surgical history includes a total hysterectomy and appendectomy. She denies any drug allergies.  Her father died in his 60s of a stroke  and her mother had diabetes and passed away in her 70s from complications of the disease. She has two living siblings healthy. She is retired and lives alone. She has a son who helps her with daily chores and a granddaughter who visits her on weekends.  On physical examination  the patient appears anxious and sweaty  and is clearly in distress. Her blood pressure is 165/95 mm Hg  pulse 110 beats per minute  and respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute. Initial EKG shows ST-segment elevations in leads II  III  and aVF  but she has a normal cardiac silhouette on chest X-ray. Lab findings showed slightly elevated cardiac enzymes.

Patient Presentation:  A 67-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with acute onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath. The pain was described as a stabbing sensation that began about an hour prior to arrival  radiating to her left shoulder. The patient rates the pain at an 8 out of 10 on the severity scale.  The stress response was triggered by the recent sudden death of her husband  two weeks prior. She reports feeling mild waves of lightheadedness and nausea.  Past Medical History:  Patient has been relatively healthy. She has a history of well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She does not smoke  denies substance use  and drinks alcohol occasionally.   Family history is notable for her father who had coronary artery disease and died from a myocardial infarction at 76. Her medications include amlodipine for hypertension and rosuvastatin for hyperlipidemia.  On examination  patient appeared distressed and in pain. Vital signs were stable but tachycardic. Electrocardiogram was suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome  with ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads.  Preliminary diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome was made and the patient was immediately started on aspirin  nitroglycerin  and fondaparinux. However  her coronary angiography results were normal. Echo cardiogram showed apical ballooning of the left ventricle. In light of her recent emotional stress  she was diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken-heart syndrome).

Patient Information: A 68-year-old female with a past medical history significant for well-controlled hypertension and generalized anxiety disorder.   Chief Complaint: ""Chest pain and difficulty breathing.""  History of Present Illness: The patient reports that she started experiencing severe  crushing chest pain a couple of hours ago similar to ""an elephant sitting on my chest"". The pain radiates to the left arm and is associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and a sense of impending doom. Patient has never experienced this before. The onset was shortly after she received news of her son's fatal car accident.  Past Medical History: Hypertension  Generalized Anxiety Disorder.  Family History: Father passed away due to myocardial infarction at 70 years of age. Mother is alive and healthy at 93. One sibling with Type 2 diabetes.  Review of Systems: The patient reports extreme emotional distress due to the sudden death of her son. She denies any recent illness  fever  or cough.   Physical Exam: Vital signs reveal blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  pulse 110 bpm  respiratory rate 22/min  oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. The cardiovascular exam reveals tachycardia without murmur  rub  or gallop. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.   This scenario is typical of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  often brought on after severe emotional stress  hence its nickname ""Broken Heart Syndrome"".

Patient Profile:   Ms. K  66-year-old  Caucasian female  widow  retired nurse.   Chief Complaint:  Presenting to the emergency department with severe chest pain radiating to the arm and jaw for the last five hours. Describes it as ""crushing"" and is rated as an 8/10. She also reports associated severe shortness of breath  nausea  and feeling of impending doom.  Past Medical History:  Known history of hypertension controlled on medication – Losartan 50mg daily. No history of ischemic heart disease  diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  or any other chronic illnesses. She is a nonsmoker and denies any drug or alcohol abuse.  Family History:  Father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 59. Mother is alive with type 2 diabetes and hypertension.  Social History:  Recently  she lost her son in a motor accident one week ago. She lives alone and has been under considerable emotional stress since the incident.  Physical Examination:  Appears uncomfortable  anxious. Blood Pressure: 160/90 mm Hg  Heart Rate: 115 bpm  Temperature: 98.4 F  Respiratory Rate: 20 breaths per minute. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia. The remainder of the exam including pulmonary  abdominal and neurologic tests are within normal limits.   Emergent investigations including an electrocardiogram (ECG) and cardiac enzymes are obtained given the concern for acute coronary syndrome. The patient is treated with aspirin  nitroglycerin  and oxygen for suspected myocardial infarction and is quickly moved for a coronary angiogram. Her angiogram doesn't show significant coronary artery disease  but there is an abnormal motion of her left ventricle with ballooning  suggesting the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. She is admitted to the ICU for further monitoring and treatment.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female patient presents to the emergency department with complaint of acute chest pain  radiating to her left arm  that started suddenly 30 minutes prior to arrival. She describes it as 'crushing' in nature and rates it as 8 on a 10-point scale in severity. She also endorses feelings of lightheadedness and dyspnea  but denies nausea  vomiting or diaphoresis.   Past medical history is significant for well-controlled hypertension (on lisinopril 10mg daily)  hyperlipidemia (on atorvastatin 20mg daily)  and type 2 diabetes (managed through metformin and lifestyle modifications). She has no previous history of cardiac disease. She smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for 25 years but quit 15 years ago. She drinks alcohol socially and denies illicit drug use.   She also reports significant life stressors happening currently  including her husband's recent death and financial troubles. She has no family history of cardiac diseases but her father had type 2 diabetes.  On examination  the patient is anxious andarous is normal  she is pale and mildly diaphoretic. Her vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 145/90 mmHg  heart rate 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 94% on room air.  An electrocardiogram shows ST segment elevation in the anterior leads. Troponin levels are elevated and a bedside echocardiogram shows apical ballooning with preserved basal function  suggesting a working diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as ""broken-heart"" syndrome)  possibly triggered by her ongoing life stressors.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Jones  a 68-year-old Caucasian female presents today in the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain that started three hours ago. The pain radiates to her left shoulder and is associated with shortness of breath  palpitations  and nausea. The pain is described as a ""crushing"" sensation  similar to a previous myocardial infarction she experienced two years ago. She mentions the pain began in the immediate aftermath of a significant emotional distress as she received news of her brother's death overseas.   Her medical history is significant for hypertension and stable coronary artery disease. Two years back  she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention with stent placement for an anterior wall myocardial infarction. Her medications include Aspirin  Bisoprolol  and Lisinopril. She lives alone since her husband passed away five years ago. She quit smoking 10 years ago  drinks alcohol occasionally  and denies any illicit drug use. She has no family history of heart disease.   The patient denies any recent chest trauma  fever  or cough. There is also no evidence of any recent physical exertion or use of illicit substances associated with the chest pain.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Barbara is a 68-year-old widow who came to the emergency department today  complaining of sudden and severe chest pain that started an hour ago. She describes the pain as a heavy  crushing sensation that radiates from her chest to her left arm. She also reports associated shortness of breath and lightheadedness. The pain started suddenly when she was informed about the unexpected death of her son.  She is a non-smoker and doesn't consume alcohol. She has a past medical history of hypertension for which she takes amlodipine daily  and a recent history of major depressive disorder. She has no known allergies and follows a balanced diet. She has been compliant with her medications and has no personal or family history of heart disease.   Upon examination  she is in distress  diaphoretic  and appears pale and anxious. Her vitals are: blood pressure 165/95 mm Hg  pulse 110 bpm  respiratory rate 22/min  temperature 37°C  SpO2 95% on room air. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds at the lung bases. Cardiac examination reveals a regular rhythm with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops.  The sudden incapacitating emotional stress followed by symptoms akin to acute coronary syndrome suggests Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome."" However  further diagnostics such as blood tests  EKG  and echocardiography are needed to rule out other conditions and confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Profile: A 68-year old Caucasian female  retired teacher  Presenting Complaint: The patient came to the emergency room reporting acute substernal chest pain that she characterized as sharp and constant. The pain radiated down the patient's left arm and up to the throat. The patient also reported shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history of hypertension controlled with medication  and she experienced a significant emotional stress event two weeks prior - the sudden death of her husband. She is a non-smoker and only occasionally consumes alcohol.  On observation  the patient appeared anxious and diaphoretic  supporting a high-stress situation. ECG showed ST-segment elevation suggestive of acute coronary syndrome.  Her symptoms  coupled with her recent stressful event  support a possible diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy or ""Broken Heart Syndrome"".

A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department accompanied by her two sons. She complains of chest pain and excessive shortness of breath that started around two hours ago. She rates her pain as 8/10 and describes it as a crushing feeling  radiating to her left arm. She further reports she has been feeling nauseated and started sweating profusely.   Her past medical history includes hypertension for the past 10 years and she experienced a significant bereavement in the family three days ago  with the sudden death of her husband due to a car accident. She is a non-smoker and takes Lisinopril 20 mg once daily to control her blood pressure.  On examination  she appears distressed  diaphoretic. Her vital signs are BP - 150/90 mmHg  Heart rate - 110 beats per minute  Respiratory rate - 18 breaths per minute  Oxygen saturation - 95% on room air  Temperature - 98.6 F.  There is no personal or family history of heart disease. Her father  however  suffered from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and passed away at the age of 72 due to exacerbation of COPD. Her mother is diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes and is alive at the age of 89  living in a care home. The patient has two older brothers in good health at the age of 67 and 70 respectively.

Patient Presentation:  A 61-year-old Hispanic female presents to the emergency department complaining of chest pain radiating to both arms  cold sweats  extreme fatigue  and shortness of breath. These symptoms occurred after she learned of her husband's sudden death earlier that night.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension controlled with lisinopril  as well as high cholesterol managed with simvastatin. She is a non-smoker but has had high alcohol intake in the past. She has no prior history of heart disease  such as coronary artery disease  heart attack  or heart failure  and no family history of sudden cardiac death. There is also no history suggestive of angina or typical stress-induced chest pain.  Prior to her husband's death  she led a moderately active lifestyle and did not use any illicit substances. She reports low levels of chronic stress at work as she is heading towards retirement and had been relatively health conscious until the recent life-changing event.  Due to the significant emotional stress she has undergone and the sudden onset of her symptoms  a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (or broken-heart syndrome) is suspected.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Z is a 71-year-old Caucasian female presenting to the emergency department with acute onset of severe chest pain  radiating to her left arm. She reports the pain started suddenly during a family crisis when she learned about her grandson's fatal accident. The chest pain is associated with shortness of breath  nausea  lightheadedness  and a sense of impending doom. She has never experienced such a pain before.   She has a past medical history of well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She does not consume alcohol  has quit smoking 10 years ago  and leads an active lifestyle. She denies any history of diabetes  atrial fibrillation  or any other cardiac disease. She lost her husband a year ago and lives alone. She's on medications like Amlodipine for hypertension and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. She is allergic to sulfa drugs.  On physical examination  she appears distressed. Her blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg  pulse rate 120 bpm  respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute  and temperature 98.2 F. Her cardiovascular exam reveals tachycardia  and her lung fields are clear to auscultation bilaterally. An ECG shows ST-segment elevation in precordial leads.   Her presentation of chest pain after intense emotional stress  ST-segment elevation  and history of hypertension suggests the possibility of acute coronary syndrome or Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. She needs admission and further diagnostic work-up  including cardiac enzyme studies and an echocardiogram. Prompt management and monitoring are mandatory considering the severity of her symptoms. However  the definitive diagnosis would be made based on clinical findings and diagnostic work up results.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Jackson  a 65-year-old African-American woman  presents to the emergency department with acute chest pain and shortness of breath. She describes her pain as a sudden  severe  and crushing sensation in the center of her chest that radiates to her left arm and jaw. The pain onset about an hour ago when she received news that her sister had passed away suddenly. She also reports associated nausea and a feeling of impending doom.  She has a past medical history of hypertension for which she takes hydrochlorothiazide daily. She is a non-smoker and denies alcohol or drug use. She has no other known heart disease  but admits to having a stressful lifestyle and her dad passed away from a heart attack at the age of 70.  Upon arrival  her vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 170/100 mmHg  heart rate 110 bpm  respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute  temperature 36.8°C  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Initial EKG reveals ST- segment elevation in leads V1-V4  suggestive of an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction.   Her symptoms  EKG changes  and the profound emotional stressor  suggest a potential diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy or ""Broken Heart Syndrome."" Further confirmed by a negative troponin and characteristic changes on an echocardiogram. Ms. Jackson is admitted for observation and further management.

A 67-year-old Caucasian female patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe chest pain and shortness of breath that started a few hours ago. She describes the chest pain as a ""crushing"" feeling that radiates to her left arm. She also reports episodes of nausea and sweating.   She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been managed with medication for 15 years. She is a non-smoker and drinks only occasionally. She is retired  lives with her husband  and has two grown children.   The onset of symptoms occurred after she heard the news of her younger sister's sudden death  which was an extremely stressful event for her. She has no known allergies. Family history reveals no cardiac illness but her father had hypertension and her mother was diabetic.  She had a similar episode of chest pain 5 years ago for which evaluation  including cardiac enzymes and electrocardiogram  was normal. She has no previous history of coronary artery disease. On examination  her blood pressure is 155/90 mmHg  pulse 110/min  and respiratory rate 20/min. Physical examination is largely unremarkable. She was certain that she had not missed any of her regular medications including the antihypertensives and statins.   This presentation suggests a possible diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome  which should be confirmed by further diagnostic measures like coronary angiography and echo-cardiogram.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department complaining of chest pain and shortness of breath which commenced suddenly after she received news of her son's unexpected death. Pain was described as a severe  crushing sensation  radiating to her jaw and left arm. She also reported associated symptoms such as palpitations  diaphoresis  and nausea.
