She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  controlled with lisinopril and atorvastatin respectively. There is no history of coronary artery disease  diabetes mellitus  or previous heart disease. She has never smoked and has a moderate alcohol intake. Her diet is balanced and she engages in regular exercise. Her family history reveals her father had a myocardial infarction in his early 70s.   On physical examination  she looked anxious. Her blood pressure was found to be 160/95 mmHg  heart rate was rapid at 112 beats/minute and irregular  and her respiratory rate was 20 breaths/minute. Cardiac auscultation revealed an S3 gallop and examination of her lungs was normal.   Her ECG demonstrated ST-segment elevation in leads V2-V6  I and aVL  which are indicative of an acute coronary syndrome. However  coronary angiogram did not show significant coronary artery disease. Subsequent echocardiography demonstrated apical ballooning and basal hypercontractility of the left ventricle  leading to a presumptive diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   This patient’s acute stress  presenting symptoms  tests  and the exclusion of significant coronary artery disease points to a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Asian female presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain that started abruptly about two hours ago. The pain is described as a heavy  tight feeling located at the center of the chest  radiating to the back and left arm. The patient also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  profuse perspiration  and lightheadedness.   The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which are well-controlled with medication. She denies history of heart disease or heart attack. She has no known drug allergies. She was a forty-year smoker but quit 12 months ago.  The working diagnosis was an acute coronary syndrome. However  the lack of coronary vessel occlusion on angiogram  characteristic wall motion abnormalities with hypokinesis of the apical and mid segments and hyperkinesis of the basal segments on echocardiogram  and recent encounter of severe emotional stressor (death of her spouse) indicated towards Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department complaining of chest pain that started an hour ago and is radiating to the left arm. She describes the pain as a crushing sensation and rates it an 8 on the scale of 10. She also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  nausea  and lightheadedness. She denies fever  cough  palpitations  changes in color or temperature of the extremities. On arrival  she looks anxious and scared.  She is a widow  living alone. She reports a significant level of stress due to the recent death of her husband. She has a past medical history of hypertension and Type II diabetes managed with losartan and metformin  respectively. She denies any history of heart disease or drug and alcohol abuse. Recent lipid profile reflected well-controlled lipid levels.  Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 162/98 mmHg  heart rate 110 bpm  respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 91% on room air  and temperature of 37°C. On physical examination  heart sounds are regular without any murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lung fields are clear  and there is no ankle edema or jugular venous distension. Rest of the physical examination is within normal limits.  Based on the intensity and quality of pain  age  gender  stress history and known diabetes and hypertension  there is a high suspicion of a cardiac event. Considering her recent history of emotional stress  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome"" is one of the possibilities. Accordingly  an electrocardiogram  cardiac enzymes  and an echocardiogram are ordered to evaluate further.

A 65-year-old Caucasian woman presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the back  associated with nausea and shortness of breath. The pain is described as crushing in nature  lasting for approximately 30 minutes. She reports she has been suffering from severe emotional stress over the last week due to the unexpected loss of her husband.  She has a past medical history significant for hypertension controlled with lisinopril and type 2 diabetes managed with metformin. She denies tobacco  alcohol  or illicit drug use. She lives alone since her husband's passing with her cat. She is retired from a career in teaching. Her parents both had cardiac diseases; her father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 68 and her mother had a stroke at 70.   On presentation  her blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  pulse rate is 105/min  respiratory rate is 22/min  and O2 saturation is 96% on room air. Her physical examination is notable for mild bilateral basilar lung crackles suggestive of pulmonary congestion but no peripheral edema. Initial electrocardiogram (EKG) shows ST elevations in the precordial leads without corresponding reciprocal changes and her troponin levels are markedly elevated. Based on these findings  she is suspected to have takotsubo cardiomyopathy triggered by her recent emotional stress. Confirmation of diagnosis would require an echocardiogram showing a typical pattern of regional wall motion abnormalities that can help differentiate this from myocardial infarction.

Presenting Patient: Mrs. Jane Hansen  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  retired high school teacher and widow with a weight of 158 lbs. and a height of 5'4"".  Chief Complaint: Intense  acute chest pain following a heated argument with her son  accompanied with shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: Hypertension  anxiety disorder  no known history of coronary artery disease  non-smoker  and drinks 1 to 2 units of alcohol per week. She completed menopause at the age of 52 and has been on hormone replacement therapy since then. No family history of premature cardiovascular disease.  Previous Medication: Olmesartan 20 mg once daily for hypertension  and Sertraline 50 mg once daily for anxiety disorder.  Allergies: No known drug allergies.  On Physical Examination: looks anxious  in distress  diaphoretic  heart rate: 110 beats/min  irregular  Blood pressure: 150/90 mmHg  Respiratory rate: 24 breaths/min  Oxygen saturation: 96% on room air. Heart auscultation: Tachycardic. Lungs: Mildly decreased breath sounds bilaterally.  The patient was immediately stabilized  EKG and cardiac enzymes were ordered due to suspicions of acute coronary syndrome  but coronary angiogram found no significant coronary artery stenosis  implying a possible diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. An echo cardiogram was done which showed apical ballooning and basal hypercontractility of the left ventricle  findings suggestive of classic takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female  Mrs. E  presented to the ER with acute-onset  severe chest pain similar to past myocardial infarction she had fifteen years ago. The pain started an hour back  radiating to her left arm  associated with shortness of breath and nausea. Her past medical history revealed hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes mellitus type 2  and a previous episode of acute myocardial infarction. None of her chronic conditions were well-controlled. She is a non-smoker and non-drinker.   The patient reported a significant stressful event yesterday when her daughter was diagnosed with lymphoma. She reported feeling very anxious and depressed after hearing the news. Her medications include metoprolol  glipizide  and Rosuvastatin. The family history is significant for coronary artery disease in both her father and brother. On examination  she was tachycardic and hypertensive. Her ECG findings show ST-elevation in the precordial leads but without reciprocal changes.  Mrs. E has been independent in all her daily activities with a strong support system but reports non-compliance with medications due to multiple financial constraints. She lives with her husband and has a strong relationship with her daughter  who lives nearby.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Elena Rodriguez  a 68-year-old Hispanic female  retired school teacher  presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath for the past 2 hours. She denies any dizziness  syncope  nausea  or vomiting. She describes her pain as substernal  7/10 in intensity  crushing type  non-radiating  not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. The patient is a widow and lives alone. She lost her husband 6 months ago and has been under a lot of stress since his death.  Her past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both well controlled with oral medications. She has no history of smoking  alcohol  or drug abuse. She denies any history of cardiac diseases in the past. She has no known drug allergies.  Her mother had a myocardial infarction at the age of 72 and her father had a stroke at the age of 75. She has no siblings. Her two children are alive and healthy.  On examination  she appears anxious with moderate respiratory distress. Her pulse is 100/min  blood pressure is 140/95 mmHg  respiratory rate is 24/min  oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Heart sounds are normal with no murmurs. Chest reveals bibasilar crackles. Her electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevation in the anterolateral leads.   Given her presentation  the presumptive diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome is made and she is immediately started on aspirin  nitroglycerin  and heparin. However  on coronary angiography  no significant stenosis in any coronary arteries were found  suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  likely triggered by her recent stress.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Anita is a 68-year-old Caucasian female who has presented to the emergency department with chief complaints of shortness of breath  a sudden onset of severe chest pain  and impending sense of doom. She states that the symptoms began abruptly during a heated argument with her neighbor a few hours ago.  She describes the pain as a ""squeezing"" sensation  radiating to her left arm and neck. She denies any nausea  vomiting  sweating  or dizziness. On examination  she is visibly distressed and anxious.  Her past medical history is notable for anxiety disorder and hypertension which is well controlled with angiotensin receptor blockers. She has no known allergies and her family history is unremarkable for cardiovascular diseases. She does not smoke  drinks alcohol occasionally and follows a balanced diet. Her daily activities include yoga and gardening which she enjoys doing.  Initial vital signs include a blood pressure of 155/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 105 beats/minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air.  The rest of the physical examination doesn't show any significant abnormalities. She appears in good health  well-nourished  and well-hydrated. No edema  pallor  or cyanosis is noted. Her chest is clear on auscultation  the breath sounds are normal bilaterally. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia with regular rhythm  there is no audible murmur or gallop.  Her distressing symptoms combined with the normal physical findings suggest the possibility of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy  which might have been precipitated by her recent emotional stressor.

Patient Profile:   Mrs. Alice Bloomfield is a 68-year-old Caucasian woman living in Main Street  Florida. She is a retired schoolteacher  widowed  with two children. She has a history of hypertension  controlled with medication. She does not smoke or drink alcohol and follows a healthy diet. Alice is not physically active due to being overweight with a BMI of 27.  Chief Complaint:   Mrs. Bloomfield visits the ER  presenting with sudden-onset chest pain radiating to the left arm  along with extreme shortness of breath. She rates her pain as a 9/10. The pain surfaced this morning  extreme enough that it woke her from sleep  and has been persistent since then. She also reports a feeling of impending doom.  History of Present Illness:   Mrs. Bloomfield lost her husband of nearly 40 years about a month ago. She has been dealing with severe emotional distress since then.   Vitals:   Blood Pressure: 150/90 mm Hg Pulse: 110 bpm (irregular) Respiration: 24 breaths/minute Temperature: 98.2 F  Clinical Finding:   On examination  mild pedal edema is noticed. Heart sounds reveal an early systolic murmur.  Investigation and Diagnosis:  Her initial EKG shows ST elevation in the precordial leads. Bloodworks reveal slightly raised Troponin I level. Considering her ongoing stress  along with her presenting symptoms and findings  she was diagnosed with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (also known as 'Broken Heart Syndrome') after confirming with an echocardiogram showing apical ballooning of the left ventricle.  Treatment:   A plan is made to manage her hypertension better along with the provision of supportive care and regular follow-ups. A referral is also made for a grief counselor to help her cope with the emotional distress.

Patient Information: Jane Doe  a 51-year-old Asian female who works as a receptionist in a high-stress law firm is admitted to the hospital.  Chief Complaint: Presenting with severe chest pain started suddenly two hours earlier while she was arguing with her boss at work.   History of Present Illness: The patient describes the chest pain sensation as a sharp  crushing pain  associated with breathlessness  and shares that it is her first such episode. The pain does not radiate to her arms  neck or jaw. She also reports feeling nauseated and sweaty but no loss of consciousness or palpitations.  Medical History: Jane denies any previous cardiac problems or surgery. She smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day and has done so for around 10 years. Her mother died suddenly at 68 due to a heart attack. She does not have a diagnosis of diabetes  hypertension  or high cholesterol.  Review of Systems: The patient's review of systems is largely unremarkable. Her last Physical Exam was one year ago  and it was normal. She has no known allergies.  Medications: She takes daily oral contraceptives but no other daily medications.  Family History: Her mother died at 68 due to heart disease and father is 75 years old and has diabetes. Her older sister is healthy.  Physical Exam: She is in physical distress  and her blood pressure is slightly elevated at 145/90 mmHg. Heart rate is 110 bpm. The rest of her physical exam is within normal limits.  In light of the stressful event that triggered the symptoms  a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome"" could be considered  where the patient's extreme emotional stress could have led to a sudden temporary weakening of the heart muscles.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian female who presents with a sudden onset of severe  crushing chest pain  similar to a heart attack  radiating to her left arm and associated with shortness of breath and diaphoresis.  The patient states she felt this pain after being overwhelmed with the news of her husband's sudden demise. Her medical history is significant for hypertension which is being controlled with Hydrochlorothiazide. She also suffered from mild depression for which she was prescribed Fluoxetine  but otherwise she has no history of cardiovascular disease  smoking  diabetes  or high cholesterol.  Family history is positive for ischemic heart disease in her late father. The patient’s BMI is 25 and she has a sedentary lifestyle. She lives alone after her husband's demise and her two children live out of town.  Last week  during a routine check-up  all her lab results  including kidney function and lipid profile  were within normal limits. She had a flu vaccination last month. She is currently taking her prescribed medications correctly. She denies any over-the-counter or recreational drug use. Her last mammogram was a year ago which was normal and her last Pap smear three years ago was also normal. However  she mentions skipping her daily walks since her husband died and having increased her intake of fast food.  The patient appears distressed  tearful  and anxious. Cardiac auscultation reveals tachycardia  but no murmur or gallop. Lung and abdominal examination are normal. Initial electrocardiogram shows ST-elevation in multiple leads and Troponin levels are slightly increased  raising the suspicion of an acute coronary syndrome despite her lack of traditional risk factors.

Patient Presentation:   A 67-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the left arm  shortness of breath  and profuse sweating that started two hours prior. The pain is described as a heaviness  similar to a previous heart attack and is not relieved with rest. The patient also reports a recent emotional stressor  the death of her spouse three weeks ago.   She has a past medical history that includes hypertension and a myocardial infarction five years ago. She is a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol. She reports a family history of heart disease  her mother having suffered a heart attack at the age of 62.  On physical examination  she appears generally unwell  anxious  and is diaphoretic. Blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  pulse is 110 bpm and irregular  respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air.   Based on her history of similar symptoms during a previous myocardial infarction and recent emotional stress  as well as physical examination and elevated cardiac biomarkers found on laboratory testing  a clinical suspicion of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is raised.

Patient Presentation: A 65-year-old Caucasian woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath. The pain is described as severe  pressure-like  radiating to the left arm  not improved or worsened by movement or changes in body position. She rates it as an 8 out of 10 on the pain severity scale. Accompanying symptoms included nausea and diaphoresis. She denies any cough  fever  palpitations  dizziness  or syncope.   Past Medical History: She is a retired school teacher  lives alone  does not smoke cigarettes or take illicit drugs  but admits drinking a glass of red wine a few nights a week. She has a known history of hypertension  for which she takes Lisinopril  and hypercholesterolemia  managed with Atorvastatin. She has a family history significant for coronary artery disease. Her father died from a heart attack at age 72. The patient has recently been going through a contentious divorce and reports feeling increasingly stressed and anxious.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian woman who presents to the Emergency Room with acute onset chest pain radiating to the left arm  associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and a sense of impending doom. The symptoms started about an hour ago while she was watching a distressing news broadcast that reminded her of her late husband.  She reported significant emotional stress over the past few months  stating she feels helpless and depressed since her husband passed away 6 months ago.  Her past medical history includes hypertension (controlled with Lisinopril)  hyperlipidemia (managed with statins)  and diagnosed major depressive disorder for which she's not under any medication.  She denies any history of smoking  illicit drug abuse  or alcohol consumption. Family history is positive for heart diseases with her father dying of a heart attack at the age of 55.  On physical examination  she was obese with a BMI of 31 kg/m2  look anxious  profusely sweating  heart rate was 102 beats per minute  and blood pressure was 168/95 mm Hg. Cardiovascular examination revealed fast heart rate while the rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  The patient's presentation and context — acute onset chest pain with significant emotional stress  already existing risk factors for coronary artery disease (hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and obesity) and normal coronary angiography should raise suspicion for takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Further tests such as an Echocardiogram or cardiac MRI would be needed for definitive diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Ana is a 68-year-old Caucasian female who presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain that started around two hours ago. She described the pain as crushing in nature  radiating to the left arm  and associated with shortness of breath. She rates the pain as 9/10 in severity. The symptoms started when she was informed about the unexpected death of her daughter and she hadn’t experienced anything like this before.   She has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  well controlled on her daily medications: lisinopril and atorvastatin. She does not have any previous history of cardiac diseases. She doesn’t smoke  drinks occasional red wine  and denies the use of illicit drugs. Her mother had a heart attack at the age of 76  and her father died from stroke at the age of 80.   On examination  she appeared distressful. Her vitals were: BP 180/100 mmHg  heart rate 105 bpm  respiratory rate 22/min  and SpO2 95% on room air. Auscultation revealed no murmurs  rubs  or gallops  and lungs were clear. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.   ECG showed ST-segment elevation in precordial leads and labs revealed slightly elevated troponin levels. Despite her typical presentation  her coronary angiogram was normal without any significant obstructions  raising high suspicion for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. She was subsequently managed for the same and showed considerable improvement.

Demographics:  A 68-year-old widowed female  non-smoker  living alone and retired from management position.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient was brought to the emergency department experiencing severe chest pain and shortness of breath. She described the pain as ""crushing"" in nature  radiating to her left arm  and occurred suddenly while preparing to attend the one-year remembrance service of her deceased husband. She associated it with a feeling of extreme stress.  Past Medical History:  She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient also reported a mild depressive disorder for which she was on Cognitive Behavioral Therapy but no medical treatment. She denies previous similar episodes or history of coronary artery disease and there is no family history of early heart disease. Her medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin.   Examination: Patient was anxious  in distress and diaphoretic. Her pulse was 115 beats/min  blood pressure 145/85 mm Hg  O2 saturation on room air was 96%.   An EKG showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Chest X-ray was normal.   Given her symptoms  she was initially managed for acute coronary syndrome. However  her subsequent investigations including blood tests and coronary angiography revealed disproportionately elevated cardiac biomarkers with normal coronary arteries. An echocardiogram revealed apical ballooning and impaired left ventricular function  consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Asian female presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of severe  crushing chest pain. The pain radiates to the arms and is accompanied by shortness of breath  sweating  and a feeling of impending doom. She is a retired teacher  non-smoker  and has no known history of substance abuse. Her only medication is lisinopril for mild hypertension.   Her past medical history is notable for an episode of major depressive disorder following the death of her spouse two years ago  for which she had been on sertraline until six months ago.   She does not take any over-the-counter medications or dietary supplements. She lives alone  has close contact with her two children  and generally reports feeling well. She has not traveled recently and has no known sick contacts. She also reported a stressful event having occurred several days before the onset of the chest pain; her house was burglarized and precious keepsakes were taken.   Physical Examination: The patient appears pale and sweaty  but is able to speak in full sentences. Vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 145/95 mmHg  heart rate 110 beats/minute  respiratory rate 16 breaths/minute  temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F)  oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Cardiac auscultation reveals tachycardia without murmurs  rubs  or gallops. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Based on her presentation  elevated troponin levels  supportive EKG findings  and echocardiogram demonstrating decreased left ventricular function with apical ballooning and basal hyperkinesis  she is diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Johnson is a 65-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension and major depressive disorder presenting with chest pain  shortness of breath  and palpitations following her husband's recent sudden death.   Symptoms:  She reports the symptoms began suddenly during her husband's funeral two days ago and persisted since. The chest pain is central  heavy in nature  radiating towards her left arm. Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea and orthopnea have also been reported  and she has been increasingly fatigued since the symptoms began.  Past Medical History:  Ms. Johnson's medical history consists of well-controlled hypertension  treated with Lisinopril  and a depressive disorder managed with sertraline. She has no personal or family history of heart diseases. She does not drink  smoke  or use any recreational drugs.   Physical Findings:  On physical examination  she has a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals a regular rhythm with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Pulmonary examination is significant for bilateral crackles halfway up both lung fields.   Investigations:  Preliminary blood tests are positive for elevated troponin levels  and an EKG shows ST-elevation in the anterior leads consistent with an anterior wall myocardial infarction. However  subsequent coronary angiogram is negative for coronary artery disease. Echocardiogram  however  shows apical ballooning and contraction abnormalities suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Patient is admitted to the cardiac care unit and is managed supportively for heart failure symptoms. A follow-up appointment is made for a repeat echocardiogram in 2 months to evaluate the resolution of her myocardial dysfunction.

A 68-year-old widowed Caucasian female with a history of chronic generalized anxiety disorder and hypothyroidism presents to the emergency room. Her chief complaints are sudden onset of intense chest pain  shortness of breath  and palpitations that began a few hours following the news of her daughter's fatal car accident.  Her symptoms began acutely and she reported severe  crushing chest pain that radiated to her left arm. She denied any dizziness  syncope  or fatigue.  Her current medications include levothyroxine 50 mcg once daily for hypothyroidism and escitalopram 10 mg daily for anxiety. She has no known drug allergies. She is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol.  Family history is significant for cardiovascular disease in her father and brother.  On examination  she appears visibly distressed and diaphoretic. Vitals include a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats/minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths/minute  oxygen saturation of 94% on room air  and a temperature of 37.1 °C (98.8 °F).  Given her clinical presentation with a significant psychological stressor and her symptomatic presentation highly suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome  a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy was suspected. EKG  cardiac enzymes  and an echocardiogram were ordered. Her EKG results revealed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  raising suspicion for myocardial infarction  but her cardiac enzyme levels were found to be only mildly elevated. The echocardiogram showed a typical pattern for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  with the characteristic apical ballooning and hyperkinesia of the basal segments.  Further diagnostic tests include coronary angiogram  which ruled out significant coronary artery disease  thus supporting the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. She was admitted to the hospital for management and monitoring.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath that started 1 hour ago. The pain is described as a heavy sensation in the middle of her chest which made her feel uncomfortable. She rates the pain as 8/10 on the pain scale. The patient also reports feeling lightheaded and experiencing nausea. She mentions these symptoms began suddenly after she received news of her husband's unexpected passing yesterday evening.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension for ten years controlled with lisinopril. She has no previous history of cardiac disease  lipid disorders  or diabetes. She does not smoke  drink alcohol  or use recreational drugs but has a high-stress job as a company executive. She reports rare exercise due to her busy lifestyle.   Family History: She reports a family history of ischemic heart disease. Her father had a myocardial infarction at 55 years of age  and her mother had angina  but no known congenital heart diseases in the family.  Current Medications:  Lisinopril 10mg once daily for hypertension. No known drug allergies.   Social History: The patient is a widow as of yesterday  has 2 children  lives alone  and is retired from a high-stress job.   This patient presentation raises the suspicion of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced (Broken heart syndrome) cardiomyopathy. Given the patient's recent significant emotional stressor  plus her reported symptoms consistent with a heart-related event align with a potential diagnosis of this condition. Further diagnostic studies such as EKG  cardiac enzyme tests  and potentially an echo-cardiogram may be needed to confirm.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. S  a 67-year-old Caucasian female  presents to the emergency department with acute chest pain  feeling of tightness and shortness of breath  symptoms she says began suddenly upon hearing about her daughter's involvement in a car accident earlier this afternoon. She denies any fever or cough. She looks anxious and somewhat distressed.  Relevant past medical history: Known hypertensive for 15 years  on medication. No history of smoking or alcohol use. Moderate activity level and she lives alone. No previous coronary attacks or other cardiac disease and not known with any other illnesses. Family history of coronary artery disease (her father died of a heart attack at age 75). She is also post-menopausal but denies any hormone replacement therapy.

Patient Profile: A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents in the emergency department.   Presenting Complaint: The patient reports a sudden onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath that started a few hours ago. She describes the pain as similar to what she imagines a heart attack would feel like. She denies feeling nauseated but admits to feeling faint and extremely fatigued.   Medical History: The patient has a past history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are managed with medication. She has no known allergies and is a non-smoker. She also recently lost her husband of 40 years sudden death about a month ago.  Recent Event: The patient reveals that she has been experiencing high levels of stress and emotional trauma since the unexpected death of her spouse a month ago.   Physical Exam Findings: Vital signs are significant for a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg and pulse of 110 beats per minute. Pertinent cardiovascular exam findings include increased intensity of the second heart sound (S2)  S3 gallop  and there is no jugular venous distension.  Based on her presentation  recent emotional trauma  and no extensive coronary artery disease found on cardiac catheterization  a presumptive diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  or 'Broken Heart Syndrome ' is made.

Patient Presentation:   A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain and discomfort. The pain started suddenly while she was at her son's funeral  approximately 2 hours ago. The pain radiates to her left arm and neck. She also complains of shortness of breath  dizziness  and weakness.  Her past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension and hypercholesterolmia for the past 15 years. She is a former smoker  quit smoking 5 years ago  and denies alcohol or recreational drug use. She is a widow  retired  and lives by herself. She denies any history of coronary artery disease  diabetes  or other chronic illnesses.   Her husband passed away last year due to complications from Parkinson's disease. She is currently on medication for hypertension (Lisinopril) and Hypercholesterolmia (Atorvastatin).  Given the emotional stress she has been through recently and her presenting symptoms  a further evaluation for takotsubo cardiomyopathy is considered. Laboratory findings  ECG changes  and imaging studies will be further evaluated to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian female presented in the ER with severe  sharp chest pain increasing over the last 6 hours. Vital signs showed pulse at 115 beats/min  blood pressure at 140/90 mmHg  temperature at 98.2°F  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. She revealed that the chest pain started abruptly during an intense argument with her neighbor. She described the pain as a heavy pressure  rated it as 8 on a scale of 1 to 10  and noted it worsened with deep breathing.   The patient has been single  living alone  just retired from her job as a high school teacher. She admitted to having a history of major depressive disorder and anxiety. She has been generally in good health  was a non-smoker  and did not drink alcohol excessively. With no known allergies to drugs  she was only taking an SSRI for her psychiatric condition. Her mother had a history of heart disease in her later stage of life but there was no other relevant family heart history.  Physical examination found her to be in visible discomfort. Cardiac auscultation revealed tachycardia with no murmur; lung sounds were clear.   This presentation and sequence of events suggest a stress-induced tachycardia  commonly known as Takotsubo cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome"". The patient's baseline health  emotional stress trigger  described symptoms  and preliminary vitals strongly lean towards this diagnosis. Further confirmatory investigations  like EKG  cardiac biomarkers  and echocardiogram  were suggested.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset severe chest pain associated with shortness of breath. The pain started a couple of hours ago and hasn't abated since.  She recently suffered the sudden loss of her husband and reported feeling excessively stressed and overwhelmed since the incident. Her medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and she has been on medication for both. She denies any history of coronary artery disease  diabetes  or smoking.  Vital signs show a rise in the blood pressure and heart rate remarkably. Though her BMI falls within prescribed normal limits  the EKG performed in the emergency department is showing ST-segment elevation. There were no noticeable troponin levels suggesting no myocardial infarction.  The stress echocardiography test showed apical ballooning of the left ventricle with preserved function at the base  indicative of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome.  She has no known drug allergies and is compliant with her daily antihypertensive and cholesterol medications. She maintains a well-balanced diet and performs regular exercise. The sudden emotional stress she has been under appears to be the leading cause culminating in this critical cardiac condition.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. She describes the pain as severe  pressure-like  radiating to her left arm and jaw  and it has become progressively worse over the last hour. She further reports episodes of light-headedness and palpitations along with an overall feeling of being unwell. The pain began while she was attending her husband's funeral. She has no known allergies and denies any use of alcohol or illicit drugs.  Her past medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both controlled with medications (lisinopril and metformin respectively)  and she quit smoking 10 years ago. She recently retired as a teacher  living alone since the death of her husband.  On physical examination  she appears diaphoretic and in distress. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia with a pulse rate of 128 beats per minute and increased jugular venous pressure. Chest examination is largely unremarkable with clear breath sounds bilaterally. The neurological examination shows no abnormalities.  Given the acute onset of her symptoms in the context of a major emotional stressor  the combination of her age  gender  and clinical presentation raise the concern for takotsubo cardiomyopathy. EKG and cardiac enzymes were ordered in the ED to evaluate for acute coronary syndrome  and an echocardiogram is planned to further evaluate for takotsubo cardiomyopathy once the patient is stabilized.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female  recently widowed  that presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe chest pain and shortness of breath for the past 3-4 hours. The pain is described as centrally located  8/10 in intensity  radiating to the left arm  and not relieved by nitroglycerin which she has at home for her previously diagnosed angina. She endorsed associated symptoms of diaphoresis and nausea.  The patient has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  emotional stress and grief due to the recent death of her spouse a few weeks ago  and chronic stable angina. She is current on her medications which include aspirin 81mg daily  atorvastatin 40 mg daily  and metoprolol 50mg twice a day. She is allergic to sulfa drugs resulting in skin rash. The patient denies any history of smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use.   Given the symptoms  recent emotional stress  and a history of ischemic heart disease  a differential diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy is being considered  among other potential differentials like myocardial infarction. An urgent cardiology consultation is sought for further diagnosis and management.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian female who presents to the emergency room with severe chest pain that is similar to a heart attack. She describes central  radiating pain to her left arm  accompanied by breathlessness. The symptoms started suddenly after she learned about the unexpected death of her brother.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are well-controlled with medications. She is a former smoker with a 20-pack year history  but she quit 15 years ago. She has no known drug allergies. The patient denies any previous cardiac issues. She had a total knee arthroplasty 5 years ago. She lives alone and is relatively active.    Family History:  Her mother died of stroke at age 75  and her father passed away from complications of diabetes at age 80. Her brother  whose death she has been deeply affected by  died of heart attack at the age of 65.   Social History:  She retired 2 years ago after a long career as a school teacher. She drinks alcohol occasionally and does not use illicit drugs. She is divorced and has two adult children. She had been seeing a therapist for mild anxiety  especially since her retirement.    Medication History:  Long-term medications include amlodipine 5mg daily for hypertension  atorvastatin 20 mg every night for hyperlipidemia  Aspirin 80mg once a day for heart health  multivitamins  and occasional lorazepam for anxiety.   Review of Symptoms:   In addition to the chest pain and shortness of breath  the patient also describes feeling a sense of impending doom  and an onset of nausea and profuse sweating. However  she denies symptoms of headache  abdominal pain  cough  or urinary symptoms.

Patient Presentation: Mrs. X is a 70-year-old Caucasian female who presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of severe chest pain. The pain began about 2 hours prior to her arrival and is described as sharp  persistent  and located in the center of her chest. It does not radiate and is not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin.  Past Medical History: Mrs. X has a history of hypertension  for which she takes lisinopril. She has no known history of coronary artery disease  does not smoke  and leads an active lifestyle. She has recently completed 40 years of a successful career as a teacher and is now retired. She currently lives with her husband and is largely independent in her activities of daily living.  Other Information: Mrs. X reports experiencing significant emotional stress over the past week following the sudden death of her sister. She is otherwise general well but admits to having feelings of sadness due to her recent stressful event.   The clinical presentation and the preceding stress suggest a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy which should be confirmed with an appropriate diagnostic workup including ECG  cardiac enzymes  and echocardiography.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department. She describes a sudden onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath that started a few hours ago. The pain radiates to her left shoulder and is accompanied by feelings of impending doom. She has a history of generalized anxiety disorder and hypertension and had experienced a significant emotional stressor earlier in the day due to a sudden death in her family.   She denies a history of smoking  alcohol abuse  or illicit drug use. She has a past medical history significant for well-controlled hypertension and generalized anxiety disorder  each of which is managed with oral medication regimens. Her physiological measurements are as follows: blood pressure 150/90 mmHg  heart rate is 100 beats per minute  oxygen saturation is 93% on room air  and respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute. Her family history is significant for cardiac disease with her mother suffering a myocardial infarction at 70 years old.   Today's acute symptoms  combined with her history of hypertension and the severe emotional stressor she experienced today  are suspicious for takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Her physical exam and subsequent diagnostic workup will further confirm or reject this working diagnosis.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain radiating to her left arm  associated with shortness of breath. The pain began suddenly one hour ago while she was arguing with her husband and has been persistent since then. She describes the pain as ""pressure-like"" and rates it 8/10 in severity.   She denies having any nausea  vomiting or diaphoresis. However  she appears anxious and distressed. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension  well-controlled on meds  and hyperlipidemia. She is a non-smoker and rarely drinks alcohol. She had a normal stress test about two years ago.   She communicates that she has been under significant stress lately due to the deteriorating health of her husband and recent financial hardships. Initial vital signs on presentation: HR: 110 beats/min  BP: 160/90 mmHg  RR: 20 breaths/min  SpO2: 95% on room air and she is afebrile.   Her physical examination is within normal limits apart from tachycardia. Her ECG shows ST elevations in the precordial leads and her initial troponin I level is elevated. The sudden onset of her symptoms with emotional stress  elevated cardiac markers  and suggestive ECG changes lead to the suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 66-year-old female with a past medical history of hypertension and generalized anxiety disorder who presents with a complaint of severe chest pain. She describes the pain as substernal  with a pressure-like quality but denies radiation to the arms or jaw. Her symptoms began abruptly this morning following a heated argument with a family member  with the pain increasing over several hours. She has been experiencing periodic palpitations and mild shortness of breath. She does not have any history of coronary artery disease  and her medication list includes only an antihypertensive and an anxiolytic. She does not smoke  consume alcohol or use recreational drugs. She is widowed and lives alone. She has a familial history of heart disease with her father dying from a myocardial infarction in his 60s. Examination reveals a slightly elevated blood pressure but otherwise is largely unremarkable. ECG shows ST segment elevation in the anterior leads.

Patient Information: Ms. Morgan  a 68-year-old  Caucasian female.  Presenting Complaint:  Ms. Morgan presents to the emergency department with symptoms of severe chest pain and difficulty in breathing. These symptoms have started abruptly an hour ago while she was dealing with a stressful family emergency.  Past Medical History:  Ms. Morgan's clinical history includes well-controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes. She has a history of bereavement as she lost her husband 2 years ago. No history of prior coronary artery disease  myocardial infarction  or any surgeries. She quit smoking 10 years ago but did have a smoking history of 20 pack-years. No known drug allergies.  Family History: Her family history reveals no heart disease but both her parents had hypertension and her father had type 2 diabetes.  Review of Systems: Cardiovascular review indicates a sudden onset of acute chest pain  analogous to acute coronary syndrome. Other systems review is largely unremarkable.  Physical Exam: Vital signs show tachycardia and increased blood pressure. An examination reveals no audible murmurs  but there are some crackles heard at lung bases. Overall  the patient appears in acute distress due to pain.  Summary: A 68-year-old female patient presented with sudden intense chest pain and shortness of breath in the setting of significant acute emotional stress  suggestive of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (Broken Heart Syndrome). ECG to be performed for further evaluation  as well as cardiac enzymes levels to be monitored. Cardiology consult requested for further management.

A 67-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden severe chest pain radiating to her left arm  associated with shortness of breath and feelings of nausea. She states the symptoms commenced a few hours ago at her husband's funeral  a highly emotional event for her. She also mentions a similar occurrence of chest pain two years ago  but she did not seek medical attention at that time.  Her past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are well managed on medications  including Hydrochlorothiazide and Atorvastatin. In terms of family history  her mother had coronary artery disease. She is a non-smoker and denies having any alcohol or drug use. She has been living alone since her husband was diagnosed with terminal cancer.  The sudden onset of her symptoms  combined with her history of cardiovascular risk factors and recent emotionally stressful event  raise the suspicion for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome.

A 58-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presented to the emergency department with acute onset chest pain  diaphoresis  and palpitations. The pain was tiered at 8 on a scale of 1-10  described as sharp  located in the substernal area  and radiated to her left arm. She reported onset one hour ago after receiving news of her brother's sudden death. This is the first time she has experienced such symptoms. The patient denied any prior history of chest pain or diagnosis of coronary artery disease; her only prescribed medications are Lisinopril for hypertension and Atorvastatin for elevated cholesterol. The risk factors for her cardiovascular health include her age  a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  current smoking  and a family history of early coronary artery disease in her father. This severe stress and distress  combined with her symptoms  may imply Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome.""

A 65-year-old Caucasian female  Mrs. Smith presents to the Emergency Department with complaints of severe chest pain and shortness of breath  feeling as if she is ""having a heart attack."" She reports the symptoms began suddenly while she was attending the funeral of her husband who died two weeks ago. Mrs. Smith has no known personal or family history of cardiovascular disease but is a 30 pack-year (1.5 packs per day for 20 years) smoker with well-controlled hypertension being managed with amlodipine.  On examination  she's slightly diaphoretic  anxious with vital signs showing resting heart rate: 104 bpm; breathing rate: 22 breaths/min; blood pressure: 140/90 mm Hg; and oxygen saturation: 96% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia without murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lungs are clear to auscultation. No edema or evidence of deep vein thrombosis in extremities.  She also has an ongoing major depressive disorder for the past five years and is under treatment with SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors). She also complains about lack of sleep and appetite since her husband's passing. Overall  she seems to be suffering from acute emotional distress.

Patient Presentation:   Ms. Johnson is a 72-year-old Caucasian female presenting to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to her left arm. The pain started about four hours ago  following a stressful argument with her son. The patient also reports experiencing shortness of breath  nausea  and light-headedness.  Relevant Past Medical History:  Ms. Johnson is a widow who lives alone but her son visits her often. She is a former smoker quit twenty years ago  and her alcohol use is moderate. She has a history of hypertension controlled with medication  and no history of heart disease. She was previously diagnosed with major depressive disorder and anxiety and is currently on Fluoxetine and Alprazolam. She denied recreational drugs use. Ms. Johnson had breast cancer treated with lumpectomy and radiation fifteen years ago  followed by ten years of adjuvant tamoxifen therapy. She has no known family history of heart disease.

The patient is a 68-year-old postmenopausal female who presents with severe chest pain radiating to the neck  jaw  and left arm. She reports feeling sudden intense stress and emotional trauma due to the recent death of her husband. Upon arrival to the ER  she was found to be sweaty and pale  with elevated blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg and tachycardia of 110bpm.   Her past medical history is significant for mild hypertension  controlled on lisinopril and asthma. Her only surgical history involves a knee replacement surgery 5 years ago. Considering her cardiac history  she had a normal stress echocardiogram 6 months prior to this incident. Her family history is significant for a father who died of a myocardial infarction in his late 50s.   She is a non-smoker  occasional alcohol drinker  and denies illegal drug use. She says she enjoys socializing with her bridge club and taking daily walks for exercise. She takes 10mg lisinopril daily  inhalers for asthma  and over-the-counter multivitamins.  The sudden onset of severe chest pain following a highly stressful incident  elevated blood pressure  and the ECG showing ST-segment elevation suggest Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome.""

The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female presenting with acute onset of chest discomfort. She describes the pain as ""like an elephant sitting on my chest”  and rates it a 7 on the pain scale of 10. The pain began suddenly while she was attending the funeral of her close friend. She reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  lightheadedness  palpitations  and a sense of impending doom.   The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and anxiety disorder. She doesn't smoke or drink alcohol and she is a widow with 3 adult children. She retired as a school teacher about 8 years ago. She has been under a significant amount of stress lately due to the death of her friend.   She takes medication for her hypertension and cholesterol  and she has been prescribed alprazolam  which she takes as needed for her anxiety. She has no known drug allergies. Her physical examination reveals unremarkable findings  except for mild tachycardia.  This patient presentation is indicative of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as 'broken heart syndrome'  often precipitated by intense emotional or physical stress. It mimics acute coronary syndrome but usually with no significant coronary artery disease. The typical patient is a post-menopausal woman.

Patient Presentation:  A 69-year-old retired Japanese woman presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of intense chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient reports the pain radiating to the left arm and seems to be slightly alleviated by sitting up and leaning forward.  Demographics Details:  - Age: 69 - Sex: Female - Ethnicity: Japanese - Occupation: Retired - Social History: Non smoker  occasional alcohol drinker - Family History: Nil significant  Past Medical History:  The patient reveals that she has experienced a high level of emotional stress over the past week due to the sudden passing of her husband. There is no significant past medical history of heart disease  and she denies any history of hypertension  diabetes  or high cholesterol. She is not on any regular medications  has no known drug allergies and her immunizations are up to date.  Physician notes post-visit: Possible takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken heart syndrome) due to recent major life stressor  symptoms mimicking a heart attack and lack of significant past heart disease history. Further testing required.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Rodriguez  a 68-year-old Hispanic woman presents today with severe chest pain and shortness of breath. She complains that the pain began suddenly three hours ago at home  describing it as a crushing sensation in the middle of her chest  radiating to her left arm.  Her past medical history is significant for hypertension controlled with hydrochlorothiazide  and hypercholesterolemia controlled with atorvastatin. She denies any history of illicit drug use  alcohol intake  or tobacco smoking. Also  she doesn't have personal or family history of heart disease.   Her husband passed away two weeks ago and she has acknowledged intense emotional stress over this period.   On physical examination  patient appears frail and anxious. She has vital signs within normal limits except for a blood pressure of 153/88 mmHg. No murmurs or extra heart sounds are heard and lung sounds are clear bilaterally. No peripheral edema is noted.  Based on her symptoms  recent severe emotional stress and absence of obstructive coronary artery disease  a diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy is suspected.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Jean is a 68-year-old Caucasian widow who presents to the Emergency Department with intermittent chest pain  palpitations  and shortness of breath that began suddenly this morning. She describes the pain as ""feeling like an elephant is sitting on my chest"" and rates it as an 7/10. She rates her dyspnea as moderate.  Patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension  for which she takes Lisinopril  and hypothyroidism  managed with Levothyroxine. She has no known history of coronary artery disease and no prior history of similar symptoms. She has never smoked and denies using any recreational drugs.  Her husband passed away a month ago and she confesses she has been under excessive emotional stress. She denies any recent trauma or intense physical exertion. She has no known drug allergies and follows a balanced diet.  From the social history  she lives alone but her adult children visit her alternately every week. She doesn't consume alcohol but drinks 2 cups of coffee daily. Her father had a history of heart disease.  On physical examination  she is visibly distressed and anxious. Vital signs show tachycardia and blood pressure is mildly elevated at 140/90. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia without any murmur. Her lung fields are clear to auscultation. Rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Given her symptoms and recent emotional stress she is suspected to have Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as ""broken heart syndrome""). Next steps include conducting an ECG  Troponin measurements  and an echocardiogram to confirm this diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain that started about an hour ago during a deeply emotional family conflict. She describes the pain as central  heavy crushing in nature and 8/10 in intensity. She says she also has associated shortness of breath  nausea and feels lightheaded. She denies having any cough  leg swelling or recent long-distance travel.   Her past medical history is significant for well-controlled hypertension  dyslipidemia and a previous episode of major depressive disorder 2 years ago  for which she had counselling and was on selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI's) for a year. She denies any history of diabetes  asthma or other respiratory diseases  kidney disease  or any personal or familial history of heart disease. She is a non-smoker  and consumes alcohol moderately. She has never used any recreational drugs  nor has she undergone any significant surgery in her life.  Her current medications include lisinopril for her hypertension  and atorvastatin for her dyslipidemia. She has no known drug allergies.   Considering her age  gender  emotional trigger  and the sudden presentation of chest pain  a preliminary diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy  is suspected.

A 70-year-old Caucasian woman presents to the emergency department experiencing chest pain  shortness of breath  and episodes of lightheadedness. The onset of her symptoms was sudden. She explains that she's been under significant emotional stress due to the recent death of her husband.  Her medical history reveals type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the past 10 years. Both conditions are well-managed with medication (metformin  lisinopril  and amlodipine). She has no known allergies. Her mother had a stroke in her late seventies. She is a recent widow with three adult children  a retired school teacher  and quit smoking fifteen years ago. She denies alcohol or drug misuse.  On physical exam  her blood pressure is moderately elevated at 150/95 and her pulse rate is 100 beats per minute. She appears anxious and diaphoretic. Cardiovascular exam is positive for soft third heart sound. No other significant physical findings noted.   EKG shows ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  and initial blood tests show a slightly elevated troponin level. Further diagnostic testing  including echocardiogram  showed wall motion abnormalities consistent with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Patient Presentation:   A 61-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with symptoms consisting of chest pain and shortness of breath  which she described starting suddenly earlier in the day  more intense during periods of rest  unrelated to physical effort and described as a tight pressure sensation in her chest. The patient rates the pain as 8/10 and mentions that it radiates to her left arm. She also reports feeling nausea and light-headedness. She denies any history of tobacco smokes  diabetes  or substance misuse.   Past medical history is significant for major depressive disorder for which she takes fluoxetine  hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide  and hyperlipidemia with atorvastatin. She has a recent stressful event  the death of her husband one month prior.   This woman does not have any history of cardiac disease and has never experienced similar symptoms before. She has been under a lot of emotional stress since her husband's death. All these factors together increase the possibility of a diagnosis like takotsubo cardiomyopathy which is often linked to a high-stress event. However  further investigations are necessary for correct diagnosis and treatment.

Patient Presentation:  A 56-year-old African-American female presents to the emergency room with a one-day history of severe  substernal chest pain that radiates to her arm. The pain is described as squeezing and is associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and lightheadedness. The intensity of pain is 10 out of 10  and she also mentions palpitations and a sudden onset severe headache.  Past medical history: The patient is recently divorced and has been under significant stress over the past few months managing her life's transition. She has past medical history significant for well-controlled hypertension and is taking Lisinopril for the same. She has no known cardiac history and does not have a family history of early heart disease. She has never smoked or used illicit drugs and drinks alcohol socially.  Social History: She lives alone  has two children and works as a school teacher. She denies any history of travel  recent illnesses or trauma. She is not involved in any strenuous activities. She is not aware of any family history of similar complaints.  Review of systems: She has been experiencing a few episodes of transient  generalized weakness along with increased frequency of headaches for the past two weeks. She has lost about 5 pounds of weight over the past month without dieting. She denies any fever  chills  cough  or abdominal discomfort.  Physical examination: Vital signs are stable except for a mildly elevated blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg. Cardiovascular exam reveals tachycardia but is otherwise normal. Other systems are unremarkable on examination.   This information is consistent with a possible diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  which is also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome."" Further investigations are ordered to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of chest pain radiating to her left arm  accompanied by shortness of breath  palpitations and extreme fatigue. She describes the pain as a crushing sensation similar to what she assumes a heart attack would feel like. Her symptoms occurred suddenly while she was attending the funeral of her recently deceased husband.  Past Medical History:  According to the patient's records  she has been previously healthy. She exercises regularly  does not smoke or consume excessive alcohol. She has no history of cardiovascular disease or hypertension. Her cholesterol levels are within normal ranges. The chief reason for her visits in the past have been mild seasonal allergies.   The patient reports that for the past two weeks  following her husband's death  she has been under significant emotional stress and has been experiencing symptoms of anxiety including trouble sleeping  and feelings of restlessness.  From a family perspective  no significant hereditary illnesses were noted. The only noteworthy point is her father who had died from myocardial infarction at the age of 79.  The patient's signs and symptoms  coupled with her recent severe emotional stress  suggest a possible diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome. Further diagnostic steps will be required to confirm this diagnosis including an EKG and possibly an echocardiogram or cardiac MRI.

A 75-year-old Caucasian woman presented to the Emergency Department with a 3-hour history of chest pain that she described as similar to the pain of an “elephant sitting on my chest”. She stated that the pain began about 15 minutes after receiving news of her son's sudden death. She rated the pain as 10/10 and described it as being heavy or crushing in nature. She endorsed radiating pain down her left arm  shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis.   Medical history is significant for hypertension and high cholesterol for which she is taking amlodipine 10mg daily and atorvastatin 20mg daily respectively. There is no known history of heart disease  though she states that both of her parents died in their 60s due to ""heart problems"". She denies any history of tobacco or illicit drug use. She consumes an occasional glass of wine. She worked as a secretary until she retired at age 65. She has been living alone since her husband passed away 5 years ago and is largely independent in her daily activities.   On further questioning  she admits to feeling very stressed and anxious over the past few weeks due to her son's lingering illness. She states that she has not slept or eaten well and has been feeling quite fatigued. She denies any suicidal ideation and is quite distressed and in grief over her son's recent death.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female with a medical history significant for hypertension  generalized anxiety disorder  and recent loss of her husband four weeks ago presents to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain. She describes the pain as similar to a ""heart attack "" with severe crushing sensation radiating to her left arm  and has been experiencing it for the past hour. She notes having difficulties with sleeping due to her grief  feeling chronically stressed and anxious recently. She denies any history of chest pain in the past  smoking  or drug use. She lives alone and consumes alcohol occasionally. Her only medications are lisinopril for hypertension and alprazolam for anxiety as needed. Her mother died from congestive heart failure in her seventies  and her father had a history of coronary artery disease. She has no known drug allergies. On physical examination  she appears anxious and diaphoretic but is not in obvious distress. Other than tachycardia with a heart rate in the 100s  the rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Carter  a 56-year-old Caucasian woman  presents in the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to her back and associated with shortness of breath. She reports the symptoms started this morning after receiving stressful news about her son's car accident. Her pain is 8 out of 10 in intensity and started 3 hours ago. She has a history of hypertension for which she is on Lisinopril. She has never smoked nor had any alcohol or illicit drug use. No known allergies have been reported. She denies any previous similar events or cardiac disease. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in her father at the age of 62. She works as a high school principal and lives with her husband.  On examination  her blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg  pulse 110 bpm  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  and her oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Her cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia with no murmurs  rubs or gallops. There is no pedal edema. Lung fields are clear to auscultation bilaterally.  Her EKG shows ST-segment elevation in leads V2-V6  I  aVL along with elevated troponin levels. Given her presentation and preliminary investigations  she is suspected to have takotsubo cardiomyopathy. She is admitted for further investigations including echocardiography or coronary angiography and treatment.

Patient Information:  A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department.  Chief Complaint: She complains of acute onset chest pain that started this morning  almost an hour after her husband passed away at home. The chest pain is central  severe  and radiates to left arm  similar to what she believes a heart attack may feel like.   History of Present Illness: The patient reports this type of chest pain is new for her and she’s never experienced anything similar in the past. She also mentions associated shortness of breath. The pain is not relieved by rest or movement. There are no other associated symptoms like nausea  vomiting  or dizziness  she denies any palpitations.  Past Medical History: - History of Hypertension  last checkup was 3 months ago  controlled with medication. - Minor stroke 2 years ago  complete recovery.  - No known cardiac diseases.  Family History: Her mother passed away from a heart attack and father from a stroke. Her older brother has early onset coronary artery disease.   Social History: She is a recently widowed. She doesn’t smoke  drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. She eats a balanced diet and walks daily.  Medications: Currently being treated with a diuretic for her hypertension  and aspirin for stroke prevention.  Review of Systems: Chest: Severe central chest pain  feeling heavy as if there’s pressure  radiates to left arm. Cardiovascular: Shortness of breath. All other systems are negative.  Examination: Vital signs are stable but patient appears anxious and distressed due to chest pain. Cardiac examination shows regular rhythm and rate  no murmurs. There's mild tachycardia. All other physical findings within normal range.   This patient's symptoms  history of hypertension  recent extremely stressful event and her age places her at a risk for a cardiovascular event  which may include takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Further diagnostic and laboratory investigations  such as EKG and cardiac biomarkers  are needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Subjective: 71-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department experiencing severe chest pain and shortness of breath starting early this morning. The onset of symptoms was sudden. Pain radiates to the left arm. No history of similar episodes. This scenario started after she received news of her daughter's sudden death yesterday. She had been in good health prior to this event. The patient's pain score was 8 out of 10. Patient rates the difficulty of breathing as moderate and worse when lying flat. She denies cough or fever but admits to feeling light-headed at times and a general sense of fatigue. She has no known history of heart disease. Her medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  prescriptions for which she has been taking regularly.  Objective: Patient's vitals are BP: 160/100  HR: 110 bpm  RR: 18 breaths/min  SpO2: 95% on room air and Temperature: 37.2°C. Patient looked anxious and in distress. Cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia. There was no audible murmur or irregular rhythm. Lung fields were clear on auscultation. Remaining physical examination was unremarkable.  Assessment: Based on the history of sudden severe emotional stress  typical presenting symptoms of severe chest pain and shortness of breath  high blood pressure and elevated heart rate  differential diagnoses can include Acute Coronary Syndrome and Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as ‘broken heart' syndrome.  Plan: Will send patient for EKG  chest X-ray  and blood tests including Troponins. If the EKG and chest X-ray aren't indicative of any other cause  and Troponins are mildly elevated  an echocardiogram will be done to diagnose Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. If confirmed  patient will be admitted to the Cardiology unit for observation and management  as well as referral to a grief counselor for the severe emotional stress.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Thompson is a 68-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for hypertension  major depressive disorder  and chronic migraine headaches. Over the past 24 hours  she experienced acute onset chest pain  dyspnea  and a sense of impending doom  which led her to seek emergency medical attention. She noted the onset of her symptoms following the sudden  unexpected death of her husband the previous day. She has never had similar symptoms before and is quite worried  given her husband died of a heart attack. She denies smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use. Medications she is taking include lisinopril for her hypertension  sumatriptan for her migraines  and escitalopram for her depression. She reports being compliant with her medications. She is retired and lives with her adult daughter since she became a widow. Family history is remarkable for coronary artery disease in her late husband and her father  who died in his early 70s. She denied allergies to any medications.

A 67-year-old Caucasian woman presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain and shortness of breath  which started suddenly an hour ago after she received the news of her daughter's sudden death. The pain is severe  located in the center of the chest  radiating to the left arm  and not relieved by nitroglycerin.   She has a past medical history of hypertension controlled with lisinopril and atherosclerosis. She denies any history of smoking  alcohol intake  or illicit drug use. She retired from her job as a schoolteacher 5 years ago. Her family history is significant for coronary artery disease in her father who died at the age of 68.  On examination  she appeared distressed and diaphoretic. Her blood pressure was 168/92 mmHg  pulse rate 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 per minute  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Cardiac examination showed tachycardia with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Pulmonary examination revealed clear bilateral breath sounds.  Her EKG shows ST-segment elevations in precordial leads V2 to V5. Laboratory results reveal elevated troponin levels and normal complete blood count  electrolytes  liver  and kidney function. She is being evaluated for acute coronary syndrome given her presentation and preliminary findings  however  her emotional stress history and EKG changes make takotsubo cardiomyopathy a consideration in the differential diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain that radiates to her left arm  accompanied by shortness of breath  dizziness  and a sense of impending doom. She describes the pain as a ""gripping"" sensation and she rates it 9/10. She also mentioned that she had a syncopal episode at home today morning.   The patient's blood pressure is 115/80 mmHg  pulse is 120 beats per minute  respirations are 22 breaths per minute  and SpO2 is 95% in room air. She appears anxious  diaphoretic and pale.   Upon questioning  she reveals a recent severe emotional stress. She lost her husband of 40 years to cancer just 1 week prior. She also mentions that she has a history of depression and hypertension and is currently taking antidepressants and antihypertensive medications. She is a non-smoker and takes occasional alcohol. She mentions having similar chest pain 4 years ago that was diagnosed as acid reflux.  Her family history includes maternal grandmother with myocardial infarction and father with stroke. Her mother has diabetes.  The patient's BMI is 28 and she informs that her physical activity is low.   Immediate ECG shows ST-segment elevation  and initial cardiac enzymes hit positive. However  the coronary angiogram shows normal coronary arteries. Echocardiography reveals an apical ballooning pattern and mild reduction of left ventricular systolic function  consistent with a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Subject is a 68-year-old postmenopausal white female who presents to the emergency department with complaints of a sudden onset of severe retrosternal chest pain radiating to the left upper arm that occurred following the sudden death of her spouse two days ago. Patient characterizes the pain as “crushing” in nature and rating it 8/10 in intensity. Associated symptoms include lightheadedness  diaphoresis  and a feeling of impending doom.   The patient has no history suggestive of ischemic heart disease or diabetes. She has a former smoking history but quit 20 years ago. She has been regularly taking anti-hypertensive medication [lisinopril] and a statin for her hypertension and hypercholesterolemia respectively. She has an allergy to sulfa antibiotics and has had no surgeries in the past. No history of recreational drug use  denies alcohol intake.  Patient is visibly anxious and upset. On physical examination  she has elevated blood pressure of 150/100mmHg and a heart rate of 110 beats per minute - suggestive of some stress. Cardiovascular exam reveals a faint systolic murmur  lungs are clear  and no dyspnea is noted.  ECG and Troponin T results suggest acute coronary syndrome but coronary angiography is not suggestive of significant coronary artery disease. Left ventriculography reveals an apical ballooning pattern with basal hypermobility suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   This case demonstrates a patient presenting with cardiogenic chest pain following severe emotional stress with a clinical diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Johnson is a 72-year-old Caucasian female presenting with severe chest pain that radiates to the jaw and left arm. She describes the pain as a heavy pressure  rating it 7 out of 10 on the pain scale. She reports increasing severity of symptoms over the past few hours. The patient also describes shortness of breath  lightheadedness  and nausea.  The patient is a widow and a retired teacher living alone with her pet dog. She lost her husband 5 months ago and has been under immense psychological stress since then. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  both of which are well-controlled with medication. She denies smoking and alcohol use but admits to a relatively sedentary lifestyle.  Ms. Johnson’s vitals upon arrival are as follows: BP 165/95 mmHg  pulse of 110 bpm  and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Physical examination shows mild jugular venous distension  cold extremities  and slightly irregular heart sounds.  Initial EKG shows ST elevations in leads II  III  and aVF and troponin I levels are elevated at 0.8 ng/mL. These findings strongly suggest an acute myocardial infarction. However  given the presence of severe ongoing stress  absence of significant coronary artery disease history  and the slightly atypical nature of her EKG  the clinical suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy is high.  Confirmation of takotsubo cardiomyopathy will require further evaluation with an echocardiogram  showing characteristic left ventricular apical ballooning  and potentially a cardiac catheterization to rule out critical coronary artery disease.
