Slide 4: - Presenting symptoms: Patient was brought to the ER showing signs of severe chest pain  shortness of breath  lightheadedness and nausea. Symptoms onset followed the sudden death of her pet  pointing towards an emotional trigger.  Slide 5: - Clinical Examination: Results show ST-segment elevation in ECG  mildly elevated troponin level but no obstructive coronary disease on angiography.  Slide 6: - Diagnosis: A diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy was established based on Coronary Angiogram and Left Ventriculogram findings  incorporating the typical image of a “ballooning” left ventricle  in conjunction with her emotional stressor. An important note is the reversibility of this condition  with potential for complete recovery with proper management and care.  Slide 8: - Conclusion: The case illuminates the veracity of the mind-heart interaction in the wake of emotional stressors. High importance must be given to psychological wellbeing  particularly in patients with pre-existing risk factors or those displaying symptoms of cardiac distress following a severe emotional event.

Title: Case Presentation on Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Slide 1: Introduction Patient Introduction: Female  Aged 68  Caucasian  Slide 2: Past Medical History The patient has a past history of hypothyroidism and generalized anxiety disorder. No history of substance abuse  nor any significant hereditary disease. The physical examination was notable for diaphoresis and distress  trace peripheral edema  and no audible cardiac murmurs. As part of differential diagnosis  a coronary angiogram was performed  which ruled out a myocardial infarction. Left ventriculography demonstrated apical ballooning of the left ventricle with preserved basal function  suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM). Her chest pain improved within 48 hours  repeat troponin levels started to decline  and her condition remained stable throughout her hospital course.  Slide 7: Follow-up Two weeks following discharge  echocardiogram showed complete resolution of the apical ballooning and normalization of the left ventricular function  confirming the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The patient was prescribed regular follow-ups and mental health support. She was also instructed on identifying and managing triggers for acute stress.  Slide 8: Conclusion Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  often associated with sudden emotional stress  can mimic a myocardial infarction. It is crucial to recognize the importance of detailed medical history and specific diagnostic tests to differentiate between the two  leading to the appropriate treatment plan.  (Note: This presentation is hypothetical in nature and does not involve any real patients or violate any privacy rights.)

Title: A Case Study on Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Slide 1: Introduction Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome""  is a disease in which intense emotional or physical stress can cause rapid and severe heart muscle weakness.   Slide 2: Case Presentation: Patient Demographics Our patient is a 68-year-old female  retired school teacher with Caucasian ethnicity. She is a widow and presently lives alone.   Slide 3: Past Medical History The patient has a history of Hypertension treated with antihypertensive therapy  and was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus five years ago. No history of smoking  alcohol or drug abuse. No previous diagnoses of heart disease.  Slide 4: Presenting Complaints Patient presented at the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain  difficulty breathing and lightheadedness. The onset of these symptoms coincided with the recent death of her beloved pet.  Slide 5: Diagnosis With the given history  physical examination  ECG showing ST-elevation and cardiac enzymes that were slightly elevated  an initial assessment of acute coronary syndrome was made. However  a coronary angiogram showed no significant coronary artery disease to explain the severity of symptoms. The echocardiogram showed a typical pattern of apical ballooning with hyperkinesis of basal segments  suggestive of Takotsubo or stress cardiomyopathy.  Slide 6: Management The patient was treated conservatively with heart failure medications including beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors. Psychological support was also provided given the link between stress and the onset of symptoms.  Slide 7: Outcome and Prognosis Within a month  repeat echocardiography demonstrated much improved cardiac function. Patient was also given counselling sessions to handle bereavement.   Slide 8: Key points This case highlights the importance of considering Takotsubo cardiomyopathy in differential diagnosis in patients  particularly post-menopausal women  presenting with symptoms suggestive of acute coronary syndrome. It underscores how severe emotional stress can lead to severe  but usually reversible  heart muscle failure.  Slide 9: Conclusion Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is a great mimic of acute coronary syndrome and undoubtedly requires a high index of clinical suspicion for diagnosis. Management is supportive and the condition generally has good prognosis.  Slide 10: Questions and Discussion Open floor for questions  discussion  and shared experiences.

Slide 1: Introduction Title: Case Presentation: A Case of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Our case involves a 60-year-old Caucasian female with a significant history of acute emotional stress due to the unexpected death of her spouse.  Slide 3: Past Medical History The patient is a nonsmoker and does not consume any alcohol. She has a prior medical history of Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia.   Slide 4: Presenting Complaint The patient presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain and shortness of breath. These symptoms  resembling those of a heart attack  surfaced suddenly a few hours following her husband’s funeral.  Slide 5: Symptoms  Aside from the chest pain  the patient also reported feeling extreme weakness  dizziness  and an acute sense of anxiety. No fever  nausea  or vomiting was noted. No history of similar symptoms in the past.  Slide 6: Physical Examination Upon examination  the patient's blood pressure was found to be elevated  and she had a heart rate of 110 beats per minute. Cardiac exam revealed no murmurs  rubs or gallops. Respiratory examination was within normal limits.  Slide 7: Diagnosis Based on her initial symptoms  high stress levels  and ECG changes that showed ST-segment elevation  a diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (also known as Broken-heart syndrome) was suspected.  Slide 8: Confirmatory Tests An angiogram was performed  revealing no significant coronary artery disease  confirming the suspicion of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy. Echocardiogram showed that left ventricular function was dyskinetic in the shape of “octopus trap” - a characteristic of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.  Slide 9: Treatment and Management The patient was admitted to the Cardiac Care Unit. She was started initially on beta-blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  and anticoagulants to manage her symptoms and prevent thrombus formation.  Slide 10: Prognosis and Follow-up Studies have shown that people with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy typically recover with appropriate medical treatment and control of emotional stress. The patient was discharged with a follow-up appointment in the cardiology outpatient clinic for the regular monitoring of her condition. She was also referred to a therapist to manage her emotional stress.   Slide 11: Conclusion This case illustrates the significant impact that acute emotional stress can have on the human heart  exemplified by this patient's diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy following the loss of her spouse.

Slide 1: Introduction ------------------------- Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome  is a type of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy where there's a sudden temporary weakening of the muscular portion of the heart.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics ----------------------------------- Our patient  Mrs. X  is a 65-year-old Caucasian female  a retired school teacher who enjoys gardening and reading. She is a widow and lives independently. She has a healthy BMI and has never smoked or consumed alcohol excessively.  Slide 3: Past Medical History ----------------------------------- Previously  Mrs. X has been diagnosed with hypertension  well-controlled with medication. She hasn't had any serious ailments or surgeries in the past. However  recent significant life stressors  including the loss of her husband six months ago  have had a major impact on her overall wellbeing.  Slide 4: Presentation to Medical Facility ----------------------------------------------- She presents to the emergency room with acute chest pain similar to a heart attack. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath and sudden onset fatigue. Mrs. X states that the severity of discomfort increased progressively throughout the day.   Slide 5: Diagnostic Evaluation ---------------------------------- ECG indicates ST-elevation in the anterior leads  initial suspicion may point towards an acute myocardial infarction. However  cardiac biomarkers while elevated  are not consistent with typical heart attack levels. Echocardiography reveals the classic finding for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy with apical ballooning and hyperkinesia at the basal walls  leading to the diagnosis.   Slide 6: Management and Prognosis -------------------------------------- Mrs. X is admitted for monitoring and supportive treatment primarily focusing on the alleviation of heart failure symptoms with ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers. As the condition is typically reversible  prognosis is generally favorable. However  it is vital that she seeks help to manage her stress and consider getting counseling to cope with her psychiatric and emotional health.   Slide 7: Conclusion ------------------------ To conclude  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is a crucial differential in the evaluation of acute chest pain  particularly in post-menopausal women with recent intense emotional or physiological stress.   Slide 8: Q&A -------------- Open floor for any questions and discussion.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of anxiety and hypertension presents with acute onset chest pain and shortness of breath. She also describes experiencing palpitations and intermittent lightheadedness over the past few hours. These symptoms started abruptly after she received the news of her brother's sudden death. She mentions having no history of high cholesterol  smoking  or family history of heart disease. The patient's physical examination is significant for tachycardia and elevated blood pressure. A 12-lead ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterolateral leads. Initial labs revealed elevated troponin levels.

A 65-year-old post-menopausal woman with a history of hypertension and recent bereavement  presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and nausea. On physical examination  she was found to be diaphoretic with a blood pressure of 150/90 and a heart rate of 100 beats per minute. EKG showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior-lateral leads  suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome. However  coronary angiography exhibited normal coronary arteries but with left ventricular apical ballooning  findings characteristic of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy. Her symptoms started following the news of her spouse's sudden death  presenting a highly stressful event that may have precipitated her condition.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents with acute onset chest pain  associated with shortness of breath  slight dizziness  and general malaise which started around 4 hours ago. She has a history of hypertension but she is generally healthy. This episode happened after receiving news about her husband's sudden demise. The patient is a non-smoker with a moderate alcohol intake. She is currently on hypertensive medication. On examination  she is in distress with diaphoresis and tachycardia. There are no signs of heart failure. ECG shows ST-segment elevation in anterolateral leads.

Patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian female with a medical history significant for hypertension and recent loss of her spouse  presenting with sudden  severe chest pain and shortness of breath. Patient reports experiencing these symptoms subsequent to a panic attack. Her pain is consistent with angina  radiating to her left arm and jaw  and is accompanied by nausea and lightheadedness. Patient denies any previous episodes of similar chest pain. Patient's family history is notable for premature coronary artery disease. EKG shows ST-segment elevation that initially suggests acute coronary syndrome. However  further diagnostic results from coronary angiogram demonstrate apical ballooning and mid-ventricular dilation of the left ventricle characteristic of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  without any significant coronary artery disease. Patient's symptoms  clinical presentation  and diagnostic findings are consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 67-year-old African American female presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain that started suddenly  shortly after she received news of her husband's death. The pain is constricting in nature  rated 8 out of 10 in severity with mild dyspnea  but not associated with any other symptoms. She has no significant past medical history  and specifically denies any history of ischemic heart disease  MI  hypertension  diabetes mellitus or high cholesterol. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. She denies any family history of cardiac diseases. On examination  she appears anxious and in distress due to the pain and has slight tachycardia with normal blood pressure. There is no JVD  chest  or lung findings. Cardiovascular examination shows tachycardia with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. Preliminary diagnosis is Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (Broken heart syndrome)  possibly stress-induced due to sudden emotional distress.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a history of hypertension and anxiety presents to the emergency department with chest pain radiating to her left arm  shortness of breath  and mild confusion. She reports that her symptoms began suddenly two days following a major emotional upset due her recently deceased spouse. She experiences no dizziness  visual disturbances or vomiting. On physical examination  she appears tachycardic with vital signs noting BP: 165/98 mmHg  HR: 112 bpm  RR: 20/m  O2 saturation: 94% on room air. Cardiac examination reveals diffuse ST-segment elevation on EKG  but lack of significant atherosclerotic burden on cardiac catheterization  suggesting a possible diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as “broken heart syndrome”.

A 64-year-old Caucasian female  with a past medical history of hypertension and recent bereavement due to the loss of her husband  presents to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain occurring at rest  associated with shortness of breath and palpitations. The pain is described as central  heavy crushing  radiating to the left shoulder and is similar to how she imagines a heart attack may feel. Additionally  she reports feeling nauseous and lightheaded. On examination  she appears anxious and distressed. Her ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. Chest X-ray is unremarkable. Her troponin levels are moderately raised. A subsequent echocardiogram reveals apical ballooning of the left ventricle with basal segments contracting normally  suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 65-year-old  divorced  Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension and depression  presented to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath. She had just experienced a significant emotional upheaval due to the death of her only son the previous week. She describes the chest pain as a severe  pressing discomfort in the middle of her chest that started suddenly while she was crying at her son's funeral earlier in the day. She denies having any previous similar episodes. She does not smoke  drink alcohol  or use illicit substances. Physical examination revealed an anxious-appearing woman in apparent distress with a blood pressure of 180/ 110  a pulse of 110  and respiratory rate of 24. Cardiac auscultation was unremarkable with no murmurs  rubs  or gallop noted. There was no peripheral edema. Her ECG showed subtle ST-segment elevations in the precordial leads but the blood work-up  including troponin levels and lipid profile were within normal range.

The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female with past medical history of hypertension and anxiety  who presents with acute chest pain radiating to the left arm  shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis. Her symptoms started after she experienced an intense emotional stressor earlier in the day. On examination  she appeared anxious  diaphoretic  and in distress. Initial 12-lead ECG shows ST segment elevation in the anterior leads. Lab results reveal slightly elevated troponin levels. Preliminary diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken heart syndrome) is considered due to her clinical presentation  history of recent intense emotional stress  and initial investigations.

A 68-year-old Caucasian woman with a history of hypertension and anxiety presents with sudden chest pain and dyspnea. She reports that her symptoms started after she received news about her son being involved in a car accident earlier that day. She describes the pain as a dull ache  concentrated in the middle of her chest and radiating to her left arm. She also feels like she is having a hard time catching her breath. She denies any nausea  vomiting  palpitations  or loss of consciousness. Her blood pressure is slightly elevated (145/95 mmHg) and her heart rate is tachycardic at 110 beats per minute. Prior to this incident  she was managing her hypertension with lisinopril and her anxiety with escitalopram. Additionally  she endorses a 30-pack year history of cigarettes smoking and occasional alcohol use. Her family history is significant for a mother who suffered from a myocardial infarction in her seventies. This patient does not report any known allergies. Based on her stressor  characteristic chest pain  and dyspnea  we are considering a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 58-year-old  post-menopausal Caucasian female patient with a history of general anxiety disorder and hypertension presents to the emergency department with acute onset chest pain  physical exhaustion  and shortness of breath following the recent death of her husband. Electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation in precordial leads. Troponin I levels are elevated. Transthoracic echocardiogram reveals apical ballooning suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. There is no history of prior cardiac disease. She reports compliance with her daily anti-anxiety medication and antihypertensive regimen. She doesn't smoke  consume alcohol  or use illicit drugs.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female with a known history of chronic hypertension  hyperlipidemia and generalized anxiety disorder  presents to the ER with sudden onset severe chest pain which started approximately 2 hours ago. She describes the pain as heavy  causing her to feel shortness of breath and is associated with feelings of impending doom. The pain is not radiating and there are no accompanying symptoms like nausea  vomiting  sweating  or palpitations. The patient lives alone and experienced an extremely stressful event of being a victim of a burglary incident last night. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. She is not known to have any allergies. Her medications include Amlodipine  Atorvastatin  and Escitalopram. On examination  she appeared anxious  her blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg and pulse rate is 98 bpm. Rest of the cardiovascular system and respiratory system examination is unremarkable. Her ECG taken in ER showed changes suggestive of an anterior wall myocardial infarction. However  the patient's subsequent coronary angiogram did not reveal any significant coronary artery disease  raising suspicion for takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and anxiety disorder presents with sudden-onset severe chest pain  radiating to her left arm. Over the past week  the patient has been under increased stress caused by her husband's sudden demise. The current episode occurred immediately after an intense argument with her son. On examination  she is diaphoretic with pallor. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows T-wave inversion in leads V1-V4  and her troponin levels are significantly elevated. Echocardiogram shows apical ballooning of the left ventricle with basal hyperkinesia. These findings suggest a case of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (sometimes referred to as broken heart syndrome) likely precipitated by the recent periods of intense emotional stress and anxiety.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension and anxiety  presents to the ER with sudden onset severe  central chest pain radiating to her left arm which began during an intense argument earlier this morning. She describes the pain as ""crushing"" in nature and rates it a 10 on a scale of 0-10. Accompanying symptoms include nausea  shortness of breath  diaphoresis  palpitations  and a sense of impending doom. She denies any recent illnesses  travel  substance use  or history of coronary artery disease. Her vital signs on admission are borderline: Blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  pulse is 120 bpm  and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. EKG reveals ST-segment elevation in precordial leads. Her troponin is moderately elevated and an echo is pending to confirm suspicion of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 63-year-old post-menopausal Caucasian woman presents with acute onset chest pain that radiates to her left arm. Furthermore  she experienced an episode of extreme emotional distress earlier today prior to the chest pain onset. She denies any history of heart disease  hypertension  diabetes  or hyperlipidemia and has never smoked. She has a BMI within the normal range and leads a moderately active lifestyle. The sudden emotional event preceded the severe chest pain  which was associated with diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath. Her EKG shows ST segment elevation. Given the context of acute emotional distress and the absence of classic cardiovascular risk factors  her presentation is suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female  with a past medical history of hypertension and anxiety disorder  presents with complaint of sudden-onset severe chest pain  extreme fatigue  lightheadedness  and shortness of breath that started 12 hours ago. Her symptoms began after she received traumatic news of her husband's sudden death. Electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevation. Echocardiogram demonstrated akinesis of the apical segments and hyperkinesis of the basal segments of the left ventricle which led to a suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The patient has no history of coronary artery disease and denies any history of smoking  alcohol  or drug use. Her medications include escitalopram and lisinopril.

A 62-year-old post-menopausal woman  with a past medical history of major depressive disorder  presents with acute onset chest pain and shortness of breath. The shortness of breath is described as sudden in onset  occurring at rest  without any preceding symptoms such as cough or fever. The acute chest pain is located in the central chest  described as squeezing in nature  radiating to the left arm  and is associated with palpitations and severe emotional stress. The patient denies any history of angina pectoris or heart disease but has experienced recent severe emotional trauma. The patient is social with the occasional use of alcohol but remains non-smoker and drug-free. Her family history is notable for hypertension in her father. Clinical examination demonstrates tachycardia  elevated blood pressure  normal lungs and heart sounds  with no peripheral edema or elevated jugular venous pressure. The EKG revealed ST-elevation in the precordial leads  mimicking acute myocardial infarction.

A 67-year-old African American female with a past medical history of hypertension  diabetes  and major depressive disorder presents with severe chest pain. Symptoms started suddenly after she got the news of her son's unexpected death. Her pain is described as a ""heavy sensation "" radiating to her left arm accompanied by shortness of breath. She also reports feeling light-headed with a faint episode. She denies any history of similar pain  prior chest pain episodes  or family history of cardiac diseases. Clinical examination reveals tachycardia and slightly elevated blood pressure. Electrocardiogram findings illustrate ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. Initial laboratory results show slightly elevated troponin levels. Additional information from her son reveals poor medication adherence and confirmed life stressors including the recent loss of her husband six months ago. Given the clinical presentation  a presumptive diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  or broken heart syndrome  is considered.

A 65-year-old caucasian female with a history of major depressive disorder  panic disorder  and hypertension presents with sudden onset severe chest pain and dyspnea. She reports feeling an intense wave of fear and stress just before the symptoms started  triggered by the recent unexpected death of her husband. Her pain is similar to ""a heavy weight on her chest "" and it radiates to her left arm. Associated symptoms include diaphoresis  nausea  and light-headedness. She denies any known history of heart disease. Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  saturation of 95% on room air  and a temperature of 37.2°C. Physical examination finds her in acute distress with cold  clammy skin but cardiovascular exam is otherwise unremarkable with normal S1  S2  no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads  suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome. Nonetheless  given her emotion-triggered symptom onset  takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken heart syndrome) is also strongly suspected.

A 62-year-old African American female with a past medical history of hypertension and generalized anxiety disorder presents to the emergency department with the sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the back  nausea  and shortness of breath. She also reported feeling lightheaded and experienced one episode of syncope earlier in the day. On examination  she appeared anxious and diaphoretic. EKG revealed T-wave inversions and ST-segment elevation suggesting the possibility of an acute coronary syndrome. However  subsequent cardiac catheterization showed no significant coronary artery disease that could explain her symptoms. Following an echocardiogram  a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy was made due to the distinctive appearance of apical ballooning and systolic dysfunction  typically associated with this condition. She reports experiencing significant emotional stress over the past week due to a recent family tragedy.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for hypertension and recent bereavement presents to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain radiating to her left arm. The pain began at rest  is characterized as crushing in nature  and is associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse diaphoresis. The patient denies any prior similar episodes. She has been under a considerable amount of stress since the loss of her husband 2 weeks ago. She denies tobacco smoking  alcohol drinking or illicit drug use. Her medications include amlodipine 5 mg daily for hypertension. On physical examination  she is in apparent distress  and her vital signs show tachycardia and elevated blood pressure. Her EKG shows ST-segment elevation. The patient has no history of coronary artery disease or other cardiovascular diseases. The primary concern is takotsubo cardiomyopathy precipitated by emotional stress.

A 62-year-old female patient with a history of major depressive disorder and recently diagnosed non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma presents with one-day history of severe chest pain and shortness of breath. These symptoms started during a counseling session discussing new additions to her cancer treatment regimen. Her chest pain is characterized as severe  crushing  and radiating to the left arm. The episodes are exacerbated by physical exertion and partially relieved by rest. Associated symptoms include nausea  vomiting  and a heavy sweating. She denies any symptoms of fever  cough  abdominal pain  or lower extremity swelling. The patient has no prior history of cardiovascular disease  does not smoke  and her only medication is escitalopram for depression. On physical examination  she appears distressed. Vital signs show slight tachycardia and blood pressure is within normal range. Cardiac auscultation reveals no murmurs or rubs. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension and anxiety presents to the Emergency Department with acute chest pain  shortness of breath and nausea. The symptoms started abruptly after a heated argument with her daughter about 3 hours ago. She describes the chest pain as severe  constricting in nature  and radiating to her left arm. Her shortness of breath onset concurrently with the chest pain. She denies prior episodes of similar pain. The patient's EKG shows ST elevations in the precordial leads  but her troponin levels are within normal limits. The echocardiogram reveals apical ballooning of the left ventricle with preserved basal function  suggestive of stress-induced (takotsubo) cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old female with a past medical history significant for hypertension and generalized anxiety disorder presents with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the left arm shortly after receiving news of her husband's sudden death. She also reports associated symptoms including shortness of breath  lightheadedness  and a feeling of impending doom. On examination  the patient appears anxious and distressed. She has slightly elevated blood pressure and regular tachycardia. An EKG performed reveals ST-segment elevation in the anterior precordial leads. Despite her severe symptoms  subsequent cardiac catheterization reveals no significant coronary artery disease. An echocardiogram shows a decreased left ventricular ejection fraction with apical ballooning and basal hypercontractility consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Her troponin levels peaked at 2.3 ng/mL  consistent with acute myocardial injury. She has no known allergies and takes amlodipine for high blood pressure control and sertraline for her anxiety disorder. She denies any history of smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use. She lives alone and is retired from her career as a school teacher. There is no family history of cardiac disorders or sudden death.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female with a history of hypertension and recently experienced severe emotional stress due to the sudden death of her husband  presents to the emergency department with acute onset of severe chest pain associated with shortness of breath. She describes it as a heavy sensation in the middle of her chest that started a few hours ago and has not improved with rest. Her additional symptoms include fatigue  mild dizziness  and episodes of sweating. She denies any recent changes in her diet  alcohol or drug usage. She also denies any recent travel history or sick contacts. The patient does not smoke or use recreational drugs.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a history of hypertension  diabetes  and significant emotional stress following a recent bereavement  presents to the emergency department complaining of acute onset of severe chest pain. The pain is described as intense  crushing in nature  radiating to the left arm and jaw  with associated shortness of breath  palpitations and excessive sweating. She mentions she has never experienced anything like this before. The patient's ECG shows ST segment elevation and her cardiac biomarkers demonstrate a significant increase in troponin levels. After a left heart catheterization ruled out coronary artery disease  she is diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Ms. Jones is a 59-year-old Caucasian woman with a medical history revealing long-standing hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a recent unexpected divorce. She presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain  similar to that experienced during a heart attack  that started suddenly after hearing shocking news. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  palpitations  overall fatigue  and feeling lightheaded.   Physical examination shows moderate distress due to pain  and findings from cardiovascular examination are consistent with acute coronary syndrome with ST-segment elevation. She denies any past drug abuse or significant family history of heart diseases. She also reported some recent weight loss and sleep disturbances due to post-divorce stress. The patient reports 30-pack per year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago  also a social drinker.   Her targeted assessment reveals high-level psychosocial stressors notable for recent emotional distress associated with her divorce. There is no history of known psychiatric illness. The symptoms  clinical presentation  and precipitating emotional stress event are suggestive of a possible diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Confirmation of diagnosis is pending an echocardiogram and coronary angiography to differentiate from acute coronary syndrome. Stress management and psychological support might be necessary alongside acute medical care.

A 67-year-old African-American woman presents with acute onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. She has a known medical history of hypertension  for which she has been inconsistently taking her prescribed medication  and she recently lost her husband about one week ago. The pain is severe  central  radiating to left shoulder  and associated with sweating and palpitations. She also notes having experienced a period of emotional distress since her husband's death. Her heart rate is 104 bpm  blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. Her ECG shows ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads. Blood tests reveal mildly elevated cardiac troponin levels. An echocardiogram reveals the typical apical ballooning pattern of the left ventricle  a distinct feature of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome"". Her chest pain and shortness of breath are likely resulting from the episode of stress-induced cardiomyopathy.

A 67-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of generalized anxiety disorder presents to the emergency department with sudden and severe chest pain and dyspnea. The onset of symptoms started a few hours following an undue emotional distress due to sudden death in her family. She denies any recreational drug use  smoking  or alcohol overuse  and lacks any personal or family history of cardiac disease. Physical examination reveals tachycardia and mild respiratory distress. An EKG shows ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads V2-V4  and cardiac enzymes were raised. The preliminary diagnosis is Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome.

A 57-year-old Caucasian female with a history of major depression and generalized anxiety disorder  and no reported cardiovascular disease presents with severe chest pain and dyspnea that began abruptly 3 hours ago. The pain is retrosternal  sharp and persistent  radiating to her left arm  and not relieved by rest. She reports experiencing severe emotional stress over the past few days due to the sudden death of her husband. She denies current use of tobacco  alcohol  or illicit drugs. On physical examination  she is in acute distress  tachycardic with a heart rate of 110/min  blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg  and respiratory rate of 24/min. Upon cardiac examination  there is a regular rhythm without murmurs  rubs  or gallops. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. Electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. Given her presentation  acute myocardial infarction is initially suspected  but subsequent coronary angiogram reveals no occlusive disease  suggesting a potential diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old Hispanic woman  with a past medical history of hypertension and generalized anxiety disorder  presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain associated with shortness of breath. The duration of her pain was approximately 2 hours  and her discomfort was severe and on the mid-sternum  with radiation to her left jaw. She described her pain as a 'tight' sensation  similar to what she has heard others describe as a heart attack. Additionally  she noted profuse sweating and nausea. The pain began during a funeral service  and she reports feeling a significant emotional upset. She has no known allergies. She is currently taking medication for hypertension (hydrochlorothiazide) and generalized anxiety disorder (escitalopram). She denies any tobacco  alcohol  or illicit drug use. Physical examination revealed tachycardia and a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg. An EKG showed ST-segment elevations in the anterior precordial leads V1 to V5. Stanford evaluation revealed cardiac enzymes were also elevated.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female with a history of chronic anxiety and recent bereavement presents with severe chest pain of sudden onset. The pain is described as heavy and radiating to her left arm  consistent with angina. Symptoms also involve shortness of breath  nausea  and lightheadedness. She denies any previous record of cardiovascular disease  diabetes  or hypertension. EKG shows ST-segment elevation which indicates myocardial ischemia  but subsequent coronary angiogram does not show significant blockages. Echocardiogram reveals apical ballooning with hyperkinesis at the base of the heart  supporting the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The patient's lab results have been normal  with completely normal lipid profile and slightly elevated troponin levels. Her physical examination is unremarkable aside from tachycardia and elevated blood pressure probably due to pain and anxiety. This  along with her history and symptoms  suggests a possible diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  often referred to as broken heart syndrome.

A 73-year-old Asian female with a past medical history of well-controlled hypertension presents with sudden onset of sharp chest pain  severe shortness of breath  lightheadedness  and palpitations. The patient also experienced nausea and excessive sweating. These symptoms started two hours ago following the sudden death of her long-time spouse. She denies any history of coronary artery disease  diabetes  or substance use. Her recent stress test was negative  and she has not had any prior episodes of this kind. Her physical exam reveals tachycardia and slightly reduced blood pressure with normal lung sounds and no obvious signs of heart failure. Her EKG shows modest ST elevations in the anterolateral leads without reciprocal changes. Initial lab investigations reveal a modestly elevated troponin level.

Ms. Johnson is a 65-year-old Caucasian female presenting with sudden mid-sternal chest pain  feeling of breathlessness  and nausea. She reports her symptoms started following a stressful encounter she had earlier in the day  specifically the sudden death of her husband. She has no known previous health conditions but has been a smoker for 20 years. On physical examination  she appears anxious and has cold sweats; her blood pressure is 180/95 mmHg  pulse 110 beats per minute  and respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute. Further evaluation including an ECG suggests evidence of ST-segment elevation. She has elevated troponin levels but a coronary angiogram shows no significant obstructive coronary artery disease; left ventriculogram suggests akinesis of the mid and apical segments with hyperkinesis of the base  suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Ms. Johnson's history of an acute emotional stressor  her symptoms  and the characteristic ventriculogram findings all align with a likely episode of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian woman  with a history of hypertension and major depression  presents in the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain  rating it 7/10 in severity. The pain is described as sharp in nature  located in the mid-chest area  radiating to the neck and left arm. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  nausea  sweating  and feeling lightheaded. Patient recalls experiencing severe emotional stress recently. There are no known allergies or recent changes in her medications  which include daily Lisinopril and Escitalopram. On examination  she appears diaphoretic and anxious  with vital signs indicating tachycardia and borderline elevated blood pressure. EKG shows T wave inversions and ST-segment elevation  raising suspicions of an acute myocardial event; however  subsequent blood tests show only slightly elevated cardiac enzymes inconsistent with expected levels in acute coronary syndrome. Echocardiography reveals apical ballooning with hyperkinesis of the basal wall segments  indicative of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension and major depressive disorder presents to the Emergency Department with acute onset of severe chest pain. The pain radiates to the left arm and is accompanied by shortness of breath  feelings of impending doom  and nausea. The patient reported that she has been under extreme emotional stress since the sudden passing of her husband a week ago. Vital signs on presentation include a blood pressure of 150/90  heart rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 94% on ambient air. Electrocardiography (ECG) shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Initial bloodwork shows slightly elevated troponin levels but normal lipid profile  blood glucose and electrolytes. The patient's symptoms and  especially  the recent severe emotional stress suggest possible takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as broken heart syndrome). This diagnosis would be confirmed by coronary angiogram and/or echocardiogram showing the classic apical ballooning and absence of obstructive coronary artery disease.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a history of chronic anxiety  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain and shortness of breath. Onset of symptoms started abruptly  following a phone call with news of her husband's sudden death. The patient describes symptoms as similar to a ""heavy weight"" on her chest and admits that she has been extremely stressed lately. She denies any prior similar episodes or known history of coronary artery disease in herself or immediate family. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. Her medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. On physical examination  the patient appears in acute distress with cold sweats. Her vitals show tachypnea and slightly elevated blood pressure. Electrocardiogram reveals ST-elevation in anterior leads suggestive of ischemia. However  the troponin levels are disproportionately low for an ST-elevation myocardial infarction. This presentation is suggestive of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced or broken-heart syndrome.

Demographics: 68-year-old Caucasian female  Medical History: The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hypothyroidism  for which she is on metoprolol and levothyroxine respectively. The patient does not smoke  drink alcohol  or use illicit drugs. No recent surgeries or procedures. She has no known drug allergies. One noteworthy event in her personal history is the recent loss of her husband  following which she has experienced severe psychological stress.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to her left arm  associated with shortness of breath. She reports feeling lightheaded and having a sense of impending doom. Vital signs are generally normal but she has an elevated heart rate. On physical examination  she appears anxious and is diaphoretic. Lung auscultation reveals no abnormalities and the remainder of the exam is unremarkable.   Based on the underlying stressor  the psychological components  and the physical observations  there is a strong potential that she may be suffering from broken heart syndrome  clinically known as Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy. Further diagnostic investigation  like electrocardiogram and echocardiogram  will be necessary to confirm this hypothesis.

A 65-year-old postmenopausal Caucasian woman  with a history of hypertension  presents with sudden onset chest pain  shortness of breath  and nausea following the unexpected death of her husband. Examination reveals elevated blood pressure  tachycardia and diaphoresis. EKG reveals ST-segment elevation and inverted T waves. Lab results show mildly elevated troponin levels. The patient reports having no previous cardiac history. Given the emotional stress event  her symptoms  and test results  she is likely suffering from Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as stress cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome).

A 68-year-old Caucasian female with a history of anxiety and hypertension presents with acute onset of severe chest pain with the pain radiating down her left arm. She describes the pain as 'pressure-like'. The pain started suddenly after receiving a call about the unexpected death of a close friend. She reports associated nausea  shortness of breath  and an episode of lightheadedness. She denies smoking  alcohol consumption  or drug abuse. She also reports she experienced panic attacks in the past. Physical examination reveals tachycardia and elevated BP. EKG is suggestive of ST elevations in precordial leads  consistent with a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female  recently widowed and with a history of hypertension  presents with sudden  intense chest pain and shortness of breath  which began approximately six hours ago. The patient reports this pain is severe and similar to what she imagines a heart attack would feel like. She also reports feelings of extreme stress and grief over the loss of her husband a month ago. She also experiences lightheadedness. On physical examination  her blood pressure is elevated at 160/95mmHg  and her heart rate is 98 beats per minute. EKG reveals abnormal readings with ST elevation in the precordial leads but coronary angiogram does not show any significant blockages to explain her symptoms. Echocardiogram indicates abnormal left ventricular function with apical ballooning  highly suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and recent severe emotional stress following the death of her spouse  presents to the emergency department reporting acute onset chest pain and shortness of breath. Pain is characterized as a weight on the chest without any radiation and started about 6 hours ago. Patient denies any history of coronary artery disease or myocardial infarction. On examination  she appears diaphoretic and anxious with stable vital signs apart from a mildly tachycardia of 110 beats/min. No noticeable murmurs on heart auscultation. A 12 lead EKG shows subtle ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads and troponin I levels are found to be moderately elevated. Patient has never experienced these symptoms before.

A 67-year-old  Japanese female with a history of depression and recent episode of severe emotional stress presents with acute onset chest pain and dyspnea. These symptoms are consistent with acute coronary syndrome  though EKG readings display slight abnormalities in ST-segment evolution inconsistent with her symptomology. Echocardiogram reveals a left ventricular apical ballooning effect  with a significant reduction in ejection fraction but without any coinciding significant coronary artery disease – suggestive of a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Demographics: 62-year-old Asian female  Medical History: Non-smoker  mild hypertension controlled with medication  recent death of her husband two weeks ago  no known family history of heart disease  no history of drug abuse or high alcohol consumption.  Presentation: The patient presents with severe chest pain and shortness of breath  which began suddenly while she was attending her husband's funeral. She describes the pain as pressure-like  radiating to her left arm and jaw  similar to descriptions of a heart attack. Accompanying symptoms include mild nausea and cold sweats. There are no evident signs of fever  cough  or other infection symptoms.  Upon taking an EKG  results are suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome. However  a subsequent angiogram does not demonstrate significant blockage in her coronary arteries. Echocardiogram  however  is suggestive of left ventricular apical ballooning. Cardiac biomarkers show a mildly elevated troponin level. The sudden emotional stress of her husband's death combined with current symptoms and negative coronary angiogram findings lead to a suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  or broken-heart syndrome.

A 64-year-old Caucasian woman presents with sudden  severe chest pain and shortness of breath. She has a past medical history of hypertension and recently experienced the sudden death of her husband. On examination  she has tachycardia  high blood pressure  and her chest pain is reminiscent of a severe heart attack. However  upon cardiac catheterization  no occlusive coronary artery disease is seen. Her EKG shows abnormalities not consistent with typical myocardial infarction  and echocardiography demonstrates apical ballooning of the left ventricle. These findings are congruent with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  provoked by the recent emotional stress she has endured.

A 60-year-old caucasian female patient presents with acute onset of severe chest pain  dyspnea  nausea  and faintness which started a few hours after she got news of her husband's sudden death. Her past medical history is notable only for well-controlled hypertension and chronic emotional stress. She doesn't smoke or drink alcohol but reports occasional palpitations in the past few months. She is currently experiencing anxiety and emotional lability. Physical examination reveals moderate distress  mild tachypnea  and slight tachycardia. Her blood pressure is slightly elevated. EKG shows ST-segment elevation and there are minor changes in cardiac biomarkers. An echocardiogram demonstrates typical apical ballooning with reduced ejection fraction which suggests a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as stress cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome). Ongoing chest pain and hemodynamic instability could suggest further evolution of the disease.

A 62-year-old Caucasian woman with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a recent stressful life event (husband's sudden death) presented to the emergency department with acute onset of severe chest pain. She described the pain as heavy and crushing  radiating to her left arm. She also reported experiencing nausea  dyspnea and lightheadedness. Upon evaluation  her blood pressure was noted to be 160/90 mmHg  pulse was 110 bpm  and EKG showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Initial diagnosis is takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced (broken-heart syndrome) cardiomyopathy  given the recent emotional stress and presentation of symptoms resembling acute coronary syndrome.

A 67-year-old recently widowed Caucasian woman presents with an abrupt onset of severe chest pain and dyspnea. She has a medical history relevant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medications. She does not smoke and her alcohol consumption is minimal. There is a notable recent personal emotional event  the death of her husband a week ago. She reports no history of similar chest pain episodes previously. Upon physical examination  she is anxious  mildly tachycardic but her blood pressure is within normal limits. ECG reveals ST-segment elevations in the precordial leads. Labs show elevated troponin levels  indicative of myocardial injury. Given her presentation and the recent emotional stress  she is suspected of having takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome.""

A 68-year-old Caucasian woman with a history of hypertension  generalized anxiety disorder and recent emotional trauma due to the sudden loss of her husband  presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain that has developed over the past couple of hours. The pain is described as crushing and radiating to the left arm  similar to what one might expect with an MI. She also mentions intermittent shortness of breath  palpitations and extreme fatigue for the past week. The patient denies smoking  alcohol or any recreational drug use. Vital signs show tachycardia and a slightly elevated blood pressure. On examination  there is no jugular vein distention or peripheral edema. She has no family history of heart disease. Differential diagnosis includes acute coronary syndrome and takotsubo cardiomyopathy that can possibly be stress- or anxiety-related.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female presented with acute onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. Key medical history includes the recent death of husband  chronic anxiety  hyperlipidemia  and absence of coronary artery disease. On presentation  she reported experiencing intermittent chest pain over the last 6 hours  associated with nausea and profuse sweating. Physical examination revealed tachycardia  elevated blood pressure  and mild respiratory distress. Her electrocardiogram showed ST elevations in the anterior leads. The patient is symptomatic with signs suggestive of acute coronary syndrome  but given her recent emotional stress and absence of coronary artery disease history  a presumptive diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is being considered.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a history of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain that started suddenly 2 hours ago. The pain is described as squeezing  radiating to her left arm and is associated with nausea and shortness of breath. She denies any associated symptoms  such as cough  fever  or recent surgery. She also reveals significant emotional stress due to the death of her spouse 1 week ago. Physical examination reveals diaphoresis and tachycardia. Initial EKG reveals ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads and blood tests indicate elevated troponin level  suggesting myocardial injury consistent with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome - a stress-induced cardiomyopathy.

Patient is a 65-year-old  widowed  Caucasian woman presenting with an acute onset of severe chest pain and shortage of breath. She has no known history of coronary artery disease or hypertension  but has recently been under significant emotional stress due to the passing of her husband. Patient reports that the chest pain is ""crushing"" and began suddenly while she was performing her daily activities  with no prior warning of such symptom. On physical examination  her heart rate was 95 beats per minute and her blood pressure was 140/90 mm Hg. ECG showed ST-segment elevation in precordial leads (V2 through V6)  suggestive of anterior wall myocardial infarction. However  her coronary angiogram did not show any significant obstruction  suggesting a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of chest pain and difficulty breathing. Her medical history is significant for hypertension and recent intense stress due to the unexpected loss of her husband. Physical examination reveals mild tachycardia  and EKG shows ST-segment elevations. History elucidates that she was previously healthy with exercise tolerance before the recent event. She has no personal or familial history of ischemic heart disease. She doesn't smoke or drink alcohol  and there is no history of drug abuse. CT angiography rules out aortic dissection and pulmonary embolism; however  left ventriculography shows apical ballooning and hypercontractile bases  characteristic of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome.

A 65-year-old post-menopausal female with a past medical history notable for anxiety and hypertension presents with acute onset of severe  central chest pain associated with dyspnea  palpitations  profuse diaphoresis  and nausea. This occurrence was immediately following a high-level stress event of learning about the death of her spouse. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Initial laboratory investigations revealed slightly raised troponin levels. There is no known history of coronary artery disease  and the patient denies any previous similar episodes  substance abuse  or family history of premature coronary artery disease. Her medications include a beta-blocker for her hypertension and a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) for her anxiety disorder. The patient's physical examination is positive for tachycardia and hypotension. Given these findings  it is highly suggestive that this patient is presenting with takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female with a history of major depressive disorder  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department exhibiting acute onset shortness of breath  chest discomfort  nausea  and profuse sweating. She denies associated symptoms of fever or cough. She also shares the recent passing of her husband  acknowledging a significantly increased level of stress. Her blood pressure is noted to be 165/101 mmHg  pulse rate is 108 beats per minute  and EKG shows ST-segment elevation. Lab findings reveal increased cardiac troponin levels but coronary angiography is negative for any obstructive coronary disease leading to a provisional diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female with a history of hypertension and anxiety presents with acute onset chest pain and shortness of breath following her husband's recent death. Vital signs show tachycardia with a heart rate of 112 bpm  and blood pressure of 168/101 mmHg. Physical exam reveals unusual EKG changes mimicking an anterior wall myocardial infarction and mild bilateral leg edema. Echocardiogram demonstrates apical ballooning of the left ventricle with a preserved basal function  indicative of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 61-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of depression and hypertension presents with sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to the left arm accompanied by shortness of breath. The symptoms started immediately after she was informed about the sudden death of her husband. Also  reveals worsening lower extremity edema over the past two days. Vital signs reveal tachycardia and elevated blood pressure. No previous history of coronary artery disease  but non-compliance to her antihypertensive medication for the past week. Electrocardiogram findings are suspicious for an acute myocardial infarction. However  the coronary angiogram reveals no occlusive disease in the coronary arteries  which leads to suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy due to recent severe emotional stress.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female with a history of anxiety and previously managed hypertension presents to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain. Symptoms initiated during a high-stress family event three hours ago  with pain radiating from the chest to the left arm. Accompanied by shortness of breath  light-headedness  and palpitations. The patient denies any history of similar episodes or known coronary heart disease. Past surgical history is unremarkable; oral medication compliance for hypertension is reported. She has never smoked and reports occasional alcohol consumption. Family history is positive for heart disease with her father having had a myocardial infarction at age 66. No known allergies reported. On examination  the patient appears anxious and distressed  and vitals reveal elevated blood pressure and heart rate. Due to the presenting symptoms and their onset during a stressful event  a potential diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken heart syndrome) is considered.

A 67-year-old woman presents with acute onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath for the past 2 hours. Her medical history is notable for generalized anxiety disorder and she reports experiencing a severe personal stressor over the past week. She smokes 10 cigarettes per day  consumes alcohol occasionally and has a family history of hypertension. No known drug allergies reported. She denies previous episodes of chest pain  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or edema. Examination reveals a patient in apparent distress  pallor  with a heart rate of 110 bpm  blood pressure of 155/95 mmHg  and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Lung auscultation reveals no abnormal respiratory sounds and cardiac auscultation reveals normal first and second heart sounds without any added sounds. EKG shows ST elevation in leads V2-V6  I and aVL. The patient appears to have takotsubo cardiomyopathy in the context of recent significant emotional stress.

A 67-year-old Asian woman presents with acute  severe chest pain in the setting of a recent highly stressful personal event. Patient has controlled hypertension but no history of coronary artery disease. She describes her pain as an abrupt onset  radiating to her back and associated with shortness of breath. Physical exam is notable for mild tachycardia and elevated blood pressure. An EKG demonstrates non-specific ST-segment changes but no classical ST-elevation myocardial infarction pattern. An echocardiogram reveals a distinct pattern of regional wall motion abnormalities with the base of the left ventricle contracting normally but the mid-ventricular and apical segments ballooning outward.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of generalized anxiety disorder and hypertension presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and a feeling of impending doom  that started after she received news about her daughter getting into a car accident. Vital signs are stable. ECG shows nonspecific ST-segment and T wave changes  and her Troponin levels are mildly elevated. Echocardiogram reveals apical ballooning of the left ventricle with hyperkinesis of the basal walls  suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Problem Representation:  An 68-year-old single African American female presents with acute onset of chest pain and shortness of breath that started after she received news of her son's sudden death. She has a past medical history significant for hypertension  which is managed with amlodipine  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is controlled with metformin. She narrates a history of increasing exertional dyspnoea over the last week. She denies tobacco use  alcohol consumption  and illicit drug use. She is visibly distressed.   Physical examination reveals tachypnea  tachycardia  and mild bilateral pedal edema. The ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads and her troponin levels are slightly elevated. Echocardiogram reports an apical ballooning of the left ventricle with hyperdynamic basal segments  a pattern suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain and shortness of breath. She has a past medical history of well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She denies any prior history of coronary artery disease or heart failure. She states that her symptoms started abruptly a few hours ago  following an intense argument with her son. She describes her chest pain as a heaviness  rated as 7/10  alongside sudden onset of shortness of breath. Patient also reports feeling excessive anxiety and distress. EKG reveals ST-elevation and QT prolongation  and her labs show slightly elevated cardiac enzymes suggesting myocardial damage. This presentation follows a recent a period of emotional stress  making takotsubo cardiomyopathy a strong possibility.

A 67-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of mild hypertension presents with severe chest pain  exacerbated on exertion  accompanied by shortness of breath. She also reports recent severe emotional stress after the death of her spouse. An EKG showed ST segment elevation in the precordial leads and troponin levels were markedly elevated. Echocardiogram revealed hypokinesis of the apical segments and hyperkinesis of the basal segments  consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female  retired teacher  presents with chest pain  shortness of breath  and mild confusion. The symptoms began suddenly after receiving news of her husband's unexpected death. She has a past medical history of well-controlled hypertension and occasional anxiety  for which she takes Lisinopril and an occasional Alprazolam. She reports no known drug allergies. Her father had a heart attack at age 70. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her body mass index is 27 and vitals are unremarkable except for borderline tachycardia. On examination  she is visibly distressed. ECG shows ST-segment elevation. Test results are pending  but given her presentation after an intense emotional event  the working diagnosis would be Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken heart syndrome).

A 68-year-old  Caucasian female  with no significant past medical history  presents to the emergency room complaining of severe  sudden onset chest pain following the death of her spouse a few weeks ago. Her pain is accompanied by dyspnea on exertion and palpitations for the past two days. She does not smoke  drink alcohol or take any illicit drugs  and she has no known drug allergies. She has no previous history of heart disease or hypertension in her family. She does not take any medications except for a daily multivitamin. Physical examination reveals the patient to be in acute distress while vitals show tachycardia and slightly elevated blood pressure. Lung auscultation is clear  with no rales or wheezes. Cardiopulmonary exam reveals no additional abnormalities. EKG demonstrates ST-segment elevation and T-wave inversion  yet initial Troponin levels return to normal. Echocardiogram shows apical ballooning and impaired ejection fraction consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The patient is suspected to have takotsubo cardiomyopathy owing to her presenting symptoms  recent severe emotional stress  and absence of significant coronary artery disease  confirmed with subsequent negative coronary angiography.

A 62-year-old post-menopausal woman presents to the ER with severe chest pain. The pain is retrosternal  has a sudden onset  and is associated with shortness of breath. Her medical history shows no prior cardiovascular issues  however  she's had a considerable amount of stress lately due to the loss of her husband. She's maintained a healthy lifestyle throughout her life with no smoking or alcohol use. Examination on arrival shows a slightly hypertensive patient  with no cyanosis  and revealed a diaphoretic and anxious patient. ECG findings show an ST elevation in the precordial leads  and echo reveals hypo-contraction of the left ventricular apical segments  suggesting a potential diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old Caucasian woman with a history of well-controlled hypertension and no known cardiac history presents to the emergency department (ED) with complaints of severe  sudden-onset central chest pain radiating to her left arm raking it 8/10 on severity  which began while she was dealing with an argument with a neighbor regarding property disputes. She denies recent infection. She also complains of nausea and excessive sweating. Her vitals on admission were blood pressure (BP) of 150/90mmHg  heart rate (HR) of 110/min  respiratory rate (RR) of 20/min  oxygen saturation (SpO2) on room air of 98%  and temperature of 97.6 F. Physical examination reveals a moderately distressed woman in no acute respiratory distress. Cardiovascular examination reveals normal S1/S2 heart sounds with no added sounds and bronchovascular breathing sounds bilaterally in her lungs. An abnormal EKG shows ST segment elevations in precordial leads with no history of such changes. Her cardiac enzymes are slightly elevated. Her symptoms and EKG findings are indicative of an acute coronary syndrome  however  her coronary angiography indicated no coronary artery disease ruling out myocardial infarction. Further examination with echocardiogram revealed akinesia of the mid to apical segments of the left ventricle with hypercontractility of the basal walls  resembling a ""takotsubo"" or a Japanese octopus trap. The patient was diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy possibly triggered by the emotional stress of argument. Her condition was managed  and she was stabilized and exhibited progressive improvement with supportive care and emotion management therapy.

A 60-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperthyroidism presents with sudden onset chest pain radiating to her left arm  consistent with acute coronary syndrome. Patient also reports feeling shortness of breath  nausea and excessive sweating. There is no significant family history of cardiac disease. She recently underwent a divorce and mentions she's experiencing significant emotional stress. EKG shows ST-elevations in the anterior leads suspicious for an anterior wall myocardial infarction. Troponin levels are elevated. On echocardiogram  there is apical ballooning of the left ventricle with preserved function at the base  highly suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents with acute chest pain and shortness of breath. She has a past medical history significant for hypertension and a high-stress lifestyle as a corporate executive  but no history of cardiac diseases. Her vitals reveal tachycardia and an elevated blood pressure. EKG findings show ST-segment elevation  and elevated cardiac enzymes are noted on labs. Despite these symptoms mirroring those of acute myocardial infarction (AMI)  the coronary angiogram is surprisingly normal with no significant stenosis present. Echocardiography demonstrates hypokinesis of the mid ventricular segments and apical ballooning  which are characteristic findings of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome"". The patient reports having experienced major work-related stress in the few days leading up to her presentation.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female with a history of anxiety  hypertension  and no known cardiac disease presents with acute onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath after a significant emotional stress event. Her symptoms started 2 hours ago and are associated with diaphoresis and nausea. She denies any history of smoking or substance abuse  and family health history is noncontributory. Personal history points to a high-stress job and recent events  including the death of a close family member. On presentation  she appears anxious and diaphoretic with elevated blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg and tachycardia of 112 bpm. Her O2 saturation is 95% on room air. Current medications include escitalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. Her clinical picture is suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as 'broken heart syndrome'. Further workup to confirm the diagnosis and guideline-directed medical therapy is warranted.

A 65-year-old widowed female  with a history of hypertension and depression  presents to the ER with sudden onset severe chest pain and dyspnea following hearing of her son's tragic accident. Pain is described as crushing in character  radiating to the left arm and jaw. She denies any headache  fever  cough  or earlier similar episodes. Her pain seems to be exacerbated by exertion and relieved by rest. She has been adherent to her antihypertensive medication. The patient is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally  and reports a significant increase in stress recently.  The ECG shows ST-segment elevation with incongruous low troponin levels for a STEMI. The echocardiogram shows apical ballooning of the left ventricle with preserved basal function  consistent with the diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy or ""broken-heart syndrome"". The patient's sudden onset of severe chest pain and dyspnea  triggered by emotional stress  with EKG and echocardiogram findings  favor the diagnosis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for hypertension and generalized anxiety disorder presents to the ER with sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. She reports that the pain is severe  radiating to the left arm and associated with diaphoresis and dizziness. The patient also shares that she has been under significant emotional stress for the past two weeks due to the sudden death of her husband. On physical examination  she is in palpable distress with vital signs demonstrating hypertension and tachycardia. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevation. Initial troponin levels are elevated  indicative of myocardial injury.

A 65-year-old Caucasian woman with a past medical history of depression  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia presents with a sudden onset of severe  crushing chest pain which radiates to her left arm and is associated with shortness of breath  palpitations  sweating  and nausea. The presentation coincided with a stressful event in her life  the recent death of her husband two days ago. The symptoms started approximately 1 hour prior to presentation and have not relieved with rest. She denies tobacco  alcohol or illicit drugs usage. Her last measured vital signs are blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  pulse 110 bpm  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension with clear lung fields and an S3 heart sound with no murmurs. An initial EKG showed ST elevations in leads V2-V5 with negative troponins on serial blood draws.uggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and generalized anxiety disorder presents with sudden onset severe chest pain  dyspnea and palpitations that began while she was experiencing a severe emotional upset earlier today. She has no history of coronary artery disease  smoking  or illicit drug use. She takes amlodipine for hypertension  atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  and takes lorazepam on an as-needed basis for anxiety  which has been increasingly more frequently in recent months due to several stressful life events. The chest pain is radiating to her left shoulder and arm. She also complains of lightheadedness  and a feeling of fear and doom. She has never experienced something like this before. She denies fever  cough  abdominal pain  orthopnea  or lower extremity swelling. A family history does not reveal any immediate family members with early heart disease or sudden cardiac death.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female  whose medical history includes untreated anxiety  recent widowhood  and no known cardiac history  presents with severe chest pain and shortness of breath that she has been experiencing over the past couple of days. The patient reports the symptoms feel similar to a ""heart attack."" Upon examination  the patient appears distressed and anxious with pallor and profuse sweating. EKG shows ST-segment elevation in precordial leads (V2-V4) causing clinical suspicion of an acute myocardial infarction (AMI). However  the patient's Troponin levels  though elevated  do not match the typical levels for an AMI of this perceived severity  and angiogram does not demonstrate significant coronary artery disease. The patient's echocardiogram report shows apical ballooning of the left ventricle  leading to a Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken-heart syndrome) diagnosis.

An 65-year-old female  retired teacher presents with recently experienced severe emotional stress due to loss of her spouse. She presents with acute onset chest pain and shortness of breath  symptoms similar to acute myocardial infarction  with a history of hypertension but no known history of coronary artery disease. Physical examination reveals rapid heartbeat and decreased physical functioning. Her ECG report shows ST-segment elevation and the echocardiogram report demonstrates ballooning of the left ventricle  suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for generalized anxiety disorder presents complaining of acute chest pain since yesterday. The pain is described as severe  crushing in nature  radiating to her left arm and associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and excessive sweating. She reported a major emotional stressor three days ago  characterized by the sudden death of her spouse. She denies any history of coronary artery disease  smoking  diabetes  or hyperlipidemia. On examination  she appears anxious and is diaphoretic. EKG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Lab results reveal elevation in cardiac enzymes including troponin and CK-MB. An echo shows apical ballooning of the left ventricle with hyperkinesis of the basal segments  findings suggestive of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.

A 67-year-old Caucasian female with a history of hypertension and major depressive disorder  presents with acute onset of severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and palpitations following the recent sudden death of her spouse. Her pain is central  radiating to her left arm  similar to descriptions of myocardial infarction. It is not related to exertion and not relieved by rest. The patient is visibly distressed with diaphoresis. She denies nausea  vomiting  dizziness  or loss of consciousness. Her blood pressure is elevated at 170/90 mmHg  heart rate is rapid and irregular at 105 bpm  and she appears discomforted. She has no known allergies  she is on anti-hypertensive medication and standard antidepressants. She has a previous history of mental health hospitalizations following traumatic events. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes a day and denies alcohol or drug misuse. Her family history is significant for cardiovascular disease in her father. Her EKG shows ST-segment elevation and her lab results show slightly increased cardiac troponin levels. The echocardiogram demonstrates apical ballooning with the base of the heart contracting normally  suggestive of a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.
