Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:   Mrs. L  a 60-year-old Caucasian woman from an urban setting presents to the emergency department.   Current Situation:  The patient is complaining of severe chest pain similar to a heart attack. She confirms it started suddenly  in the midst of an emotionally overwhelming situation. On a pain scale from 1 to 10  she rates her pain as a 9.   Demographic details:  The patient lives independently. She is a retired librarian  a widow for 10 years and has three adult children. The patient is a non-smoker and does not report any use of alcohol or recreational drugs.   Medical and Family History:  Mrs. L has a history of hypertension controlled with medications (hydrochlorothiazide) and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 5 years back which is being managed through dietary control and medication (Metformin). She has a BMI of 28.3 kg/m^2. She has no known allergies. She had a cholecystectomy 20 years ago. She reports an occasional episode of palpitations but has no past medical history of heart disease or high cholesterol. She has no family history of premature coronary artery disease or other cardiovascular diseases.  Recent Changes and Stressful Events:  Patient’s mother recently passed away which has brought on significant emotional stress. She also reported experiencing episodes of anxiety and occasional panic attacks since her mother's death.  Medication History:  Mrs. L is currently taking metformin for her diabetes and hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension.  Risk Factors:  She has a history of hypertension and diabetes which are risk factors for heart disease. She is also under significant emotional stress which is a known precipitant for takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   Clinical Findings:  On presentation  her Blood pressure was elevated at 160/90 mmHg and pulse rate was 110 beats per minute. An EKG shows ST segment elevations. Results from an echo cardiogram indicate apical ballooning of the left ventricle  a typical feature of takotsubo cardiomyopathy and a troponin test also reports higher levels.   Patient's Symptoms in line with problem:  Her chest pain is severe  similar to the pain experienced during a heart attack  she has a history of hypertension and occasional palpitations. Her recent emotionally stressful event (mother's death) along with the clinical findings all point towards a potential diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   Management:  Pending consultant cardiologist review  she should be reassured and given initial treatment to relieve symptoms and stabilize her condition. In general  treatment of takotsubo cardiomyopathy is usually supportive and similar to the treatment given for an acute coronary syndrome.  This is a typical problem representation for a patient with a suspected diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. However  each patient may vary  and this representation should be adjusted based on the individual case presentation.

Patient Profile:  - Name: Mrs. Jane Doe - Age: 58-years-old - Gender: Female - Occupation: Retired school teacher - Marital status: Widowed for the past 2 years - Abstains from alcohol  non-smoker  Presenting Complaint:   Mrs. Doe has come in complaining of sudden chest pain  palpitations and shortness of breath. These symptoms started two hours ago  soon after she received news of a relative's sudden death.  Past Medical History:   Mrs. Doe has a history of hypertension  managed with medication (Enalapril) for the past 10 years. She has been trying to manage her levels of stress after her husband's death but admits difficulty doing so. She does not have a history of any heart disease.  Family History:   Her father had coronary artery disease and passed away at 65 due to heart attack. Her mother is alive  aged 80  and suffers from Type 2 diabetes.   Review of Systems:   On further questioning  Mrs. Doe also complained of feelings of anxiety and occasional bouts of fatigue. She had been feeling particularly stressed and anxious over the past week after getting news that her sister  whom she was very close to  was diagnosed with breast cancer. She had been crying a lot and had trouble sleeping the past several days.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  she appears visibly anxious and in pain. The rest of her physical examination is essentially normal with no sign of heart failure or other acute conditions.  Objective Data:  The ECG shows ST-segment elevation  simulating an acute myocardial infarction. However  cardiac biomarkers reveal mildly elevated troponin T levels  which are discordant with the ECG changes  and her echocardiography reveals systolic apical ballooning with preserved basal function  consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy (or broken heart syndrome).

The chest pain is described as a crushing type  radiating to her left arm. She also reports associated symptoms of lightheadedness  nausea  and excessive sweating. She lives alone at home. She reports no known drug allergies.   Her father died at the age of 65 years from a myocardial infarction and her mother at the age of 78 years due to stroke. Problem Representation:  Gender: Female  Age Range: Typically middle-aged to older adult  65-75  Ethnicity: No specific predilection  can be seen in any ethnicity   Occupation: Variable  possibly retired due to age range  Residence: No specific location can be applicable  however might live in areas with high levels of stress or have a stressful lifestyle  Presenting Problem: Severe chest pain and shortness of breath presented suddenly  similar to symptoms of a heart attack. These symptoms often follow physical stress (ex. surgery  illness  strenuous physical exercise etc.) or emotional stress (ex. intense arguments  grief  intense fear etc.).   Past Medical History:   1. Previous episodes of stress-induced chest pain 2. Chronic Anxiety Disorder 3. Other stress-related disorders (Post-traumatic Stress Disorder  Depression  etc.) 4. Mildly Hypertensive  5. No previous history of Coronary Artery Disease 6. May have had previous surgeries or recent illnesses  Family History: N/A (Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy is not known to be hereditary)  Social History: Significant recent life stress  such as a death in the family or major surgery. Various levels of social support  potential history of trauma.  Physical Examination:   1. Physical distress consistent with severe chest pain 2. Normal body mass index 3. Blood pressure may be high due to pain and anxiety  4. Heart rate may also be rapid and irregular   Provisional Diagnosis: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (also known as ""broken heart syndrome"")  a sudden and usually reversible weakening of the heart muscle resulting in left ventricular systolic dysfunction without coronary artery occlusion. This is often caused following extreme emotional or physical stress.  Plan: Admit to the hospital for cardiac monitoring and commence medications like beta blockers and ACE inhibitors  offer psychological support.

She experiences a severe emotional or physical stress episode prior to symptom onset  specifically the sudden death of her spouse. She has a history of depression and anxiety and is on fluoxetine. She does not have a personal history of hypertension  diabetes  or dyslipidemia; no known drug allergies; BMI is within the normal range. She has a sedentary lifestyle with mild alcohol use. Electrocardiogram (ECG) findings include ST-segment elevation consistent with the acute coronary syndrome. Echocardiogram shows apical ballooning of the left ventricle  with preserved function at the base  creating a takotsubo or ""octopus pot"" appearance. Coronary angiography shows no significant coronary artery disease. Troponin levels are mildly elevated.   Medical History - Depression  Anxiety.  Current medications - fluoxetine.  Social History - Currently non-smoker  mild alcohol use.  Family History - No known heart disease or any genetic conditions.  Past Surgical History - None reported.   Allergies - None reported.  Review of Systems - Negative except for the current issue.   Thus  the provisional diagnosis would be Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (also known as Stress Cardiomyopathy or Broken Heart Syndrome).

Patient Characterization:  Name: Jane Doe Age: 65 years old Gender: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher Location: San Francisco  California Marital Status: Widowed Tobacco use: Lifetime non-smoker Alcohol use: Occasional red wine Recreational drug use: None Medication: Low dose aspirin for heart health  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension for 15 years  controlled with medication 2. Hyperlipidemia  managed with diet and exercise 3. Mild osteoporosis  on calcium and Vitamin D supplements 4. No history of heart disease  Description of Presenting Problem:  Mrs. Doe presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain and shortness of breath which began suddenly while she was at her husband's funeral. Initial workup revealed elevated cardiac enzymes and ECG changes suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome. However  the coronary angiography did not show significant blockage in the coronary arteries. Instead it showed apical ballooning and mid-ventricular dilation of the left ventricle consistent with a diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome"". This condition is often triggered by severe emotional stress.  Plan:  1. Implement appropriate medical management for Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy with heart failure medicines. 2. Arrange for an echocardiogram in 6-8 weeks to confirm recovery of left ventricular function. 3. Refer to stress management and counseling to address the emotional distress. 4. Regular follow-up to monitor the patient's progress.   This patient's representation clearly summarizes her demographic information  lifestyle habits  medical history  and the presenting problem with the tests that confirmed her diagnosis. This all facilitates a comprehensive understanding of the patient's case and the foundation for her care planning.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mrs. B. Smith Age: 65 years Gender: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher Marital Status: Widowed  Presenting Complaint:  Patient presents into the ER with symptoms akin to a heart attack including severe chest pain and shortness of breath  however  ECG and other tests have ruled out a heart attack.  Medical History: - Patient has a long history of chronic hypertension. - Diagnosed with high cholesterol levels 5 years ago  partially controlled by statins. - Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes  managed by diet and metformin. - She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially. - No known allergies to drugs.  Family History: - Mother and father both died in their late 70s from valve-related heart diseases. - Younger brother has Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy.  Social History: - Patient lives alone. - Since the death of her husband 6 months ago  she has reported feeling under considerable emotional stress. - She relies on a close network of friends for social activities and emotional support.  Based on the above profile and the presentation of symptoms  there is a high possibility of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  which typically presents in post-menopausal women following a period of severe stress. This condition  commonly referred to as ""broken heart syndrome "" can mimic symptoms typical of a heart attack. Close monitoring and appropriate intervention are required.

Problem Representation:  A 67-year-old postmenopausal Caucasian female  nonsmoking  nonalcoholic and with a body mass index (BMI) of 25  appeared in the emergency department with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and up to her jaw. Pain was accompanied by shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting and a sense of impending disaster. The patient has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and osteoporosis. However  she denies any history of drug abuse  such as cocaine or methamphetamine  or recent physical/emotional stressful events. She also reports to be 'physically inactive.' Laboratory findings include a slight increase in cardiac enzymes (troponin T and I) and creatine kinase  with EKG indicating ST-segment elevation. An echocardiogram revealed reduced ejection fraction with apical ballooning  a typical manifestation of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   Her current medications include amlodipine for hypertension  atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia and alendronate for osteoporosis. Allergies are unreported.

Patient Representation:  Demographics: Ms. Tako  a 65-year-old postmenopausal woman of Asian descent  presented concerns relating to sudden-onset distress and chest pain. She lives independently in a suburban area with strong social support from her family. She is divorced with two grown children who visit regularly. She retired from being a school teacher about five years ago.  Medical History: Ms. Tako has a known history of hypertension  well-controlled on medication (Lisinopril 10mg once daily)  borderline high cholesterol managed with dietary changes  and mild osteoarthritis. She has no known diabetes or established coronary artery disease. She has no history of smoking or alcohol abuse. Her family history revealed that her mother had a stroke at age 70 and her father died of a myocardial infarction at age 65.   Recent Life Events: Ms. Tako had been through a series of stressful events in the past few months - her younger brother recently passed away and she is managing her own retirement planning  all concurrently caring for her elderly and ailing mother.  Medications: In addition to her Lisinopril  Ms. Tako takes a multivitamin  calcium supplement  and a baby aspirin daily.  Presenting Problems: She presented with complaints of severe stereotypical chest pain  shortness of breath  light-headedness  and profuse sweating  which began abruptly the previous night. The chest pain is central  radiating to the left arm  with a squeezing character  gets worse on exertion  and is associated with exertional breathlessness. The onset of chest pain is not related to food intake and it does not change with postural variations. There is no prior history of similar chest pain and she does not have any chronic cough or weight loss.   Given the sudden onset of distress  chest pain  and her recent series of stressful events  the differential diagnosis includes takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The condition mimics heart attack symptoms and is often triggered by severe stress but does not involve the coronary arteries. Hence  it is often known as ""broken heart syndrome"". Prompt evaluation and management are needed to address her symptoms and rule out other possible life-threatening conditions.   The description above provides problem representation for a typical patient presenting with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Problem Representation:  Patient Info:  - Patient: 67-year-old Asian woman  - Occupation: Retired school teacher - Marital status: Widowed  - Children: Two children (lives with a daughter) - Lifestyle: Non-smoker  occasional alcohol  regular exercise  Presenting Problem:  The patient presents with chest pain  shortness of breath  and mild fatigue following a severe emotional distress that occurred a week ago.   Past Medical History:  - The patient has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  under medication control  which has resulted in her lifestyle changes (regular exercise  low-salt  and low-fat diet).  - She was diagnosed with an underactive thyroid two years ago.  - She had a difficult year after the loss of her spouse  suffering grief and depression  for which she attended regular counseling but no pharmacologic therapy was necessary.  - There are no reports of previous similar incidents  nor has any prevalent heart disease been diagnosed before this event.  - She underwent hysterectomy due to marked uterine fibroids at the age of 45.  - She has no known drug allergies.  Investigations: - An EKG  cardiac enzymes such as troponin and CK-MB tests have been ordered to evaluate the cause of chest pain.  - An echocardiography and coronary angiography were performed based on her symptoms and age though no significant blockages were found  but a peculiar  balloon-shaped pattern in the left ventricle (LV) with characteristic apical ballooning was noticed  thus  clinching the diagnosis.  Treatment: Currently  she is admitted for observation and symptom management and is given beta-blockers to lower the heart rate and blood pressure. Additional interventions are being considered based upon symptom progression and response to the initial treatment.  Family History: Her mother succumbed to a stroke at the age of 72  and her father had prostate cancer in his late 70s. Her older sister is living with Type II Diabetes Mellitus.

Patient Representation:  Subject: Ms. Turner  a 58-year-old  Caucasian  female  Demographics: Ms. Turner is an unmarried woman who recently retired from her job as a high school principal. She lives alone but has a supportive network of friends and family nearby. She is moderately active  non-smoker  and drinks alcohol occasionally. She maintains a balanced diet and regularly takes her prescribed medications.   Relevant Medical History: Ms. Turner has a history of hypertension  controlled with medication  and suffered a mild stroke two years ago. She recovered well with no residual neurological deficits. She has no known incidences of heart disease in the family. She is not diabetic but has occasional episodes of anxiety due to the stress of her previous job. She has also previously been diagnosed with hypothyroidism.  Recent Health Issues: Ms. Turner recently experienced an intensely stressful event with the sudden death of her brother. Soon after  she experienced severe chest pain similar to that of a heart attack and was rushed to the ER. Cardiac enzymes were elevated  and an ECG indicated changes suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome. However  a coronary angiogram viewed normal coronary arteries. Instead  the distal part of the left ventricle was noted to have abnormal contractions  resembling a takotsubo  a Japanese octopus pot  leading the physician to suspect takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   Current Symptoms: Ms. Turner's symptoms include chest pain and shortness of breath. She also mentioned having palpitations and a sense of impending doom  likely secondary to anxiety.  Current Medications: 1. Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension 2. Levothyroxine 75 micrograms daily for hypothyroidism 3. Aspirin 81mg daily for stroke prevention 4. Occasional benzodiazepines (lorazepam) for anxiety  as needed  Risk Factors: - Post-menopausal state: The majority of takotsubo cardiomyopathy occurs in postmenopausal women. - Hypertension: Ms. Turner has a known history of hypertension. - Acute psychological stress: Recently experienced due to the sudden loss of her brother. - History of anxiety disorder   Clinical Examination and Laboratory Evaluations: Physical exam  blood work  chest x-ray  ECG  echocardiography  and coronary angiography would be performed to better understand her heart's current state.

Problem Representation:  Demographic Information: Ms. Samantha  a 61-year-old Caucasian female  presents in the emergency department with symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath. She also suffered from hypertension diagnosed five years ago that has been controlled with Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. Samantha is not a smoker and doesn't consume alcohol. The pain is severe  located in the center of the chest  radiating to the left arm  and not relieved by rest or traditional remedies.  Assuming that her emotional trauma acted as a potent trigger  the possibility of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (broken-hearted syndrome) is considered. The patient's recent emotional distress  current symptoms mimicking a heart attack (but without significant coronary artery disease history) all point towards this transient heart condition. Further tests including electrocardiogram (ECG)  cardiac enzymes  and echocardiogram to visualize wall motion abnormalities are required to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Demographic Information:   - Age: 67 years - Sex: Female  - Ethnicity: White/Caucasian - Occupation: Retired English Teacher - Marital Status: Widowed - Living Situation: Lives alone  with a nearby adult daughter who checks in regularly - Insurance: Medicare  Presenting Symptomatology:  The patient presents with sudden  severe chest pain and shortness of breath. Patient Profile:  Name: Mrs. Elizabeth Williams  Age: 65 years old   Gender: Female   Race: Caucasian   Residential History: Lives in Austin  Texas   Marital status: Widowed   Occupation: Recently retired school teacher   Insurance Status: Medicare   Family Medical History: Mother passed from heart disease at the age of 75. Both maternal and paternal grandparents had diabetes.  Presenting Problem:  Mrs. Williams has recently been feeling faint and exhausted after her usual daily activities. She has also experienced chest pain and shortness of breath over the last week. This caused her concern  as she leads an otherwise healthy lifestyle with regular moderate exercise and balanced diet.  Past Medical History:  1. Has been diagnosed with hypertension and been on medication for the past five years. 2. Recently went through the intense emotional strain of the death of her husband  six months ago. 3. Had gone through a major depressive episode during her late 40s. 4. Had gestational diabetes when she was pregnant with her second child but it resolved post-delivery. 5. She had a breast lump which proved to be benign fifteen years back.  Relevant personal history:  She is a non-smoker and does drink moderately  only socially. She has been consistent with her hypertension medications and has regular follow-ups with her physician.  Clinical representation of the problem:  The symptoms - chest pain  faintness  and difficulty breathing – along with the past history of hypertension and significant emotional stress  potentially point towards takotsubo cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome"". This is a temporary heart condition that's often brought on by stressful situations  such as the death of a loved one. People with this condition may have sudden chest pain and think they're having a heart attack. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is usually reversible  but it's important that it's caught early to avoid serious complications like heart failure.

Demographics:  Name: Mrs. H Sex: Female Age: 71 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher Marital status: Widowed Members in the home: Lives alone Lifestyle: Non-smoker  occasional alcohol  low-moderate physical activity Medication: Daily multivitamins  Problem Representation:  Presenting Issue: Mrs. H has come with complaints of severe chest pain  difficulty in breathing  emotional distress  and fatigue. She states that these symptoms started suddenly after she got to know about her son's death last week.   Medical History:  - Has a history of hypertension for which she is not on regular medication. - Regular screenings revealed no evidence of any cardiovascular disease. - Previous reports of occasional migraines. - No history of surgeries or major illnesses. - Family history consists of a father with type 2 diabetes and a mother with hypertension. No reported family history of heart disease.  Primary Care Physician Examinations:  After examination of Mrs. H  the doctor noticed: - Physical examination revealed no cyanosis  clubbing or edema.  - Chest was clear on auscultation  but she has tachycardia - EKG revealed changes typically seen with patients who have had a severe heart attack.   Hospital Course and Evaluation:  - Admitted immediately due to presenting symptoms suggestive of Acute Coronary Syndrome. - Causes of chest pain other than cardiac etiology does not seem fitting based on history and symptoms.  - Test revealed elevated cardiac enzymes. - Coronary angiogram showed no significant blockages that typically cause a heart attack  but abnormalities in her heart’s left ventricle. - Echocardiogram showed ballooning and weakening of left ventricle.  Diagnosis:  Based on the findings  Mrs. H was diagnosed with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy or Broken Heart Syndrome. The condition is characterized by a temporary sudden weakening of the heart muscle  most often triggered by intense physical or emotional stress  precisely in her case - an overwhelming grief caused by loss of her child. She likely had a healthy heart previously  hence no symptoms until this stressful event. Despite the condition itself mimics symptoms of a heart attack  there are no blocked arteries  a typical factor with heart attacks.

Problem Representation:   Case: Mrs. A  a 64-year-old postmenopausal woman  presents to the emergency department experiencing severe chest pain  similar to that of a heart attack. She describes her pain as sudden onset  severe  and pressure-like spreading to the back. It is associated with mild dyspnea.   Demographic Profile:  - Gender: Female - Age: 64 years - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired teacher - Marital Status: Widow - Living Status: Alone  Past Medical History:   - Post-menopausal  - No known prior cardiac disease  - No history of high blood pressure or diabetes  - Negative for smoking and alcohol use  - Negative for drug abuse - History of mild asthma  - History of generalized anxiety disorder   Recent Major Life Events:   Mrs. A recently lost her spouse of 30 years.  Salient Features:  - Severe chest pain - Mild dyspnea  - Absence of coronary artery disease  - Widowed with a history of generalized anxiety disorder - Recent bereavement   Problem:   Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  often known as broken-heart syndrome  is being suspected. The condition is often triggered by severe emotional stress  such as the loss of a spouse. The symptoms mimic those of a heart attack and typically occur in post-menopausal women. Most people affected by takotsubo cardiomyopathy do not have any known heart disease history  and this correlates with this patient’s lack of prior cardiac issues. It is proposed that the patient’s severe chest pain and dyspnea are due to the sudden release of stress hormones causing part of the heart to enlarge temporarily and not pump well  while the rest of the heart functions normally or with even more forceful contractions.   Further confirmatory tests are necessary to determine the diagnosis and appropriate treatment. With supportive medical care  most people recover completely from takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Post-Menopausal Female  Introduction: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome  is a condition in which extreme stress impairs the heart's ability to pump  often triggered by serious physical illness or extreme emotional stress. The following classic case of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy discusses a post-menopausal woman who developed symptoms following a stressful incidence.  Case Presentation: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian female who was presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with acute onset of severe chest pain and dyspnea. The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes mellitus type 2  for which she is taking amlodipine  simvastatin  and metformin  respectively.  The patient  a retired teacher  lives with her husband and has two adult children. She has a 20-pack year history of smoking  which ceased 15 years ago. She consumes alcohol socially and denies illicit drug use.  Clinical Findings: Upon examination  the patient was anxious  with a heart rate of 112 beats/minute  blood pressure of 152/90 mmHg  respirations of 22/minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. The cardiac examination revealed tachycardia without murmurs  rubs  or gallops. The patient’s lungs were clear on auscultation and her troponin was elevated at 1.3 ng/mL.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: ECG showed ST segment elevation in the anterior leads suggestive of anterior wall myocardial infarction. A subsequent coronary angiogram  however  did not reveal any significant obstructive coronary artery disease that would explain the electrocardiographic changes and her presenting symptoms.  An echocardiogram was performed revealing apical ballooning of the left ventricle  a classic sign of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. These results were consistent with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy using the Mayo Clinic diagnostic criteria.  The patient reported that her symptoms started shortly after she received distressing news of her brother's sudden death  suggesting that her condition was likely precipitated by extreme emotional stress.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment: The patient was managed with supportive therapy  intravenous nitroglycerin for chest pain  and was closely monitored in the Intensive Care Unit for any complications.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: Repeated echocardiography after a week showed normalization of the left ventricular function without any wall motion abnormality. The patient made a good recovery and was discharged with advice to undergo psychological counseling.  Discussion: While the exact cause of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy is not known  extreme stress seems to affect the heart muscle and its ability to pump. This case emphasises the need for the consideration of this diagnosis in post-menopausal women with chest pain and ECG changes  especially in the context of emotional stress  despite the absence of significant coronary artery disease.   Patient Perspective: The patient felt relieved understanding the cause of her symptoms and was grateful for the care and support provided by the medical team. She agreed to consider psychological counseling to manage stress better in the future.  Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and any accompanying images.

Title: Acute Stress-Induced (Takotsubo) Cardiomyopathy in a Middle-Aged Female: A Case Report  Patient Profile: A 59-year-old Caucasian female  employed as a high school teacher  presented at the emergency department at 7:23 pm on 20/05/2022.  Demographics: The patient lives in an urban area  has a stable family life with two grown-up children and a supportive husband  and is a non-smoker. She has no known drug allergies. This patient has lived a physically active life  with no recorded unhealthy dietary habits or substance abuse issues. She has no family history of cardiovascular disease. Her Body Mass Index (BMI) is classified as 'normal' (21.7 kg/m2).  Past Medical History: The patient had a diagnosed history of anxiety and depression and was on selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) for the last ten years. Incidentally  the patient had been experiencing higher stress levels in the past few months due to work. She does not have any history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus  respiratory  kidney  or gastrointestinal diseases. She had her menopause at the age of 52 years and was not on any hormonal replacement therapy.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented with sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to the upper left arm and associated with shortness of breath and palpitations since 01:00 pm on the same day. There was no history of cough  fever  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or prior similar episodes.  Clinical Examination: Physical examination revealed tachycardia  with a heart rate of 110 beats/min  and blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg. The rest of the physical examination  including cardiovascular  respiratory  and abdominal examination  showed no abnormal findings.  Investigations: An electrocardiogram (EKG) showed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  suggestive of acute anterior wall myocardial infarction. Laboratory tests showed raised troponin levels. However  the coronary angiogram was surprising as it reported no significant coronary artery disease. An echocardiogram was conducted  which showed apical ballooning consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Discussion: Given the clinical picture and the results of investigations  the patient was diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy  likely precipitated by significant work stress  despite a lack of traditional cardiovascular risk factors.  Treatment: The patient was treated supportively with beta blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  and reassurance. Her SSRIs were continued and a referral was made for further psychological support.  Outcome: The patient's symptoms improved over a period of a few days  and she was discharged home with close outpatient follow-up.  Final Remarks: This case report underscores the importance of recognizing takotsubo cardiomyopathy as a differential diagnosis in acute chest pain  especially in postmenopausal women with a history of psychiatric illness and recent stressful events. This diagnosis necessitates a different therapeutic approach than acute coronary syndrome  focusing on symptomatic relief and stress management.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 70-Year-Old Female Patient: A Case Report  Patient Description: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian female of medium build with past medical history significant for essential hypertension  non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus  and major depressive disorder. She has no known allergies and is not a smoker or an alcoholic. The patient lives in a suburban setting with her husband  is retired  and leads an active lifestyle.   Presenting Complaint: The patient presented with acute-onset chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  and a feeling of impending doom  which began approximately 2 hours earlier while attending a graveside service of a close friend.   Hospital Admission: Upon admission to the hospital  vital signs revealed the patient had tachycardia and hypertension. Her blood pressure was 150/100 mmHg and heart rate was elevated at 112 beats per minute.   Investigations: Cardiac enzyme tests revealed a slightly elevated level of Troponin T at 0.04 ng/ml. A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in the anterolateral leads and deep T-wave inversions. An echocardiogram revealed apical ballooning and reduced left ventricular ejection fraction at 45%  suggesting the possibility of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.  Medical management: The patient was commenced on aspirin  a beta-blocker  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor  and a statin as per management of an acute coronary syndrome (ACS). Also  she was given intravenously administered nitroglycerin for acute hypertension management and better coronary perfusion.  Further Tests: To exclude ACS  coronary angiography was performed  revealing normal coronary arteries  which confirmed the diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.   Outcome and follow up: The patient’s symptoms started subsiding after 48 hours  and repeat echocardiogram done after 5 days from the episode  demonstrated normalized left ventricular function. She was discharged from the hospital in a stable condition after 7 days  with outpatient follow up recommendations. As part of the follow-up  behavioral therapy was advised considering her prior depression diagnosis and the possibility of psychological stress playing a role in her cardiac event.  Conclusion: This case recapitulates the clinical presentation of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  which mimics acute coronary syndrome  often induced by severe emotional stress. Even though this condition often affects post-menopausal women  it should be considered in differential diagnosis irrespective of gender and age  when patients present with chest pain  especially with triggering emotional or physical stress. Furthermore  psychological intervention should be an integral part of the therapy.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in an Elderly Female with History of Hypertension   Introduction:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TTC)  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome  is a condition characterized by transient left ventricular dysfunction  commonly triggered by acute emotional or physical stress. This condition mimics the clinical features of acute coronary syndrome (ACS) but has no obstructive coronary disease on angiography. Most cases of TTC are typically identified in post-menopausal women.  Case Report:  The patient is a 74-year-old Caucasian female presenting with severe chest pain radiating to her neck and left arm. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension  controlled with lisinopril  and a remote history of depression  treated with fluoxetine.   The patient reported that her chest pain began suddenly  several hours after hearing about her sister's unexpected passing. On examination  she had a blood pressure of 170/97 mmHg  pulse rate of 105 per minute  and respiratory rate of 22 per minute. Twelve-lead EKG indicated ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads  raising the suspicion of an anterior wall myocardial infarction.  The patient was urgently moved to the catheterization lab where coronary angiography revealed no obstructive coronary artery disease. Left ventriculogram demonstrated apical ballooning with impaired systolic function which is consistent with TTC  leading to the diagnosis.  The patient was managed with supportive care including beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and diuretics to control her blood pressure and heart rate and was monitored in the cardiac care unit for 72 hours. The case was complicated by transient left ventricular outflow tract obstruction treated with fluid resuscitation and cessation of ACE inhibitors.  Discussion:  In this case  the patient's chest symptoms  EKG changes  and the transient nature of the left ventricular dysfunction after emotional stress are all consistent with TTC  also known as broken heart syndrome. The stress of her sister's untimely death likely precipitated the TTC in this patient with pre-existing hypertension who presumably had heightened sympathetic activation.   This case highlights the need for physicians to consider TTC in the differential diagnosis for patients  particularly post-menopausal women  presenting with chest pain and ECG findings suggestive of ACS  especially in the context of recent severe emotional stress. Though the prognosis of TTC is usually favorable  complications can occur  as exemplified by this case where the patient developed transient outflow tract obstruction.   Detailed and informed care can lead to positive short and long-term outcomes for these cases. While treatment is primarily supportive and most patients recover within days to weeks  this condition can reoccur. Therefore  patients should be informed about the nature of the disease and the potential for recurrence with future stressors.   Keywords: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Post-Menopausal Women  Chest Pain  EKG  Acute Coronary Syndrome.

Patient Information: Ms. J.R.  a 75-year-old Caucasian female.  Chief Complaint: Ms. J.R. presented at the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain radiating to her left arm along with episodes of lightheadedness. She reports that her symptoms commenced suddenly during a family gathering at which she received the shocking news of her younger brother's abrupt death.  Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  for which she has been taking medication (Lisinopril  10mg daily) for the past 10 years. She has no history of coronary artery disease  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  or family history of cardiac-related diseases. She quit smoking around 20 years ago and consumes alcohol recreationally. She reports having an uneventful medical history except for occasional bouts of anxiety and depression  exacerbated by stressful events. The patient has been currently grieving the sudden loss of her younger brother  which she reports as a significantly stressful event.  Investigations: An electrocardiogram (EKG) was immediately performed  revealing ST-segment elevation in the anterolateral leads  suggestive of a possible anterolateral myocardial infarction. The patient's bloodwork showed elevated cardiac biomarkers— troponin T levels at 0.12 ng/mL(normal: <0.01 ng/mL). Complete blood count  renal function  and electrolytes were within normal limits. Chest X-ray yielded no conclusive anomalies.  Emergency coronary angiography did not reveal any significant coronary artery disease to account for the ST-segment elevation. An echocardiograph was then performed  showing akinesis of the apical and middle segments of the left ventricle and hyperkinesis of the basal walls  which is typical of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Diagnosis: Based on these results  the patient was diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Treatment: The patient was managed conservatively with heart failure medications: angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors)  beta-blockers  and diuretics. Additionally  she was also conscientiously monitored throughout her hospital stay.  Outcome and Follow-Up: After 5 days of hospitalization  the patient's symptoms improved significantly. Her chest pain and lightheadedness subsided completely. A repeat EKG demonstrated normalization of previous ST changes  and a follow-up echocardiogram showed significant improvement in the left ventricular function. The patient was discharged with a prescription for a beta-blocker (Metoprolol)  an ACE inhibitor  and a recommendation for follow-up consultations with a cardiologist and psychotherapy for grief management.  Conclusion: This is a classic presentation of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome "" triggered by extreme emotional stress. With timely diagnosis and conservative management  the prognosis is generally good  and most of the patients recover completely. However  routine follow-up and psychological support form a crucial part of the management and recovery process.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Information:  - Age: 67 - Sex: Female - Ethnicity: Asian - Occupation: Retired primary school teacher  Chief Complaint:  The patient presented to the emergency department with central chest pain and shortness of breath.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  both of which are well controlled with medication. She is a non-smoker and takes moderate alcohol. She has no known allergies. Her family history was negative for cardiac diseases.  Clinical Findings:  On presentation  the patient appeared in obvious distress  her blood pressure was 160/85 mmHg  pulse was 110 bpm  and respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute. Electrocardiogram (EKG) showed ST-segment elevation in anterior leads. Initial blood tests revealed elevated levels of cardiac troponin T (cTnT) and brain natriuretic peptide (BNP).  Diagnostic Assessment:  Based on the presenting symptoms and the EKG changes  the initial suspicion was for an acute coronary syndrome. However  on performing an urgent coronary angiogram  no significant coronary artery disease was found. An echocardiography  instead  showed apical ballooning of the left ventricle with preserved basal function  characteristic of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM) or 'broken heart syndrome'.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient received supportive care for her symptoms  with oxygen supplementation and nitroglycerin for her chest pain. Given her diagnosis of TCM  she was started on a beta blocker and an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor  then switched to a calcium channel blocker due to a dry cough side effect.  Follow-up and Outcome:  She was discharged 5 days after admission with a decreased level of cTnT and BNP. At a 1-month follow-up appointment  she reported a remarkable reduction in symptoms. Follow up echocardiography at six weeks showed resolution of the left ventricular dysfunction with an improved ejection fraction. The beta blocker was slowly tapered off over a 3-month period.  Clinical Lessons:  This case highlights the importance of considering TCM as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with suspected acute coronary syndrome  especially in postmenopausal women with a history of psychological stressors. Prompt recognition of this condition can help in instituting appropriate management and preventing unnecessary interventions. It also underscores the necessity of a follow-up echocardiography in the differential diagnosis of chest pain.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Post-Menopausal Woman - A Case Report  Patient Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian female presented at the Emergency Department with severe chest pain. The patient reported she lived alone  had recently retired from her job as a high-school teacher  and was a non-smoker with a moderate consumption of alcohol (5-10 drinks/week).  Clinical Findings: The patient described a sudden onset of chest pain radiating to the left arm with associated shortness of breath. She rated her pain as 8 on a scale of 10  which significantly worsened with exertion. She also reported experiencing an intense emotional stress event earlier in the day  consisting of finding out about her son's serious car accident.  Diagnostic Assessment: Electrocardiogram (ECG) at presentation showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior-septal and inferior leads. Initial troponins were slightly elevated  further raising the suspicion for Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS). However  coronary angiography did not reveal any significant blockages. Echocardiography displayed apical akinesis  basal hyperkinesis  and moderate left ventricular dysfunction; findings consistent with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TCM).  Past Medical History: Patient's past medical history was significant for hypertension  controlled with an angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitor  and hyperlipidemia  managed with statin therapy. She had no history of ischemic heart disease  diabetes  or known cardiac risk factors. She had no prior episodes of chest pain or discomfort.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was managed with standard heart failure treatment  including beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and diuretics as needed for volume status. She reported subjective improvement of symptoms and was monitored in the cardiology ward.  Follow-up: The patient was discharged after four days of admission with a stable condition. She was continued on her previous antihypertensive and lipid-lowering treatments and was also started on beta-blockers. At 1-month follow-up  repeat echocardiogram showed resolution of the previous wall-motion abnormalities with an improved left ventricular ejection fraction  confirming the diagnosis of TCM. The patient reported no residual symptoms and had returned to her normal level of activity.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the vital role of emotional stress as a trigger for TCM  otherwise known as 'broken heart syndrome'. The prompt diagnosis and appropriate management of these patients are essential for improving patient outcomes. It is also important to follow these patients closely  as recurrence of TCM has been reported in the literature. The patient was advised to seek mental counseling to cope with stressors in the future.

Title: An Unusual Presentation of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 58-year-old Caucasian Male  Patient Information:  Caucasian male  58 years old  married  residing in Greensboro  North Carolina. He is a non-smoker and a social drinker. He reports a sedentary lifestyle as a computer programmer with high levels of work-related stress. The patient has a history of mild hypertension  well-controlled with lisinopril. There are no recorded instances of heart disease in his family.  Clinical Findings:  The patient was brought in by ambulance following a sudden onset of severe chest pain with associated shortness of breath whilst at work. Vitals taken at emergency hospital admission showed - BP: 170/90 mmHg  HR: 101 bpm  RR: 20/min  SpO2: 96% on room air  Temp: 37.2°C. The initial examination revealed diaphoresis  tachycardia  and elevated blood pressure signs consistent with acute distress.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An EKG was promptly performed  suggesting ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). However  subsequent cardiac catheterization did not reveal any significant coronary artery disease.  Laboratory investigations showed elevated troponin levels at 2.5 ng/ml (normal range: < 0.5 ng/mL) signifying myocardial injury.  Selected acute echocardiography revealed a markedly reduced left ventricular ejection fraction of 35% (normal range: 55-70%) and a distinctive pattern of apical ballooning with basal hypercontractility. These findings in the absence of significant obstructive coronary disease  favored a provisional diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TTC). An evaluation of his history revealed intense work stress just before the onset of symptoms.  Therapeutic Interventions:  Initially  aspirin and clopidogrel were given considering the provisional diagnosis of STEMI. However  once Takotsubo cardiomyopathy was diagnosed  heart failure management was initiated with beta-blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  and diuretics. The patient was subsequently managed in the CCU until improvement of his cardiac function was evidenced on repeat echocardiography.  Follow Up and Outcomes:  Repeat echocardiography after the 4-week outpatient follow-up visit showed recovery of left ventricular function with an ejection fraction of 62%. Troponin levels at follow-up were within the normal range. The patient reported adherence to medications and had incorporated regular physical activity and mindfulness practices into his routine to better manage his work-related stress.  Patient Perspective:  The patient expressed surprise about his diagnosis  as he was not aware that extreme stress could result in a heart condition mimicking a heart attack. He has made significant lifestyle modifications to avoid a similar event in the future.  Informed Consent:  The patient gave informed consent for this data to be published.  This case highlights the importance of considering Takotsubo cardiomyopathy as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with suspected acute coronary syndrome  particularly in the context of recent severe stress. An awareness and understanding of this condition can lead to appropriate management and favorable outcomes.

Case Report  Demographic Information:  The patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian female who presented to the Emergency Department (ED). She resides in a suburban neighborhood of Boston  Massachusetts  living with her husband and two retired university faculty. She is a retired school teacher who is now a part-time volunteer at a local charity organization. She has never smoked and drinks occasionally during social gatherings. Her BMI is 24.2 kg/m^2. She has no history of illicit drug use.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of hypertension for 20 years  for which she takes Lisinopril 20 mg daily. In the past  she demonstrated a moderately healthy lifestyle  exercising three times a week and maintaining a balanced diet with a low salt intake. She has no known allergies. She is without a history of diabetes mellitus  dyslipidemia  and has no known genetic disorders.   Presenting History:   The patient was brought to the ED by her husband. She was experiencing a sudden onset of chest discomfort  radiated to the back  along with shortness of breath  and nausea that started three hours prior to presentation. She mentioned that she had been under immense emotional stress for the last two weeks due to the sudden death of her only son.  In the ED  her blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg  pulse rate 110/min  and respiratory rate 24/min. The ECG showed ST-segment elevations in the precordial leads (V2-V4). Initial cardiac enzyme tests indicated moderately elevated troponin levels.   The patient was initially managed as a suspected case of acute myocardial infarction and underwent emergency coronary angiography. The results showed no significant stenosis in coronary arteries. Thus  myocardial infarction was unlikely. However  her left ventriculography revealed apical ballooning with basal hyperkinesis  resembling a takotsubo.   The patient was managed conservatively with beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and reassured regarding the generally good prognosis of the condition.  Diagnosis:  Based on the clinical presentation  cardiac biomarker levels  ECG changes  and characteristic angiographic findings  a diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TTC) or Broken Heart Syndrome was made.  Conclusion:   This case represents an instance of TTC associated with bereavement stress. It highlights the necessity of considering TTC in the differential diagnosis in patients  especially post-menopausal women  presenting with chest pain  ECG changes  and elevated cardiac markers despite angiographically normal coronary arteries. The underlying intense stress and emotional trauma appear to be potential triggering factors.   As TTC often mimics an acute myocardial infarction  an accurate and rapid diagnosis is critical to initiate the appropriate management and avoid unnecessary invasive treatments. Moreover  given the clear association between emotional stressors and TTC  clinicians should also consider the importance of psychological support as part of the management plan.

Patient Information: The patient  a 64-year-old Caucasian woman who lives alone  presented at the ER with acute onset of severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and light-headedness. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia but no known cardiac history. Her regular medications include Amlodipine for her blood pressure and Atorvastatin for her cholesterol. She has been a non-smoker for her entire life  consumes alcohol infrequently  and maintains a balanced diet.   Situation Leading to Presentation: She reported that she had heard upsetting news that her only son was moving overseas in two days earlier. An initial electrocardiogram was concerning for an acute coronary syndrome with ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Her initial cardiac biomarkers showed a troponin level of 4.2 ng/mL (normal range <0.04 ng/mL) with a CK-MB of 35 ng/mL (normal range <7 ng/mL).  Investigations: The patient underwent emergency coronary angiography to rule out myocardial infarction. The angiogram showed normal coronary arteries without any significant stenosis. However  ventricular angiography showed left ventricular apical ballooning suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Diagnosis: The diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy was established based on the Mayo Clinic criteria: transient hypokinesis  akinesis  or dyskinesis of the left ventricular mid-segments with apical ballooning; absence of obstructive coronary disease or angiographic evidence of an acute plaque rupture; new ECG changes or elevated cardiac troponin level; and absence of pheochromocytoma or myocarditis.  Treatment: She was initially managed with aspirin  a loading dose of P2Y12 inhibitor (Clopidogrel)  beta-blocker (Metoprolol)  and ACE inhibitor (Lisinopril). Once coronary artery disease was excluded and the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy was confirmed  aspirin and Clopidogrel were discontinued. She was maintained on Metoprolol and Lisinopril.  Outcome and Follow-Up: Her hospital course was uneventful  her signs and symptoms improved dramatically over the next 48 hours and she was discharged home. One month later at her cardiology outpatient follow-up  repeat echocardiography showed normalization of the left ventricular systolic function. The patient has since been coping well with ongoing psychological support to manage her emotional stress.  Learning Points: This case highlights the relationship between emotional stress and Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Thorough medical evaluation is crucial in differential diagnosis to exclude acute coronary syndrome. The management of patients with this condition often involves handling not only their cardiac condition but also their psychological stressors.

Title: Postmenopausal Woman with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy Precipitated by Emotional Stress  Case Report:  Patient Information: The patient is a 67-year-old African American woman  who lives with her adult children in the suburban area. She is a widow  and a retired elementary school teacher. She has no history of alcohol or tobacco use.  Clinical Findings: The patient presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain  symptoms of palpitations  and shortness of breath. She reported an extremely stressful episode occurred earlier in the day  involving a sudden passing of a close friend.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: The EKG on presentation demonstrated ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads. Patient was immediately brought to the cardiac catheterization lab  thinking it was an acute myocardial infarction. However  coronary angiography revealed no significant coronary artery disease. Left ventriculography showed apical ballooning with hypercontraction of the basal segments  a classic ""octopus pot"" appearance indicative of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TTC).  Her laboratory profile showed increased values of cardiac enzymes with Troponin T level of 0.94 ng/ml. Echocardiogram revealed left ventricular systolic dysfunction  with a reduced ejection fraction of 40%. Her blood pressure was normal  and she had a heart rate of 88 beats per minute.   Past Medical History: The patient had a history of diabetes mellitus type 2  hyperlipidemia  and hypertension. She had also been treated a couple of years back for a major depressive disorder.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment: The patient was managed with standard heart failure medication including beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and diuretics. Her blood glucose was also managed with insulin therapy. A psychiatric team was involved to address her emotional stressors and past history of depressive disorder. A grief counseling session was also arranged to help cope with her loss.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Post-treatment  she showed significant improvement both physically and emotionally. The repeat echocardiogram after 8 weeks showed a normal ejection fraction and resolution of wall motion abnormalities  confirming the diagnosis of TTC. The patient was then discharged from the hospital with appointments for regular follow-ups and continued grief counseling sessions.  Conclusion: This case demonstrated that TTC  often precipitated by severe emotional stress  might present similarly as an acute coronary syndrome. Hence  it underscores the importance of the differential diagnosis in a patient presenting with chest pain and EKG changes  especially in postmenopausal women with an emotional trigger.  Patient Consent: Obtained.  Ethical Approval: Not Required.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Demographics: Patient Identifier: Mrs. A Age: 64 years old Gender: Female  Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher  Current Presentation: The patient presented to the emergency department with acute onset chest pain and shortness of breath  which had started a couple of hours before her presentation. On examination  she appeared in distress with labored breathing. The chest pain was described as sharp and persistent  centralized in the mid chest region without radiation to the neck  jaw  or left arm.   Past Medical History:  The patient had a significant past medical history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  maintained on standard medication. She had no known allergies. She had no previously documented instances of angina  myocardial infarctions or cardiac interventions. Mrs. A had no history of diabetes mellitus  connective tissue disorders or malignancies. Her family history was significant for coronary artery disease  as her father had been diagnosed at the age of 59.   Investigations: On admission  her vital signs showed a blood pressure of 170/110 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per min  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per min and peripheral oxygen saturation of 92% on ambient air. The electrocardiogram revealed ST segment elevations in leads V1-V4 suggestive of an anterior wall STEMI. Blood tests revealed slightly elevated cardiac troponin levels. A bedside echocardiogram demonstrated apical ballooning with preserved basal function suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   Treatment and Course: The patient was started on beta blockers  ACE inhibitors  and statins as per the standard treatment protocol for suspected acute coronary syndrome. She was also put on oxygen via nasal cannula to maintain oxygen saturation over 94%. Given the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  high stress level was identified as a potential triggering factor  although the patient could not recall any particular recent stressing events. On the 3rd day of admission  the patient's condition improved significantly; her chest pain had subsided  and her respiratory status had stabilized. A repeat echocardiogram showed improvement in the apical ballooning. The patient was discharged after 5 days of hospital stay with prescriptions and lifestyle modification advice.  Follow Up: She was scheduled for a regular outpatient cardiology follow up visits. The importance of regular follow-ups and medication compliance were discussed in detail  with an emphasis on controlling hypertension and lowering cholesterol levels. The patient was also advised to seek therapeutic modalities to manage stress.  Conclusion:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome  can mimic the presentation of acute coronary syndrome. This case of Mrs. A highlighted the significance of comprehensive clinical examinations and the prudent use of diagnostic tools to establish the correct diagnosis and hence the appropriate management.

Patient Description: A 62-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department.  Presenting Complaint: The patient was concerned about recent episodes of severe chest pain and shortness of breath that began after receiving news of her son's sudden passing.  Medical History: The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension  for which she has been on amlodipine 10 mg daily for the past ten years . She has no known allergies. She has a 20 pack-year history of smoking but quit 15 years ago. She does not consume alcohol or use illicit drugs. There is no family history of ischemic heart disease or any genetic disorders.   Assessment: Physical examination showed that her blood pressure was 170/95 mmHg  heart rate was 105 beats per minute  and respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute. Her oxygen saturation was 93% on room air. The patient appeared anxious and was sweating profusely. The cardiovascular examination revealed no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. The lungs were clear to auscultation  and the rest of her examination was normal.  Investigation: The electrocardiogram (ECG) exhibited ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. The Preliminary blood investigations showed normal complete blood count  electrolytes  renal  and liver function test results. Cardiac markers were elevated with troponin I level of 2.4 ng/ml.   Hospital Course: The patient was promptly moved to the Cath lab suspecting acute myocardial infarction. Coronary angiography showed no obstructive coronary artery disease. Left ventriculography revealed apical ballooning with basal hyperkinesis consistent with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.   Management: The patient was started on therapy with a beta-blocker (metoprolol)  an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor (lisinopril)  and a statin (atorvastatin). The patient's chest pain and dyspnea improved significantly over the next few days. Repeat echocardiogram after 1 week showed significant improvement in left ventricular function.   Discussion:  Although takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM) is most commonly reported in postmenopausal women  it can occur in people of all ages and genders. Our patient's particular circumstance of her son's unexpected death was probably the acute emotional stressor that resulted in TCM.   Conclusion: This case illustrates the classic presentation of TCM following a severe emotional stressor. Despite the initial presentation's similarity with acute myocardial infarction  the lack of significant coronary artery disease  and characteristic ventriculogram contributed to the diagnosis of TCM. This case emphasizes the importance of considering TCM in the differential diagnosis when presented with similar cases. Also  it underlines the significance of stress management  considering TCM has been associated with emotional and physical stressors.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 60-year-old Female  Presenting Patient:  A 60-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset severe  crushing central chest pain that radiated to her left arm. The pain was not associated with exertion and came on suddenly while she was attending her husband's funeral service. The pain was accompanied by pallor  sweating and a brief episode of syncope.  Demographics:  The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian female  married and retired secondary school teacher  who lives with her daughter and son-in-law after her husband's recent passing away. She used to smoke  but quit 20 years ago and drinks alcohol occasionally. There is no record of drug abuse.  Past Medical History:  She has a history of well-controlled hypertension for the past 10 years and is on regular antihypertensive medication. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago and maintains good control with oral hypoglycaemic agents. She also has a history of mild anxiety and has been on low doses of an SSRIs with good control of her symptoms. There is no family history of premature coronary artery disease.  Presenting Symptoms:  She is in severe pain rated at 8 on a 0-10 scale despite 5 mg of IV morphine. She has pallor  and her blood pressure is 105/65 mmHg  and heart rate is 110 bpm. She reports a feeling of impending doom.  Investigations:  Initial ECG shows ST-elevation in anterior leads  consistent with a suspected myocardial infarction. Troponin I level was elevated. However  a subsequent coronary angiogram revealed patent coronary arteries. An echocardiogram was performed that showed hypokinesia of the mid and apical segments of the left ventricle with hypercontraction of the basal walls  a pattern suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Treatment and Outcome:  The diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy was confirmed  and the patient was treated with supportive measures including ACE inhibitors  beta-blockers  and diuretics. Her pain gradually subsided over the course of several hours  and her cardiac function returned to normal upon re-testing 4 weeks later  confirming the diagnosis.  Discussion:  This case illustrates the typical clinical scenario of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome  often precipitated by sudden emotional stress. Despite presenting like an acute myocardial infarction  coronary angiography often reveals patent coronary arteries  while shell ventriculography or echocardiography demonstrates the characteristic balloon-like dilation of the apical segments of the left ventricle. Management is usually supportive  and most patients experience complete resolution of symptoms within weeks.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Post-Menopausal Woman: A Case Study   Case Presentation:   The patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia and pre-diabetes. She presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the left arm. She is a retired school teacher  lives with her husband  non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. Her family history reveals that her mother had cardiovascular disease and her father had Type-2 diabetes.   Clinical Findings:  Upon arrival at the hospital  she appeared distressed and diaphoretic. Her blood pressure was 165/95 mmHg  pulse rate was 100 bpm  respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation was 96% on room air and her body temperature was within the normal range. Cardiac auscultation revealed no murmur  gallop or rub. Pulmonary  abdominal  and neurological examinations were normal. An electrocardiogram (EKG) showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads and mild T-wave inversions in the inferior leads.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Given the suspicion of an acute coronary syndrome  she was immediately started on dual antiplatelet therapy  beta-blockers  and high-intensity statin. Troponin I level was elevated at 2.8 ng/mL. However  a coronary angiogram did not show any significant coronary artery disease. A left ventriculogram revealed apical ballooning with basal hyperkinesis consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The patient did not have any evident stressors except she mentioned having a heated argument with her husband the day before the symptoms occurred.  Therapeutic Intervention & Follow-Up:  In consultation with Cardiology  the patient was managed conservatively with continuation of beta-blockers and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. The dual antiplatelet therapy and statin were discontinued. She was monitored in the cardiac care unit and her chest pain improved over the next couple of days. Echocardiogram prior to discharge showed improving left ventricular function with an ejection fraction of 45% (initially it was 30%). The patient was discharged home with instructions to avoid stress and to follow-up in the outpatient cardiology clinic.  Conclusion:  This case highlights that takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome "" should be considered as a differential diagnosis among post-menopausal women presenting with chest pain and EKG changes suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome  especially in the absence of significant coronary artery disease. This case also emphasizes the essential role of a thorough patient history to understand potential emotional triggers  which could be valuable in the management of this condition.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Post-Menopausal Woman Following Emotional Stress: A Case Report  Case Report: The patient is a 65-year-old post-menopausal woman  Caucasian  retired school teacher  residing in Boston  Massachusetts. Her medical history is significant for hypertension  well controlled with amlodipine 5mg daily  and hypercholesterolemia controlled with atorvastatin 10mg daily. She has had no prior history of chest pain  palpitations  or syncope. She does not smoke  drink alcohol  or use illicit drugs. She is physically active  regularly participating in tennis and yoga. Her familial history is unremarkable  with no immediate relatives having heart disease.  The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain and dyspnea strictly correlated with an emotional stress episode. Prior to the chest pain episode  the patient discovered the sudden death of her beloved cat  which evidently caused severe emotional distress. She described the pain as ""crushing "" radiating to her left arm. She also reported feelings of lightheadedness and palpitations. On arrival  her vital signs were stable but her blood pressure was elevated at 160/95 mmHg. The ECG demonstrated ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  suggestive of an anterior wall myocardial infarction.  Emergency coronary angiography was performed  showing normal coronary arteries without any signs of atherosclerosis. Left ventriculography showed apical ballooning with preserved basal function  consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Cardiac biomarkers were significantly elevated with troponin T levels peaking at 332 ng/L (reference range  <14 ng/L) about 14 hours after the onset of symptoms. Echocardiography demonstrated left ventricular systolic dysfunction  with a left ventricular ejection fraction estimated at 45%.  The patient was admitted to the coronary care unit (CCU) where she received treatment that included beta blockers  ACE inhibitors and diuretics. As she stabilized  her blood pressure levels returned to her baseline and her chest pain subsided completely. The patient was discharged on the fifth day with medical therapy including metoprolol  lisinopril  and aspirin. She was also recommended to follow up with her primary care physician and a cardiologist as an outpatient  and she was advised to join a support group or start therapy to address the emotional trauma she experienced.  A follow-up exam performed 3 months later showed complete recovery of left ventricular function as confirmed by echocardiography  which demonstrated an ejection fraction of 60%. This helped confirm the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  as the spontaneous recovery is characteristic of this stress-induced condition.  Discussion: This case illustrates the clinical manifestation of takotsubo cardiomyopathy induced by emotional stress in a post-menopausal woman. This patient's presentation of symptoms typical of myocardial infarction  absence of obstructive coronary artery disease  and the presence of transient left ventricular dysfunction supports the diagnosis. The significant impact of emotional stress underlines the importance of the mind-heart connection and emphasizes the need for holistic patient management strategies in such cases  including psychological support.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy Triggered by Emotional Stress: A Case Report   Introduction:   Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TTC)  also referred to as stress cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome  is a fully reversible form of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy caused by excessive stress leading to an apical ballooning syndrome and deep T-wave inversions or QT segment prolongation on EKG. The condition  predominantly affecting postmenopausal women  is often precipitated by a significant stress event.   Case Presentation:   Patient Information: A 68-year-old Caucasian female  known to live alone  presented to the emergency room (ER) with chest discomfort radiating to her left arm along with shortness of breath.  Medical History: Her past medical history included hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which were well controlled with medication. She had no known cardiac history. Family history revealed a mother with hypertension but no premature coronary disease or sudden cardiac death.  Clinical Findings: On examination  she was noticed to be tachycardic with a heart rate of 105 bpm  blood pressure of 140/85 mmHg. Her physical examination was largely unremarkable  with no clinical evidence of heart failure. Normal S1 and S2 were heard and there were no murmurs  rubs  or gallops.  Diagnostic Assessment: Electrocardiography revealed T wave inversions in the anterior precordial leads  initially raising concerns for ischemic heart disease. An echo-cardiogram showed reduced left ventricular systolic function with apical ballooning  consistent with the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Her troponin T level was mildly raised at 0.06 ng/ml (normal = < 0.01 ng/ml). Subsequent cardiac catheterisation ruled out a coronary artery disease  further confirming the suspected diagnosis.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was admitted to the cardiac intensive care unit and started on beta-blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  and was treated conservatively with aspirin and statins until coronary artery disease was ruled out.  Follow-up and Outcomes: A follow-up echo-cardiogram after two weeks showed complete resolution of apical ballooning with an improved left ventricular ejection fraction  thus confirming the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. She reported the recent stress of her grandson's sudden death  suggesting an emotional trigger for her cardio-vascular event.  Patient Perspective: The patient stated she felt ""relieved"" that she did not have a heart attack  but was surprised that ""stress could have such an impact"" on her heart. She is committed to managing her stress levels and continuing the prescribed medication considering her cardiac episode.  Conclusion:   This clinical presentation highlights the important differential of takotsubo cardiomyopathy in post-menopausal women presenting with symptoms suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome. It underscores the need for thorough investigation  to ensure accurate diagnosis and appropriate management. It is essential to consider emotional stress as a trigger for a broken heart syndrome.

Patient Information:  A 67-year-old Hispanic female patient presented to the emergency department of a community hospital.  Chief Complaint:  The patient complained of severe chest pain that started about an hour prior to presentation while she was dealing with a stressful situation at home.  Medical History:  The patient has a documented history of hypertension for which she has been taking prescribed alpha-beta blockers for about five years. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes six years ago and has been controlling it with dietary modification and oral medications. She denied smoking or alcohol use but reported a moderate level of daily stress mainly related to her role as caregiver for her husband who has Parkinson's disease.  Description of Problem:  The patient was in severe distress during presentation  with symptoms mimicking that of a classic heart attack  including shortness of breath  palpitations  and chest pain - primarily on the left side. Initial electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation  initially suggestive of a myocardial infarction  prompting urgent attention.   However  an emergency cardiac catheterization showed no significant blockages in the coronary arteries that would cause a heart attack. An echocardiogram and left ventriculogram showed a normal size left ventricle  severely reduced function  and a peculiar shape - her left ventricle took on the appearance of a traditional Japanese octopus fishing pot  known as ""takotsubo"". Given the patient’s symptoms  absence of significant coronary blockages and the characteristic abnormality demonstrated  she was diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Treatment and Outcome:  Treatment was initiated which comprised mainly supportive care since there is no clear consensus on how to treat Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. As her chest pain began to subside  her cardiac function gradually returned to normal over the course of a few weeks. The unusual shape of the left ventricle slowly disappeared  confirming the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Her at-home supportive care was recommended to reduce stress levels.  Conclusion:  This case highlights that the presentation of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy can closely mimic more renowned cardiac disorders such as myocardial infarction  hence its nickname ""Broken Heart Syndrome"". High stress levels  in this case life strain associated with caregiving  appear to play a key role. Physicians should remain vigilant for the possibility of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  especially in post-menopausal women with a recent history of severe emotional stress.

Title: Case of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy Triggered by Emotional Stress  Patient Profile:  Mr. X is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  a retired professional  with no known history of any cardiovascular diseases. His past medical history is significant for controlled type II Diabetes Mellitus for the past seven years  managed with Metformin and lifestyle modifications. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol rarely. He has no known allergies.
