However  given the absence of atherosclerotic risk factors  an emergent cardiac angiography was performed which revealed patent coronary arteries without any blockages. The presence of apical ballooning of her left ventricle on ventriculography led to the suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM).  Treatment: Ms. A was immediately admitted to the ICU where she was given supportive care  including angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  beta-blockers  and diuretics. She was counseled about stress management and referred to a psychologist for further aid in this area.  Progress & Follow-Up: After a hospital stay of five days  the patient's symptoms completely resolved  and she was discharged with prescriptions for continuing her antihypertensive therapy and newly-prescribed medications. She was asked to follow up at a cardiology outpatient clinic.  On her first follow-up after one month  ECG and echocardiography revealed complete resolution of the ST-segment elevation and apical ballooning  conforming to the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Four months following the event  Ms. A was doing well without any recurrence of symptoms and had made progress in managing her emotional stress.  This case underscores the relationship between emotional stress and takotsubo cardiomyopathy  emphasizing the importance of identifying and managing emotional triggers in susceptible individuals.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Information:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female. She resides in Leicester  England  where she has lived for the majority of her life. She is a retired schoolteacher and currently lives alone. She is a non-smoker and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. Her medical history includes hypothyroidism and hypertension  both of which are well-controlled with medication. She has no known allergies.  Clinical Presentation:  The patient presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain  dyspnea  and a feeling of impending doom  symptoms that indicate a potential myocardial infarction. The patient described the onset of symptoms as sudden and intense. Further discussion revealed that she experienced a significant emotional stress event: the unexpected death of her son three days prior to admission.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Initial electrocardiogram (ECG) indicated ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Blood tests showed a mildly increased troponin level but were inconclusive for a definitive myocardial infarction. An echocardiogram demonstrated a significant mid and apical segment hypokinesis with basal hyperkinesis  producing a classic ""octopus pot"" appearance  suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. These findings were subsequently confirmed with a coronary angiogram  which revealed no evidence of obstructive coronary artery disease but confirmed the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TTC).  Therapeutic Intervention:  Immediate therapy included supportive care with oxygen  low-dose aspirin  and nitroglycerin. Post-diagnosis  the patient was closely monitored  and her symptoms were managed with heart failure medications  including beta-blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  and diuretics. As TTC is often a reaction to severe stress  the patient was also offered counselling and stress management strategies to assist with her emotional well-being.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient responded well to treatment and showed gradually improved cardiac function over the course of several weeks. Follow-up echocardiograms showed resolution of previously noted wall motion abnormalities  and she was symptom-free at the time of discharge. Long-term monitoring and patient education regarding symptom recognition and stress management were planned as part of her continuing care.  Patient Perspective:  The patient expressed relief upon learning that she had not suffered a heart attack  but she was surprised to comprehend the physical impact of severe emotional stress. The incident significantly increased her interest in stress management and mental health support.  Conclusions:  This case highlights the importance of considering takotsubo cardiomyopathy as a differential diagnosis in individuals presenting with chest pain and emotional stress. Appropriate management requires a comprehensive approach involving not only medical treatment but also psychological support. It underscores the role of a stressful event in precipitating takotsubo cardiomyopathy  the importance of early recognition  and the necessity of targeted treatment protocols based on the unique pathology of this condition.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Postmenopausal Female Patient  Patient Information  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female who presented to the Emergency Department. She is a lifetime non-smoker and exercises regularly. Her family history is significant for hypertension and cardiovascular diseases  but she has no pre-existing personal history of cardiac disorders. The patient lives alone and has reported experiencing long-term stress due to considerable personal and financial worries.   Clinical Findings  She presented with acute onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath  symptoms suggestive of acute myocardial infarction (AMI). However  she also reported unexpected stress she had encountered earlier in the day.  Diagnostic Assessment  An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST segment elevation in the anterolateral leads  a sign typical of AMI. Initial laboratory tests  including complete blood count  electrolytes  and kidney function  were within normal ranges. However  her troponin I levels were elevated (0.76 ng/ml).   A coronary angiogram was conducted to assess for possible coronary artery disease. Interestingly  the angiogram revealed normal coronary arteries  which is inconsistent with the clinical suspicion of AMI. A subsequent transthoracic echocardiogram showed abnormal motion of the left ventricular wall  along with reduced ejection fraction (45%). Moreover  the characteristic apical ballooning shape  resembling a Japanese octopus trap (Takotsubo)  was observed. These findings  in combination with her elevated stress levels  led to a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM).   Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was initiated on beta-blocker therapy (metoprolol)  along with ACE inhibitors (lisinopril) to manage her heart failure symptoms. She also received aspirin and statins for secondary prevention of any potential cardiovascular event. Psychological counselling was recommended to help her cope with chronic stress.   Follow-up and Outcomes  She remained in the hospital for monitoring for a week. Her symptoms started improving by Day 3. Repeat echocardiogram at six-weeks follow-up showed complete recovery of left ventricular function  suggesting typical course of TCM. She also reported better management of stress after attending regular counselling.  Discussion  This case highlights that TCM  often mimicking AMI  can occur even in the absence of significant cardiac history. It is important to note that TCM is mostly seen post-menopause in women  and often an emotional or physical stressor can be identified. In this case  chronic stress appears to have led to her presentation. Early diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial in ensuring recovery from this reversible cardiomyopathy.   Patient Perspective  The patient reported that she was startled by the severe chest pain. However  it was comforting to know her heart disease was reversible  and was satisfied with her care management. She emphasized the psychological component of her disease and shared her commitment to focus on stress management.  Informed Consent:  Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 65-year-old Female: A Case Report  Introduction: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome  is a transient left ventricular dysfunction often precipitated by severe physical or emotional stress. This cardiomyopathy typically mimics acute myocardial infarction  presenting with chest pain and changes in the electrocardiogram.  Patient Information: We report on a 65-year-old Caucasian female who presented to the emergency room with severe chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient resides in a suburban community in Dallas  Texas  and is retired. She lives with her husband  has three grown children  and owns two pets. She is a non-smoker and occasionally drinks alcohol.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient appeared acutely distressed with cold and clammy skin. Her vitals revealed a blood pressure of 120/90 mmHg  pulse 107 bpm  respirations 28 per minute  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air.  Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history of hyperlipidemia and osteoarthritis. She had no previous history of cardiovascular diseases or strokes. Her medication regimen includes statins for her hyperlipidemia and occasional NSAIDs for joint pain.  Diagnostic Assessment: Complete blood count  metabolic panel  and cardiac biomarkers were obtained. Our patient had a slight elevation in cardiac troponin levels  raising suspicions of an acute coronary syndrome. An urgent electrocardiogram displayed prolonged QT interval and ST-segment elevation. However  coronary angiography ruled out significant coronary artery disease. The transthoracic echocardiography revealed a reduced left ventricular ejection fraction with characteristic apical ballooning.   Therapeutic Intervention: Treatment was supportive concerning her symptoms and clinical findings. The patient received standard heart failure medications  including beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and diuretics.   Follow-up and Outcome: On a follow-up examination after two months  repeat echocardiography showed a complete recovery of left ventricular function  thus confirming the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Patient Perspective: The patient reported a high level of stress due to the recent loss of her mother  which likely triggered her Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Since her recovery  she has been working with a therapist to manage her stress and grief.  Conclusion: This case highlights the crucial role of careful diagnostic evaluation in ruling out more common causes of acute chest pain. Clinicians should be aware of conditions like Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  particularly in post-menopausal women with recent severe emotional or physical stress. Timely intervention and supportive care play a significant role in the patient's recovery and prognosis.

Patient Information  Demographics: 58-year-old Caucasian female  Presenting concerns: The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of intense chest pain and shortness of breath that started a few hours earlier. She was experiencing severe emotional stress due to her husband's recent untimely death.  Medical history: The patient reported no significant past medical history. She was a non-smoker and led an active lifestyle with regular exercise.  Diagnostic focus and assessment:  On physical examination  she appeared anxious and showed signs of respiratory distress. She had elevated blood pressure with 155/85 mmHg and a heart rate of 100 bpm. Her electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  initially leading us to suspect an acute myocardial infarction. However  the patient's subsequent troponin levels  although raised  were not consistent with the significant ST-segment changes noted on the ECG  raising suspicion for a different diagnosis. A transthoracic echocardiogram was subsequently performed  which showed apical ballooning with preserved function of the basal segments  a pattern characteristic of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Clinical Findings:  In addition to these findings  the patient's complete blood count  electrolytes  creatinine  and liver function tests were normal. Her fasting glucose and cholesterol were within normal levels  while thyroid function tests were borderline normal. The Coronary angiogram revealed no obstructive coronary disease ruling out a myocardial infarction.   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was initially managed as an acute coronary syndrome. She was started on aspirin  clopidogrel  and heparin. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and beta-blockers were added after the tentative diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Her symptoms and heart failure were managed with diuretics and meticulous fluid balance.   Follow-Up and Outcomes:  Over the following days  her symptoms  ECG changes  and cardiac biomarkers markedly improved. She was discharged home after a week in the hospital. On a one-month follow-up appointment  echocardiography showed complete resolution of wall motion abnormalities consistent with a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. She was informed and counseled about the condition and its association with intense emotional stress.   Patient Perspective:  The patient was appreciative of the care received and expressed her commitment to managing emotional stress more effectively utilizing recommended therapy and counseling.  Informed Consent:  The patient gave informed consent for her anonymized information to be published in this case report.  Teaching Points:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy  is an important differential diagnosis in patients presenting with suspected acute coronary syndrome  particularly when the clinical presentation is atypical or the cardiac biomarker profile does not fit with the degree of ECG changes. The condition is often preceded by emotional or physical stress and primarily affects postmenopausal women. Although its exact mechanism is not clearly understood  takotsubo cardiomyopathy is reversible and typically carries a good prognosis if recognized and managed appropriately.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in an 58-year-old Female Patient  Patient Profile: Patient is a 58-year-old Asian female presenting with symptoms of acute chest pain and shortness of breath. Her BMI is 28.8 and she has no history of smoking or alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  Type 2 diabetes  but no known cardiac history. Her hypertension and diabetes have been well-managed with medication. She possesses no allergies  has no previous surgeries  and is generally in good health. She follows a balanced diet  exercises regularly  but has a stressful job as a senior manager in a corporate firm.   Family History: The patient's father had hypertension and her mother had Type 2 diabetes. There is no known hereditary cardiac illness in her immediate family.    Presenting Symptoms: Patient initially visited the outpatient department with complaints of acute chest pain  dyspnea  nausea  and anxiety. She reported the pain radiated towards the left arm  replicating symptoms similar to a myocardial infarction. She also showed signs of mild tachycardia.  Diagnostic Assessment: Electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrated ST-segment elevation  indicative of potential acute coronary syndrome. However  cardiac biomarker levels were moderately elevated  twisted with the ECG findings. Subsequent coronary angiography revealed no significant occlusive disease to explain the ECG changes. An Echocardiogram showed a hyperdynamic left ventricle with apical ballooning and preserved basal function  indicative of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (also known as broken heart syndrome  or stress cardiomyopathy).   Treatment: Given the confirmation of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  the patient was initially managed with beta-blocker therapy (Carvedilol)  Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  and supportive measures to reduce her stress levels. Encouragingly  she responded well to medication and was stable throughout her hospital stay. Psychotherapy sessions were also initiated to help the patient deal with her workplace stress.  Follow-up and Prognosis: The patient was discharged home in a stable condition after a week  with advice on maintaining good glycemic control  strict control of blood pressure  continuation of medication as prescribed  and stress management. Periodic echocardiography and therapeutic guidance on lifestyle changes and stress management were recommended. At a 3-month follow-up  the patient’s symptoms had improved significantly and her repeat echocardiography showed a complete reversal of the initial abnormality  confirming the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of considering takotsubo cardiomyopathy in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with chest pain  particularly when the ECG changes and symptoms mimic a myocardial infarction  but there's no corroborative angiographic evidence of coronary artery disease. Besides  it highlights the role of stress management in patients who demonstrate a strong correlation between their symptoms and underlying emotional or psychological stress.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy   Patient Information:  Ms. X  a 73-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department with chest pain and breathlessness. The patient is a retired teacher  lives alone and is a non-smoker. She has a known history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  both controlled by medication. She has no family history of cardiac diseases. She was previously diagnosed with anxiety disorder and has been under antidepressant treatment for many years.  Recent History:  Just two days prior to the presentation  the patient's pet dog  a companion of 11 years  had died. She mentioned that she had been extremely stressed and emotionally distressed since then.  Clinical Findings:  Her vitals upon admission were as follows: Blood pressure of 165/95 mm Hg  Heart rate of 110 beats per minute (regular)  Respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  Oxygen saturation of 92% on room air and Temperature of 98.6°F. Cardiac auscultation revealed a systolic murmur and no added sounds.  Preliminary Investigations:  ECG suggested ST-elevation in the precordial leads. Troponin levels were raised at 2.1 ng/ml (reference: <0.04 ng/ml).   Hospital Course:  Due to ECG changes and elevated Troponin levels  an acute coronary syndrome was suspected. The patient was initiated on aspirin  nitroglycerin  and a statin. A transthoracic echocardiogram and coronary angiogram were performed subsequently.  Investigation reports:  The coronary angiogram was normal ruling out coronary artery disease. Her echocardiogram  however  showed apical ballooning with basal hypercontractility consistent with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The EF was estimated to be 35% (reference: 55-70%).   Diagnosis:  Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (Broken heart syndrome)  Therapeutic Intervention:  She was initiated on therapy with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  beta-blockers and diuretics. Her emotional stress was managed with the help of a psychiatric consultation and additional supportive therapy.  Outcome:  The patient responded well to treatment  showing improvement in her symptoms. She was discharged with advice to continue medication  engage in regular physical activity  perform stress management  and to attend regular follow-ups.   Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of considering Takotsubo cardiomyopathy in the differential diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome  especially in postmenopausal women with a recent history of intense emotional stress. It also emphasizes the significance of good mental health in maintaining physical health at any age.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 65-Year-Old Female Following Emotional Stress  Abstract: This report describes the case of a 65-year-old Caucasian female diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy after experiencing severe emotional stress.  Case Presentation:   The patient presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with complaints of severe chest pain radiating to her left arm along with episodes of fatigue and faintness. The onset of these symptoms followed shortly after hearing about the sudden death of her elder sister  with whom she was very close. She holds a master's degree in education  is a retired schoolteacher  and a widow with two adult children. Her lifestyle can be regarded as sedentary  without any history of smoking  alcohol  or substance misuse.  Past Medical History:   Her past medical history includes hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  controlled using a daily dosage of 5mg amlodipine besilate  with regular follow-up assessments showing satisfactory management. She does not have any known allergies but does have a family history of cardiovascular disease; her father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 72.  Clinical Findings:   On initial examination in the ED  the patient was alert and oriented but appeared visibly distressed. Vital signs demonstrated a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  a pulse of 105 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute  and a temperature of 98.6F. Physical examination revealed a 3/6 systolic murmur on the left sternal border. No other abnormalities were discerned.  Diagnostic Assessment:  The ECG done at the ED revealed ST-segment elevation in the anterior and inferior leads suggesting acute coronary syndrome. However  her Troponin levels were mildly elevated  inconsistent with the severe ECG changes. A transthoracic echocardiogram showed apical ballooning of the left ventricle with hyperkinesis of the basal walls consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Left heart catheterization illustrated no coronary arterial occlusion  further confirming the diagnosis.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was admitted to the cardiac care unit and started on beta-blockers  an ACE inhibitor  and a statin. Gradually  her symptomatology improved  and she was discharged home in stable condition after 5 days. During outpatient follow up after 6 weeks  the patient remained asymptomatic  and repeat echocardiography showed resolution of the wall motion abnormalities  indicating recovery from the episode.  Conclusions:  This case highlights that emotional stressors can trigger takotsubo cardiomyopathy in postmenopausal women  especially those with hypertension. Awareness of this condition among clinicians is essential to ensure timely and appropriate management  which ultimately results in excellent prognosis.

Title: A Case Report on Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 67-year-old Caucasian Female  Patient Information:   The patient  Ms. A  is a 67-year-old Caucasian female living in suburban Georgia. She is relatively healthy  with regular visits to her general practitioner for routine check-ups  and no significant past medical history. She is a retired schoolteacher living alone  never smoked  and occasionally drinks alcohol. Her BMI is within the normal range and she lives quite an active lifestyle. She has no family history of heart diseases.  Presenting to Healthcare System:   Ms. A presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain after an emotionally charged incident. The pain  described as central and crushing in character  was associated with shortness of breath  nausea and light-headedness  and began suddenly after she received news of her only son's death in a car accident.  Clinical Findings:   On examination  she was anxious  her blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate was 100 per minute  and her respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute. Cardiac auscultation revealed no heart murmurs and her lung fields were clear. Her ECG showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  An immediate troponin T test was positive  indicating myocardial injury. An echocardiogram showed left ventricular apical ballooning with preserved basal function  leading to the suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Coronary angiography confirmed the absence of significant coronary artery disease  which supported the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   Therapeutic Intervention:  She was commenced on beta-blockers to manage her blood pressure  alongside aspirin  a statin  and a medication to reduce the risk of blood clots. She was also provided with eplerenone  an aldosterone antagonist  and was kept under careful observation.  Follow-up and Outcomes:   Following this treatment  Ms. A’s chest pain subsided  and her symptoms improved. Over a period of 4-6 weeks  repeat echocardiography indicated the normalization of her left ventricular function. She was discharged with instructions to continue medication and was scheduled for regular follow-ups.  Clinical Lessons from the Case:  This case underlines the importance of considering takotsubo cardiomyopathy as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with ST-segment elevation  particularly postmenopausal women confronted with sudden emotional stress. While the exact cause of takotsubo cardiomyopathy is unknown  it is often triggered by severe stress. It is crucial to note that despite similar clinical presentation  management and prognosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy significantly differ from that of a typical myocardial infarction.

Patient Information: • Initials: M.K. • Age: 72 • Gender: Female • Ethnicity: Caucasian • Occupation: Retired Teacher  Case Presentation: M.K.  a 72-year-old Caucasian female patient  presented to the emergency department (ED) with acute chest pain. The pain started suddenly  central and intense  without any identifiable triggering factor. The patient reported that the chest pain felt like a 'tight band' across her chest. The pain was unrelieved by rest and nitroglycerine. She complained of associated shortness of breath. There were no other associated symptoms like nausea  vomiting  or palpitations.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension for the past 10 years and is on regular medication (Losartan 50 mg/day). She is post-menopausal and has a past surgical history of total abdominal hysterectomy 15 years ago for uterine fibroids. M.K. does not have a history of heart disease  does not smoke  or use alcohol excessively  and maintains a fairly active lifestyle for her age.  Physical Examination & Diagnostic Findings: Upon examination in the ED  MK was anxious and diaphoretic. Her blood pressure was 160/95 mmHg  heart rate 100 bpm  and respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute. The cardiovascular examination revealed normal S1 and S2 without any additional heart sounds or murmurs. The results of the rest of the physical examination were unremarkable. Her initial ECG showed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads V2-6  suggesting an acute myocardial infarction (MI).   However  coronary angiography  performed suspecting an acute coronary syndrome  showed no significant coronary artery disease to explain the patient’s pain and ECG alterations. The left ventriculography showed typical apical ballooning with basal hypercontractility  suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. This was further substantiated by a raised troponin I level of 4.5 ng/ml (normal range 0 - 0.4 ng/ml) and a slightly increased pro-BNP of 600 pg/ml (normal range 0 - 100pg/ml).  Treatment & Outcome: Considering the diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TTC)  the patient received supportive treatment  including aspirin  beta-blockers  and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. She reported significant relief from the chest pain and was stable over the next few days. Repeat echocardiography after two weeks showed complete resolution of wall motion abnormalities  which is consistent with TTC.   This case report underscores the importance of recognizing TTC as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with chest pain  especially in post-menopausal women. It highlights the importance of timely diagnosis and treatment  which generally result in good clinical outcome in these patients.

Patient Information:  Ms. X is a 72-year-old Caucasian female who arrived at the Emergency Department (ED) with shortness of breath  chest pain and discomfort. She reported that the symptoms started abruptly after she heard about the unexpected death of her brother.   Medical History:  The patient's past medical history was significant including hypertension  hyperlipidemia and osteoarthritis. She had no known history of coronary artery disease or any other heart-related conditions. Her medications included Amlodipine 5mg daily  Atorvastatin 20mg at bed time and Ibuprofen 400mg as needed for pain. She was a non-smoker and consumed alcohol moderately. Up to the event  Ms. X had been living independently and was in her usual state of physical health.  Evaluation:  On examination  she appeared in acute distress. Her vital signs: BP 150/95mmHg  heart rate was 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  temperature of 98.8 F and oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. Cardiac examination revealed no murmur or gallops. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable. Her EKG showed ST segment elevation in the anterior leads. Initial laboratory results were significant for Troponin-I level of 0.9 ng/mL (normal <0.04 ng/mL) and a B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) of 800 pg/mL (normal <100 pg/mL).  Treatment:  She was immediately started on aspirin  nitroglycerin  and heparin and moved to the Coronary Care Unit (CCU) with the suspicion of anterior wall myocardial infarction. Emergent cardiac catheterization however revealed normal coronary arteries. On left ventriculogram  the characteristic finding of apical ballooning with preserved basal function was observed  which confirmed the clinical suspicion of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as Stress Cardiomyopathy or Broken Heart Syndrome).  Outcome:  Ms. X received supportive therapy including beta blockers and ACE inhibitors. Her chest pain resolved over the next 48 hours. Repeat echocardiogram done a week later showed near normalization of left ventricular function. She was subsequently discharged with a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Conclusion:  This case represents a classic example of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  a condition often triggered by significant emotional stress. This condition often mimics myocardial infarction and should be considered in the differential diagnosis in appropriate settings. Importantly  with supportive management and elimination of inciting stressors  prognosis is generally favorable with full recovery of cardiac function in the majority of patients.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Postmenopausal Woman: A Case Report   Case Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female  with a medical history significant for hypertension  mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  and hyperlipidemia. She is neither a smoker nor has a family history of early-onset heart disease. She was presenting to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset chest pain and difficulty in breathing. The pain was described as central  intense  and radiating to the left arm.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient was afebrile with irregular heartbeats and elevated blood pressure of 155/90 mmHg. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in leads V2-V4  quite similar to that seen in acute myocardial infarction. No other significant abnormal findings were noted during examination.  Timeline:  The patient's symptoms appeared abruptly whilst she was attending her grandson’s wedding. The onset was not associated with physical exertion. She mentioned extreme emotional distress during the event due to a significant dispute. The symptoms had lasted approximately 3 hours before she arrived at the emergency department.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Initial assessment  based on symptoms and ECG  pointed towards acute myocardial infarction. However  biochemical markers demonstrated a slight increase in troponin I level  incongruous with typical myocardial infarction levels. Computed Tomography (CT) coronary angiography was therefore undertaken and interestingly  revealed no significant obstructive coronary disease.  An urgent transthoracic echocardiogram showed reduced left ventricular function with apical ballooning and basal hypercontractility  which is characteristic of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM).  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was managed with conservative measures  including angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  beta-blockers  and statins  which she tolerated well.  Follow-up and outcomes:  Follow-up echocardiogram was performed after 6 weeks  which demonstrated complete normalization of the left ventricular function  confirming the diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy retrospectively. She remained asymptomatic and continued to be on statins and ACE inhibitors for her hypertension.  Conclusion:  The case highlights the importance of understanding and recognizing TCM  which can mimic myocardial infarction. This report also underlines the potential role of emotional triggers in the development of TCM  especially in postmenopausal women with a history of hypertension. Careful diagnostic evaluation is critical in such patients to avoid unnecessary invasive procedures and to conduct appropriate management.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Post-Menopausal Woman Following a Severe Emotional Event - A Case Report  Case Report:  Patient Information:  A 66 year-old Caucasian woman with no known previous medical history presented to the ER with severe chest pain and palpitations. She was recently widowed  losing her husband of 45 years a month ago  and reported substantial emotional stress and depression since his death.  Clinical Findings:  At her arrival  she was hypertensive with blood pressure measuring 155/90 mmHg  and tachycardic with pulse rate of 110 beats per minute. EKG showed ST segment elevation in the precordial leads suggestive of anterior wall myocardial infarction. Auscultation revealed no abnormal heart sounds or murmurs.   Diagnostic Assessment: Her initial laboratory workup was significant for elevated troponin levels to 1.2 ng/mL and Brain Natriuretic Peptide(BNP) of 950 pg/ml. Transthoracic echocardiogram depicted the characteristic apical ballooning with hypercontractile basal segments. Left ventricular ejection fraction was evaluated to be approximately 35%. Coronary angiogram did not demonstrate any significant coronary artery disease.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was initially treated with aspirin  nitroglycerin and beta blockers for suspected myocardial infarction. Once takotsubo cardiomyopathy was identified  she was continued on the beta blocker (metoprolol) and an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (enalapril) was added. She was also provided psychological counselling and prescribed an antidepressant (escitalopram) due to severe emotional trauma and depression.   Follow-Up & Outcome: Consecutive echocardiograms over the next four weeks showed progressive resolution of left ventricular function with ejection fraction returning to normal. The antidepressant treatment was effective in reducing her depressive symptoms. During her 6 month follow-up  she reported significant improvement in her wellbeing and her EKG  echocardiogram and lab results (including troponin and BNP levels) were all within the normal range.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed gratitude towards the medical team for the precise diagnosis and treatment. She also emphasized the role of psychological assistance  stating it was indispensable for her recovery.  Conclusion: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy  is a condition that may mimic acute coronary syndrome. This case emphasizes the importance of considering takotsubo cardiomyopathy in the differential diagnosis when encountering patients  particularly post-menopausal women presenting with chest pain after a recent emotional event  even in absence of prior cardiac history. An optimal therapeutic approach seems to be a combination of medical therapy and psychological support.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 68-year-old Caucasian Female  Case Report:  Patient Information:   A 68-year-old Caucasian female  known as Mrs. A  presented to the emergency department at our medical facility. She is a retired school teacher  nondrinker  nonsmoker with a body mass index of 26 kg/m^2. She lives with her husband in rural Maine.   History of Present Illness:  The patient reported acute onset of severe chest pain that started two hours prior to arrival at our centre. The pain was retrosternal  severe  and crushing in nature leading to shortness of breath. It occurred spontaneously during rest at home and was not linked to any physical exertion. The patient reported significant mental stress in relation to a recent traumatic event in her life – the unexpected demise of her only son  which occurred two weeks prior to the presentation.  Past Medical and Family History:  Mrs. A's past medical history is notable for hypertension  which is well controlled on a low-dose Diuretic (Hydrochlorothiazide). She denied any history of diabetes  dyslipidemia  renal diseases  pulmonary diseases  or any significant family history of cardiovascular events.   Clinical Findings:  On admission  Mrs. A was conscious  oriented and showed signs of palpable distress. Vital signs recorded an elevated blood pressure of 170/90mmHg  pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 22 per minute and oxygen saturation was 94% on ambient air. Physical examination revealed no abnormalities  apart from an elevated jugular venous pressure.   Diagnostic Assessments:  Electrocardiogram revealed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. However  the patient's initial troponin I level was mildly elevated at 0.10ng/mL  an unexpected finding for an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). An emergent coronary angiogram revealed no significant coronary artery disease. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) demonstrated significant hypokinesis of the mid to apical segments of the left ventricle  along with preserved basal function  favoring a diagnosis of Takotsubo (stress) cardiomyopathy. These findings were reconfirmed by a subsequent cardiac MRI.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Appropriate medical therapy for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy was initiated  including Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  beta-blockers and anxiolytics. Individualized counseling was offered to help her cope with her bereavement.  Follow-up:  During her follow-up at our outpatient clinic four weeks later  Mrs. A reported resolution of her chest discomfort and was asymptomatic at baseline. Repeat echocardiography revealed full recovery of the left ventricular function.  Conclusion:  This case illustrates the typical clinical presentation of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy seen in post-menopausal women experiencing emotional stress. It emphasizes the important role of detailed diagnostic investigations in distinguishing this condition from acute coronary syndrome. The patient made a full recovery with standard heart failure treatment and psychological support.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mrs. B (Patient's identity protected) Sex: Female Age: 65 years Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher  Summary:  Mrs. B  a 65-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency department with acute chest pain. The pain was described as crushing in nature  and it radiated to the left arm. There was associated shortness of breath  dizziness  and profuse sweating. Mrs. B stated that these symptoms developed suddenly while she was attending her husband's funeral.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. B had been previously diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She was on Metformin 500mg twice daily  Lisinopril 10mg once daily  and Amlodipine 5mg once daily. There were no known allergies to medication. Her medications were up-to-date  and she had been compliant with her treatment regimen. She'd never smoked nor consumed alcohol in her lifestyle.  Emergency Room Assessment:  On initial assessment  Mrs. B appeared anxious  she was diaphoretic  and her skin was relatively cold and clammy. She had elevated blood pressure (160/90 mmHg) and an increased heart rate (110 bpm). Her oxygen saturation was acceptable (96% on room air).  Investigations & Findings:  An ECG showed ST-segment elevation in the anteroseptal leads  which suggested a possible acute myocardial infarction. Serum troponin I levels were raised. She immediately underwent angiography  which did not show any significant blockage that might cause a heart attack. Ultrasound of the heart (Echocardiogram) showed apical balooning with a hyperdynamic base of the heart  a feature characteristic of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM).  Diagnosis:  Based on the presenting symptoms  investigative findings  and especially the emotional stressor - her husband's death  Mrs. B was diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome"".  Treatment and Outcome:  Mrs. B was managed conservatively in the coronary care unit with continued monitoring. She was treated with heart failure medications including Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  Beta blockers  Diuretics  and Anticoagulants to prevent blood clotting. Her chest pain and ST-segment elevations resolved over the next few days. In follow-up echocardiography taken eight weeks after the initial event  Mrs. B's heart function was found to have returned to normal with an efficient ejection fraction.  Discussion:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is a relatively rare  acute heart condition  often triggered by severe emotional stress. The condition is more common in post-menopausal women. Although the long-term prognosis is generally good with most patients making a full recovery  acute management in a hospital setting is often needed due to the severity of the initial symptoms which may mimic a heart attack.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy Following A Severe Psychological Trauma: A Case Report  Patient Information: A 62-year-old Caucasian female  Chief Complaint: Chest pain and shortness of breath starting a few hours earlier  Medical History: The patient has a history of anxiety and depression but without any known cardiovascular diseases. She has no past history of smoking or illicit drug usage  minimal alcohol usage  and no known family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Current Medication: Escitalopram (a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor) for depression and lorazepam as needed for anxiety.   Recent events: The development of chest pain and shortness of breath occurred a few hours after learning of her son's sudden death.  Clinical Findings: Upon presentation to the Emergency Department  she was notably anxious  pale  and diaphoretic. Initial vital signs showed blood pressure of 140/95 mmHg  pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 28 per minute  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Chest auscultation revealed tachycardia  but no murmurs  gallops  or rubs. Lungs were clear to auscultation without crackles or wheezes.  Diagnostic Assessment: The electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. Serum Troponin I levels were notably elevated. An urgent coronary angiogram did not show any significant coronary artery disease that would precipitate the presentation. Transthoracic echocardiography showed left ventricular apical ballooning with preserved basal function  a characteristic appearance of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for monitoring and treatment. She was started on dual antiplatelet therapy with Aspirin and Clopidogrel  beta-blockers  and ACE inhibitors. The patient remained hemodynamically stable throughout her hospital stay.  Follow-up and Outcomes: On follow-up after one month  the patient reported substantial improvement in symptoms. A repeat echocardiogram showed normalization of the left ventricular function.  Clinical Discussion: This case represents a classic presentation of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (or ""Broken Heart Syndrome"") following severe emotional stress. This condition is typically precipitated by intense emotional or physical stress  leading to transient left ventricular dysfunction. This case highlights the importance of considering Takotsubo cardiomyopathy as part of the differential in patients presenting with chest pain and ST-segment elevation in the context of severe emotional stress.  Patient's Perspective: The patient expressed gratitude for the care she received and is in the process of seeking grief counseling to help cope with her son's death.  Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.  Keywords: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Chest Pain  Anxiety  Stress  Cardiology.

Case Report:  A 60-year-old Caucasian Female with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy Following the Loss of Her Son  Patient Information: A 60-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department with symptoms suggestive of a heart attack including sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to her left arm  shortness of breath  and extreme fatigue. She was recently bereaved following the loss of her only son in a car accident two weeks ago.   Medical History: Mrs. X has a past medical history significant for hypertension controlled with amlodipine  hypothyroidism managed with thyroxine  and chronic back pain. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. There is no family history of cardiac disease.  Investigations and Diagnosis: On presentation  her blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior wall  and blood tests revealed a mildly increased troponin level.   An emergency coronary angiogram was performed that did not reveal significant coronary artery stenosis typically present in myocardial infarctions. Left ventriculogram  however  showed apical ballooning with a preserved basal function - a pattern indicative of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TCM) or broken heart syndrome.  Considering the presenting symptoms  the event of recent severe stress (death of her son)  and the characteristic diagnostic findings confirm the diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.  Treatment: The patient was treated conservatively with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  β-blockers and was provided psychological support for her grief. She was monitored closely in the cardiac care unit for arrhythmias  heart failure  or thrombus formation  which are common complications in the acute phase of TCM.   Outcome and Follow-Up: The patient responded well to therapy. Follow-up echocardiography after two months showed complete resolution of the ventricular dysfunction. At six months follow-up  Mrs. X was considerably better and displayed no signs of chest discomfort  fatigue  or breathlessness.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of considering Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in patients presenting with acute chest pain and relevant triggers  especially in postmenopausal women. Despite a presentation similar to a heart attack  the absence of coronary artery blockage and the presence of apical ballooning are characteristic findings. Though TCM is often triggered by severe emotional stress  it is ordinarily transient and reversible with appropriate management.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 56-year-old Female After an Emotional Triggering Event  Patient Demographics The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian female  employed as a financial manager and neither a smoker nor an alcohol drinker. She is a widow with two grown-up children.  Presenting Complaints The patient presented to the ER with severe central chest pain radiating to her left arm and neck  associated with shortness of breath  nausea  sweating  and a feeling of impending doom.   Medical History The patient had a past medical history of hypertension  diagnosed three years ago  for which she took Amlodipine 10mg daily. There was no past history of ischemic heart disease  diabetes mellitus  dyslipidemia  or any psychiatric disorders. The patient did not have any known allergies.  Recent Events and Triggers The patient recently lost her husband from a sudden cardiac event  and the anniversary of his death had occurred earlier in the week  causing intense emotional distress.  Clinical Findings On examination  the patient was anxious and perspiring with a heart rate of 110 bpm  blood pressure of 150/100mm/Hg  respiration rate of 18 breaths per min  and oxygen saturation was 94% at room air. 12 lead ECG showed ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  AVF  V4-V6.  Investigations and Results Lab reports showed normal complete blood count  renal function  and electrolytes. Cardiac troponin I levels were elevated (1.0ng/mL  normal: <0.04ng/mL). Lipid profile was within normal limits. A chest X-ray was normal. Transthoracic echocardiogram revealed impaired left ventricular function with apical ballooning and basal hyperkinesis  suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Coronary angiography showed normal coronary arteries  ruling out acute coronary syndrome.  Treatment She was admitted to the cardiac care unit and treated with aspirin  bisoprolol  ACE inhibitors  and supportive care. She was referred to a grief counseling service to address the emotional triggers of her condition.  Outcome and Follow-Up The patient was discharged home after seven days of hospital stay with a significant resolution of symptoms  and she was put on regular follow-up. At a three-month follow-up  she reported minimal symptoms and repeat echocardiogram showed a significant improvement in left ventricular function.  Learning Point This case underlines that stressful emotional events can lead to Takotsubo cardiomyopathy even in the absence of prior ischemic heart disease. Timely intervention  both medical and psychological  can lead to a good prognosis.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy Following Emotional Stress in Elderly Female: A Case Report  1. Patient Information  Mrs. A is an 80-year-old Caucasian female  retired schoolteacher  non-smoker  from a non-alcoholic background. She is widowed with two children and lives alone. She has no known family history of heart diseases. She was actively involved in community service and yoga.   2. Clinical Findings   Mrs. A reported to the emergency department with severe chest pain and shortness of breath following the sudden tragic death of her only grandson in a road accident. On examination  she was pale  mildly diaphoretic with a heart rate of 110 beats/min and blood pressure measurement of 150/80 mm Hg. She had no prior history of heart disease or hypertension. The cardiovascular examination revealed no murmurs  rubs or gallops and the lungs were clear on auscultation.  3. Timeline  The symptoms started suddenly within 2 hours following the traumatic news. On examination  she had signs suggestive of acute coronary syndrome. A 12-lead electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior and lateral leads. High-sensitivity troponin-I levels were elevated  which made the clinical picture suspicious of an acute myocardial infarction.   4. Diagnostic Focus and Assessment  The patient was immediately sent for emergent coronary angiography which surprisingly showed no significant documented arteriosclerotic changes or obstruction. A bedside transthoracic echocardiography revealed left ventricular apical ballooning with hypercontractility at the base of heart  a characteristic of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as broken heart syndrome). Given the patient's presentation  the clinical diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy was made.  5. Therapeutic Focus and Assessment  The initial acute management was a standard treatment for acute coronary syndrome  including aspirin  clopidogrel  and heparin. Once the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy was suspected based on the angiogram and confirmed by the echo  the heparin was discontinued. The patient was admitted to the coronary care unit and treated with supportive care  including beta-blockers and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors.   6. Follow-up and Outcomes  The patient's chest pain and shortness of breath significantly improved over the following days. A repeat echocardiogram performed seven days later showed complete resolution of the left ventricular dysfunction. The patient was discharged 10 days later on a regimen of Aspirin  beta-blocker  and ACE inhibitor. She underwent regular follow up for the next three months with echocardiogram showing normal left ventricular function and overall improvement in her health status.  7. Patient Perspective   “Losing my grandson was unimaginable for me. The heartache was so intense  I could feel it physically. Following my doctors' advice  I have now joined a bereavement group and continue to participate in community activities to keep myself engaged”  said Mrs. A.  8. Teaching Points   Takotsubo cardiomyopathy should be considered as a differential diagnosis in elderly females presenting with acute coronary syndrome  especially in contexts involving intense emotional stress. Confirmatory diagnosis is made by coronary angiography and echocardiography revealing characteristic apical ballooning. Timely recognition and management of this potentially reversible condition can lead to a good prognosis.

Title: Acute Stress-Induced (Takotsubo) Cardiomyopathy in an Elderly Female  Case Report:  Identification Information & Chief Complaint: The patient is an 82-year-old Caucasian female  retired school teacher  who presented to the emergency department complaining of acute onset of severe chest pain.  Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and depression  all of which are well-controlled with medication. She has been on atenolol  atorvastatin  and escitalopram for several years. The patient has no prior history of coronary artery disease  myocardial infarction  heart failure  or other cardiovascular diseases. She does not smoke but admits to moderate alcohol consumption. She has been living alone since her husband passed away 2 years ago.  Clinical Findings: Upon presentation  the patient was experiencing classic angina-like symptoms  including chest pain associated with shortness of breath. Physical examination revealed mild tachycardia and moderate hypertension. No heart murmurs  rubs  gallops  or arrhythmias were noted.  Diagnostic Assessment: Initial electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrated prominent T wave inversions in the precordial leads  suggesting acute coronary syndrome. However  coronary angiography revealed no significant blockages. Echocardiogram however showed apical ballooning of the left ventricle with hyperkinesis of the basal walls - features characteristic of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to the cardiac care unit for observation and management. Treatment was mainly supportive  including angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  beta-blockers  and diuretics to lessen cardiac load. She showed gradual improvement in symptoms and the scheduled follow-up echocardiograpy revealed resolution of the apical ballooning.  Discussion: The patient's symptoms  the absence of significant coronary artery disease on angiography along with the echocardiographic features  were consistent with a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM). TCM often presents with symptoms similar to acute coronary syndrome  particularly after a recent stressful event. In this case  the patient  living alone  might have been subjected to chronic emotional stress  possibly triggering TCM.  This case emphasizes the significance of understanding TCM as a differential diagnosis in elderly females presenting with chest pain  especially when other significant cardiac disease is absent. It also supports the necessity of treating TCM with a supportive approach  primarily focused on reducing cardiac work and reassessing with regular cardiac imaging.  Follow-Up: The patient has been advised to continue medical management for her hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and depression. She is scheduled to return for regular follow-ups and an ongoing evaluation of her cardiac status. As part of managing stress levels  the patient has also been recommended to engage in group therapy  yoga  or meditation  after discharge.

Title: A Case of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 66-year-old Female with a History of Depression  Patient Profile:  - Age: 66 - Sex: Female - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired teacher  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented to the Emergency Department with severe chest pain radiating to her left arm  shortness of breath  palpitations  sweating  and nausea. Symptoms began abruptly approximately two hours prior to her arrival.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a documented history of chronic depression for which she has been receiving psychotherapy and medication (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors - SSRI). The patient's other medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidaemia  which are well controlled with medication (ACE inhibitor and statin  respectively). The patient has never smoked and has no history of illicit drug use. She does not have any family history of cardiac diseases but has a family history of depression and suicide.  Assessment and Findings:  On physical examination  the patient appeared to be in obvious distress. She was conscious but visibly anxious and sweating profusely. Auscultation revealed normal heart sounds but also signs of slight pulmonary congestion. Her blood pressure was 165/95 mmHg  heart rate was 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute and the oxygen saturation level was 96% on room air.  Lab tests indicated raised cardiac enzymes levels  Troponin T - 0.223 ng/mL (reference range <0.01 ng/mL) and Creatine Kinase-MB - 45 U/L (reference range < 25 U/L). Electrocardiography (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior lead  mimicking an anterior wall myocardial infarction.  Diagnosis:  Given the patient's symptoms  medical history and initial test results  a presumptive diagnosis of Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI) was made  and she was moved to the Cardiac Care Unit for further evaluation.  A Coronary Angiography was performed to rule out Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  and surprisingly  no significant stenosis was observed. Meanwhile  an Echocardiogram showed severe hypokinesis of the apical segments with hyperkinesis of the basal segments - a pattern known as apical ballooning.  Considering the patient's recent history of emotional stress  the angiographic and echocardiographic findings  a final diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TCM) was made.  Treatment and Outcome:  The patient was started on beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors and was continued on her regular dose of SSRI for depression. She was under continuous monitorization in the intensification care unit. She received psychological support during her hospital stay  considering the importance of emotional factors in TCM.  Her clinical condition improved gradually over the next week  and she was discharged with advice on lifestyle modifications for controlling stress and hypertension. Close follow-ups were scheduled with Cardiology and Psychiatry for the effective management of TCM and depression.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of considering TCM in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with chest pain  particularly in postmenopausal women with recent emotional stress. The case also reinforces the importance of considering psychiatric comorbidities such as depression.   Patient consent was obtained for the write-up and publication of this case.

Title: A Case Report of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 67-year-old Female  Introduction: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome "" is a condition characterized by sudden temporary weakening of the heart muscles triggered by severe stress or emotional trauma. This case report presents a 67-year-old female with this syndrome.  Presenting complaints: A 67-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain that started suddenly after she received the news of the unexpected death of her close friend. She also reported shortness of breath.  History of Present Illness: The pain was intense  centered in the chest  lasting for about 2 hours. Associated symptoms included dyspnea  anxiety  and diaphoresis. She denied any associated nausea  vomiting or radiating discomfort.  Past Medical and Personal History: Her prior medical history revealed controlled hypertension managed on Losartan and no history of previous cardiac issues. Despite her age  she was quite active and had a history of occasional tobacco use but quit 15 years ago. She lived independently and had a history of mild depression  for which she was not taking any medication.  Clinical Findings: Initial examination showed that the patient was diaphoretic  had a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 105 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Cardiac examination revealed tachycardia with regular rhythm and no murmur  rub  or gallop were auscultated.  Investigations: Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V4  but the patient’s serum troponin level was normal. Further diagnostic testing included a coronary angiogram which revealed no evidence of a significant blockage in any coronary arteries  ruling out a conventional heart attack. However  the left ventriculogram showed apical ballooning  indicative of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Treatment: The patient was managed conservatively with beta-blockers (metoprolol)  ACE inhibitors  and was provided supportive care including reassurance  frequent monitoring  and psychological support.  Outcome and Follow-up: Her chest pain resolved within a few days  and she was discharged on beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors as standard therapy. On her follow-up appointment 2 months later  an echocardiogram showed complete resolution of left ventricular function  confirming the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. She reported feeling much better  with no recurrence of her chest pain or any other associated symptoms.  Learning Points: This case underscores the importance of considering takotsubo cardiomyopathy as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with severe chest pain  particularly following an emotional stressor. This syndrome is likely underdiagnosed as it mimics myocardial infarction  yet can be differentiated by specific EKG changes  the absence of obstructive coronary disease  and the presence of apical ballooning on ventriculography.

Patient Case Report  Patient Information:  Ms. X  65-year-old Caucasian female  retired school teacher  residing in Ontario  Canada. She presented to the local emergency department with central chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient is widowed and lives alone  she has two adult children who reside in different cities. She was previously active  smoked for 20 years  but quitted 15 years ago. There’s a family history of cardiovascular disease – her father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 69.  Past Medical History:  Ms. X reported that she has been managing hypertension and hypothyroidism for the past 5 years and has been generally compliant with prescribed medications – Metoprolol and Levothyroxine respectively. No past episodes of chest pain have been reported. Three weeks ago  she lost her younger brother to cancer which was a stressful life event.  Present Illness:  The patient’s symptoms started a few hours before presentation  the pain was described as intense and pressing  radiating to the left arm  associated with bouts of acute breathlessness. Electrocardiogram (EKG) indicated ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads suggesting an acute coronary syndrome.   Management:  She was immediately treated with dual antiplatelet therapy  statins  and nitroglycerin as per acute coronary syndrome protocol. Echocardiography was performed and showed hyperkinesis of the basal segments and akinesis of the mid to apical segments of the left ventricle  classic for takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Coronary angiogram revealed minimal coronary artery disease excluding the diagnosis of myocardial infarction. Cardiac biomarkers were slightly elevated.  Diagnosis:  Based on these findings  Ms. X was diagnosed with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy or broken-heart syndrome)  which is typically precipitated by acute severe emotional stress.   Treatment:  She was managed conservatively  and her chest pain symptoms resolved over the subsequent 48 hours. Repeat echocardiography after three weeks confirmed a complete recovery of the left ventricular function.  Prognosis:  She was educated about the condition and reassured about the generally benign nature of the condition with good prognosis and low recurrence rate. She was however advised to adopt stress-coping strategies to avoid a recurrence of similar episodes in the future. The patient agreed to lifestyle modifications and follow-up in the outpatient department for further monitoring and management of her hypertension.

Patient Information:   Ms. R  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  presented herself to the emergency department on August 5  2021.  Chief Complaint:   Complaints of sudden-onset chest pain and shortness of breath.  History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and type two diabetes mellitus  well controlled with proper medication for the past 12 years. She also suffered from informative breast cancer  for which she underwent surgical intervention in the form of a mastectomy five years ago  followed by a successful course of chemotherapy and radiotherapy. She is a non-smoker  with moderate alcohol consumption. Prior to her breast cancer  she was healthy and had an active lifestyle. She lives with her cat and has a strong social network with supportive friends and family.   Present Illness:  The patient reported waking up at night due to severe chest pain radiating to her left arm. Described the pain as a ""heavy pressure"". The chest pain was accompanied by shortness of breath  cold sweating  and palpitations. It started suddenly without any warning. The patient reported no known triggers but she has been under significant emotional stress  owing to her recent divorce.  She was immediately rushed to the hospital  arriving approximately 2 hours after symptom onset.   Physical Examination:  On physical examination  the patient appeared anxious and was in visible pain. Blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg  pulse rate 110 beats/min  respiratory rate 20 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation 95% on room air. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Investigations:  Blood tests showed elevated troponin level. ECG indicated ST elevation in precordial leads. Coronary angiography was performed which showed no significant stenosis or occlusion to suggest acute coronary syndrome.  Echocardiogram demonstrated apical ballooning and severely reduced left ventricular function  with an estimated ejection fraction of 30%. This  along with the patient's presentation and diagnostic findings  led to the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy or “broken heart syndrome.”  Treatment:  Patient was admitted to the cardiac intensive care unit where she was treated with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  β-blockers  and diuretics.   Outcome:  The patient responded well to medical management. Her symptoms significantly improved after 3 days and by the 7th day  a repeat echocardiogram showed significant recovery of left ventricular function with an ejection fraction of 55%.   The patient was discharged after two weeks with instruction to continue her medications and follow a routine outpatient check-up after one month.  Interpretation:  This case report underscores the importance of considering takotsubo cardiomyopathy as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with chest pain  especially in post-menopausal women and in the setting of recent emotional stress  despite the high prevalence of coronary artery disease in this population.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 70-Year-Old Woman Following Emotional Stress: A Case Report  Patient Information:  A 70-year-old Caucasian female was admitted to the emergency department (ED) of our hospital.  Chief Complaint: The patient presented to the ED complaining of sudden onset severe chest pain  similar in character to that of myocardial infarction.  Past Medical History: The patient had a history of hypertension and hyperthyroidism. She had no prior history of ischemic heart disease  arrhythmia  or drug allergies.  Recent Events: In the interview  it was noted that the patient experienced a severe emotional upset. She had just attended her husband's funeral the previous day  which was an extremely stressful event for her.  Clinical Findings: The initial physical examination revealed an anxious and diaphoretic woman with tachycardia  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  and slight respiratory difficulty. The 12-lead ECG showed ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  aVF  and V3-6  suggesting an acute coronary syndrome.   Diagnostic Assessment: Blood chemistry showed raised troponin levels. The subsequent coronary angiography revealed unobstructed coronary arteries  but the left ventriculogram displayed apical ballooning with preserved function at the base of the heart.   The presentation of symptoms following emotional stress  the ECG changes  elevated troponin levels  and characteristic imaging findings lead to a diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TTC)  a transient cardiac syndrome that mimics myocardial infarction.  Therapeutic Intervention: Treatment was supportive  with beta-blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  aspirin  and diuretics combined with close cardiac monitoring.  Follow Up and Outcomes: The patient's ECG abnormalities and cardiac symptoms improved greatly over six weeks. The follow-up echocardiogram showed complete normalization of the left ventricular function  confirming the diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of physicians being mindful of TTC as a potential differential diagnosis in patients presenting with chest pain  particularly when following emotional stress  despite ECG changes and biomarkers suggesting acute coronary syndrome.  Patient Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.  Conflicts of Interest: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

Title: An Uncommon Presentation of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 56-Year-Old Woman  Case Report  Patient Information: A 56-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department with severe retrosternal chest discomfort. The pain started suddenly while she was performing her daily chores. Pain radiated to the left arm and was associated with shortness of breath. No associated loss of consciousness  palpitations  or diaphoresis reported. The patient had a history of hypertension controlled with beta-blocker therapy and no history of diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  or thyroid disorders. There were no previous hospitalizations. She was a nonsmoker and denied alcohol consumption. The patient was recently widowed a few months ago.  Clinical Findings: On initial examination  the patient was pallid  acutely ill-looking  saturating 96% on room air. Pulse rate was 92 beats per minute  blood pressure was 148/98 mm Hg  and respiratory rate was 18 breaths per minute. Cardiovascular examination revealed normal heart sounds and no murmurs. Lung bases were clear to auscultation.  Diagnostic Assessment: The electrocardiogram at presentation showed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads V1-V4. Initial laboratory investigations  including complete blood count  renal function test  and liver function test  were within normal limits. The initial troponin T level was 0.51 ng/mL (normal: <0.01 ng/mL). The patient was treated as an acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) case and transferred to the cardiac catheterization lab. Coronary angiography showed no significant stenosis. Left ventriculogram demonstrated akinesia of the apex with basal hyperkinesis  consistent with ""Takotsubo"" or ""apical ballooning"" pattern. Echocardiography confirmed these findings.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was managed by supportive care including angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and beta-blockers. The anticoagulant was discontinued considering the possibility of intraventricular thrombus. Antidepressants were also prescribed to manage the stress related to loss.   Follow-up and Outcomes: During the hospital stay  the patient’s symptoms of chest pain and dyspnea improved. Serial cardiac biomarkers returned to normal within a week. Repeat echocardiography after four weeks demonstrated near normalization of left ventricular function. Clinically  the patient remained symptom-free at the 3-month follow-up.  Patient's Perspective: The patient’s sense of well-being had improved significantly  and she was relieved that her coronary arteries were normal. She was introduced to a local bereavement support group  which she found helpful.  Informed Consent: The patient gave informed consent for the case to be published.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of considering Takotsubo cardiomyopathy in the differential diagnosis of acute chest pain  especially in postmenopausal women with recent severe emotional stress. Also  a normal coronary anatomy during angiography in the setting of myocardial infarction should raise the suspicion for the same. Prompt recognition and supportive treatment can significantly improve outcomes.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Post-Menopausal Female with No Previous Cardiovascular History  Case Report:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female with an unremarkable medical history  other than controlled Hypothyroidism on Levothyroxine  who presented at our emergency department with severe chest pain. She had not been experiencing any previous symptoms  did not have any known cardiovascular history  and did not take any regular cardiovascular medication.  Five days before her admission  the patient had faced a severe emotional stress in the form of her husband's sudden death. She reported gapingly awakened from sleep with sudden  severe  and central chest pain radiating to her left arm. Her chest pain was reported as 9/10 on the Visual Analogue Scale and was associated with nausea  diaphoresis  and breathlessness.   Clinical examination revealed slightly elevated blood pressure at 140/90mmHg and a heart rate of 90 beats per minute. The rest of the physical findings were normal. The patient had an ECG  which showed ST-segment elevation in the anterolateral leads. She was immediately admitted for suspected Acute Coronary Syndrome and started on Asprin and Clopidogrel.  Laboratory investigations did not show significantly elevated Troponin T levels. Echocardiography showed akinetic apical and middle segments of the left ventricle with hyperkinetic basal segments  often compared to the shape of a takotsubo (Octopus trap). Coronary angiography did not show any significant coronary artery disease that could explain the regional wall motion abnormality.  The diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy was made clinically using the Mayo clinic criteria. She was initiated on standard heart failure treatment with Bisoprolol and Ramipril. Psychotherapy was also advised considering her emotional stress.  The patient demonstrated a gradual clinical improvement and was discharged after eight days. Follow-up echocardiography done six weeks later showed marked improvement and near-normalization of the left ventricular function.  Conclusion:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress or broken heart syndrome  can mimic myocardial infarction and is often triggered by intense emotional or physical stress. This report highlights that the syndrome  while rare  may occur in people with no previous cardiovascular history. Hence  it is vital to include Takotsubo cardiomyopathy as a differential diagnosis in individuals presenting with chest pain and electrocardiogram changes  regardless of their previous history. Additionally  psychological support might be beneficial in the management of this condition given its strong correlation with stressful events.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy Following Extreme Emotional Stress in a Postmenopausal Woman  Case Report:  The patient  Ms. A  is a 68-year-old Caucasian female with a history of depression and anxiety  but no known history of cardiovascular disease. She was in her usual state of health until the untimely passing of her son  which served as the situational stressor that exacerbated her condition.   She presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain radiating to her left shoulder  associated with difficulty in breathing  palpitations  and an episode of syncope that lasted approximately 2 minutes. The pain had started suddenly  around 2 hours after hearing the news of her son's death. She described the pain as a heavy pressure  scoring it as a 9 on the scale of 1 to 10  with 10 being the most severe pain.  She had a pulse rate of 102 beats per minute  blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 95% in room air. The rest of her physical examination was within normal limits.  Histories related to alcohol consumption  smoking  or illicit drug use were negative. She was on escitalopram for her depression and lorazepam for anxiety.  Her preliminary blood work revealed elevated troponin levels at 4 ng/mL (normal <0.04 ng/mL)  with normal CK-MB levels. EKG showed ST-segment elevations in leads II  III  aVF  and V1-V4. Following the results  she was immediately transferred for coronary angiography suspecting an acute myocardial infraction. Surprisingly  the angiography did not reveal any coronary artery disease.  Echocardiography revealed apical ballooning with basal hyperkinesis  clinical features consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TTC). Her left ventricular ejection fraction was also markedly reduced at 35% (normal >55%). She was diagnosed with TTC following confirmation from the cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that displayed transient regional systolic dysfunction of the left ventricular (LV) mid-segments with or without apical involvement  mimicking the image of the “octopus trap”  which is the hallmark of TTC.  Ms. A was given supportive care with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  beta-blockers  and anxiolytics. She was also recommended for counseling considering her grief response to her son's passing. By the end of the second week  her troponin levels normalized and her chest pain resolved  with a remarkable improvement in the echocardiography depicting the ejection fraction returning to the normal value.   This case report presents the characteristic triggers  and presentation of TTC  and how effective management with supportive care can lead to complete recovery. It is crucial for healthcare providers to consider TTC in the differential diagnosis when older women present with chest pain and EKG changes following intense emotional stress even in the absence of coronary artery disease.
