She reported that her symptoms started suddenly while she was attending the funeral of her husband earlier in the day.  Past Medical History: Patient history reveals she is a non-smoker with well-managed hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She denies any personal or family history of heart diseases. Her husband died of lung cancer a week ago and she has been under severe emotional stress since then.  Physical Examination: On examination  she appeared anxious and in distress. Vital signs showed elevated blood pressure at 169/90 mmHg  and tachycardia with a heart rate of 115 beats per minute. Auscultation revealed slight crackles at the base of both her lungs.  Additional notes: The sudden onset of her symptoms in conjunction with her recent emotional stress indicates a potential diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  commonly referred to as broken heart syndrome. It is a temporary heart condition that is often brought on by stressful situations  such as the death of a loved one. A complete evaluation  including relevant diagnostic tests  should be undertaken to confirm the diagnosis and rule out myocardial infarction which presents similarly. Immediate management and further implication of the diagnosis should be discussed as part of the case study.

Patient Profile: Name: Mrs. Evelyn Age: 61 year old Sex: Female Occupation: Retired Schoolteacher Ethnic Origin: Asian-American  Chief Complaints: 1. Difficulty breathing and chest discomfort  2. Profuse sweating 3. Feeling of impending doom 4. Nausea  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension for 7 years  regularly monitored and controlled with antihypertensives. 2. No past history of cardiac ailments. 3. Recently widowed  with significant psychological stress owing to the sudden and unexpected demise of her husband.  Presenting Scenario: Mrs. Evelyn presented to the emergency department following an episode of acute chest discomfort and profuse sweating while at a gathering to commemorate her late husband's life  an event she found particularly distressing.  Exam Findings: On examination  she appeared anxious. Her blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg; pulse 105 beats per minute; respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  and temperature of 37.2-degree Celsius. Cardiovascular examination indicated mild tachycardia with no added sounds. ECG showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Elevated troponin levels were observed during laboratory investigations  indicating myocardial injury.  This clinical scenario is typical of a suspected case of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (Broken Heart Syndrome). It frequently presents in postmenopausal women following significant emotional stress. The key symptoms such as chest pain and dyspnea mimic myocardial infarction  but it is distinct due to the absence of coronary artery occlusion. The diagnosis will need to be confirmed through an echocardiogram or angiogram to ascertain the characteristic ventricle abnormalities associated with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Learning objectives:  1. Recognize Takotsubo cardiomyopathy's clinical presentation  which can mimic myocardial infarction.  2. Differentiate between Takotsubo cardiomyopathy and acute coronary syndrome based on patient history  examination  and investigations.  3. Understand the impact of significant emotional stress in the etiology of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. 4. Develop an appropriate management plan for a patient presenting with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Demographics Patient Name: Ms. Ava Thompson  Age: 68   Sex: Female  Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher  Past Medical History  She was diagnosed with hypertension and spontaneously resolved depression 5 years ago. She has been under antihypertensive drugs since her diagnosis. There is no history of smoking  alcohol consumption  or drug use. Her mother had a history of ischemic heart disease but no incidence of myocardial infarction. No relevant surgical history is reported. The patient does not have any known allergies.  Presenting Complaints  Ms. Thompson presented to the Emergency Department describing a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to her left arm. She also reported symptoms of nausea and shortness of breath. There is no history of recent febrile illness or viral infections. The symptoms appeared abruptly following a phone call she received informing her of the sudden death of her beloved younger brother. Prior to that  she was in her usual state of health.  Patient states that this episode reminded her of a similar episode of brief unexplained chest pain that occurred when she heard about her mother's death two years ago  for which she did not seek medical attention.   The main focus of this case is to explore the potential link between emotional stress and the onset of takotsubo cardiomyopathy symptoms  looking at the pathophysiology  diagnosis  management  and long-term care for patients with this condition.

Patient Case:  Demographics:  This case involves a 68-year-old Caucasian female.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia  controlled with medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively). She is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol in moderation. She has been relatively stable from a cardiac perspective until the present event. The patient also has a history of Generalized Anxiety Disorder  managed with psychotherapy and a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). She recently experienced the sudden death of her husband two months ago.  Key Complaints:  The patient presents to the emergency department with the chief complaint of sudden onset of acute chest pain. The pain is severe  localized in the central region of the chest  and radiates up to the neck. The pain is pressure-like  non-radiating  and not related to physical exertion. She also reports associated shortness of breath  nausea  and lightheadedness. Electrocardiogram (ECG) findings show ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  mostly suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome (ACS). She denies any palpitations  dizziness  sweating  vomiting or loss of consciousness. Her blood pressure is 145/90mmHg  pulse is 88 bpm  respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute  temperature is 37.0°C  and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air.   This case represents a typical presentation of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as the broken heart syndrome)  a transient left ventricular dysfunction triggered by intense emotional or physical stress. The condition is more commonly seen in postmenopausal women. The stress causes a change in the heart muscles that results in the left ventricle changing shape. This is often temporary and reversible  but can lead to serious complications such as acute heart failure  arrhythmias  and thromboembolic events. It can sometimes also mimic an acute coronary syndrome. Timely recognition and management of this syndrome is crucial to ensure the patient’s safe recovery.

Patient Information:   Mrs. Patricia Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian woman  lives alone and recently widowed.  Chief Complaint:   Sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the left arm  shortness of breath  and a feeling of impending doom.  Past Medical History:  She has a documented history of controlled hypertension  being treated with Lisinopril 10mg daily. She has no previous history of cardiac problems but does suffer from generalized anxiety disorder managed by a psychiatrist with a stable dose of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor. She is not diabetic or dyslipidemic  doesn't smoke  and drinks alcohol occasionally. She recently lost her husband of 40 years to lung cancer about a month prior to the emergence of these symptoms.  Physical Examination:  Vitals on arrival: BP - 145/90 mmHg  Heart Rate - 112/min  irregular  Respiratory rate - 22/min  SpO2 - 98% on room air Examination conducted indicates no abnormalities in the respiratory system  mild tenderness in the epigastrium  no peripheral edema.  Emergency evaluation suggested Acute Coronary Syndrome. An ECG was conducted  which displayed an ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. Surprisingly  subsequent angiography revealed no significant obstructive coronary artery disease. A subsequent echocardiogram instead revealed apical ballooning with base-to-apex gradient in left ventricular contraction  suggestive of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.  Diagnosis:   Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy or Broken Heart Syndrome triggered by acute emotional stress following the death of a spouse.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Demographics: Patient's Name: Mrs. Davis Age: 70-year-old Gender: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Teacher  Past Medical History: Mrs. Davis has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  both controlled with medication. She has no history of a previous heart disease  no surgeries  no allergies  and no history of tobacco or alcohol use. She lives alone  and her husband passed away three years ago. She has been relatively healthy until recently.  Chief Complaints: Mrs. Davis presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain  which she describes as similar to a ""pounding"" sensation. The pain started suddenly while she was stressed and upset about financial matters. The pain is severe and is associated with shortness of breath  palpitations  and light-headedness.   Remembering Mrs. Davis's case will be crucial in accurately diagnosing and treating Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken-heart syndrome"". It commonly mimics symptoms of heart attack and occurs in response to severe stress. Complete understanding and analysis of the patient's case history  clinical presentation  and tests like Echocardiogram or Coronary angiogram can be beneficial in diagnosing the condition and ruling out a heart attack. Patients with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy like Mrs. Davis generally recover with supportive treatments if diagnosed and managed timely.

Patient Profile: - Name: Mrs. Amelia Thompson - Age: 69 years - Sex: Female - Occupation: Retired schoolteacher - Ethnic Background: Caucasian  Past Medical History: Mrs. Thompson has a history of hypertension  which is managed with Lisinopril 20mg daily. She is post-menopausal and was diagnosed with osteoporosis two years back. She lives alone and has a history of major depressive disorder  for which she has been on sertraline 50mg/day for the past 5 years. She does not smoke or consume alc0hol.  Presenting Complaints: Mrs. Thompson presented to the emergency department with acute chest pain radiating to her left arm that started abruptly 6 hours ago while she was at home. The pain was not relieved by rest. Along with this  she experienced shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. She also experienced intense emotional stress in the last week due to the sudden death of her beloved pet.  Key Points for Discussion/start>: This case provides a key opportunity for discussing the characteristic features of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM)  also known as 'Broken heart syndrome'. TCM commonly presents following a severe emotional stressor (in this case  the death of Mrs. Thompson's pet). Symptoms and signs often mimic a myocardial infarction ('heart attack')  including chest pain and shortness of breath  adding to the diagnostic challenge. It is crucial for students to learn how to distinguish TCM from other life-threatening cardiac diseases based on symptoms  risk factors (such as post-menopausal state in this case)  and appropriate diagnostic tools.  The case discussion can further encompass treating acute presentations  longer-term management strategies  and evaluating the role of psychological stress in cardiac health. The impact of this condition on patient's mental health and lifestyle modification can also be discussed to give the students a holistic understanding of the disease scenario.

Case Description:  Patient Demographics: Mrs. Anne  a 65-year-old Caucasian female  Past Medical History: The patient is a widow who lives alone. She's a retired teacher with a history of well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. Her father passed away due to myocardial infarction in his late seventies. On her regular medication list  she takes Amlodipine 5 mg daily and Atorvastatin 20 mg daily.  Key Complaints: Mrs. Anne has been brought to the emergency department by her neighbor. She reports experiencing severe chest pain that started suddenly while she was watching news reports of a terrorist attack abroad where her son is currently deployed. The pain is described as central  heavy  crushing  similar to “an elephant standing on the chest”. The pain was associated with shortness of breath and was initially relieved by rest and taking sublingual nitroglycerin. However  after a couple of hours  similar symptoms recurred and she felt nauseous and sweaty.  Physical Examination: Upon the physical examination  Mrs. Anne appeared anxious with a slightly pale complexion. Vital signs showed a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate 92 bpm and regular  respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute  and O2 saturation of 98% on room air. The examination of the cardiovascular system revealed no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Pulmonary  abdominal  and extremity examinations were unremarkable.  Discussion points for the case: 1. Stress-induced cardiomyopathy 2. Differential diagnosis for acute chest pain 3. Role of ECG  troponin level  echo  coronary angiography in ACS and takotsubo cardiomyopathy. 4. Management of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian woman named Betsy. She is widowed and retired from her job as a schoolteacher. She has two adult children and has two grandchildren. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. She is physically active and follows a balanced diet regimen. Her body mass index is 24 Kg/m^2.  Past Medical History: The patient has Type 2 diabetes  which has been under control with oral hypoglycemic agents for the past eight years. She suffered from hypertension for which she is taking medication. She has no history of myocardial infarction  heart failure  or other structural heart diseases. She experienced menopause at the age of 51.  Key Complaints: Betsy visited her local GP complaining of a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to her left arm and neck. The pain started a couple of hours after she received news of her brother's sudden demise. She describes the pain as ""heavy"" and ""crushing"". On questionning  she reported episodes of faintness and shortness of breath. Also  she had been feeling emotionally distressed since hearing the news.   ---  (Note: Medical students discussing this case would need to focus on the key  distinctive characteristics of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome: predominantly post-menopausal women  often precipitated by intense emotional or physical stress  mimicking symptoms of a heart attack. Students should be guided to recognize the unique scenarios this condition presents and differentiating it from other cardiac conditions like acute coronary syndrome  and performing appropriate diagnostic measures such as ECG  cardiac enzyme testing  and echocardiography.)

Patient Information:  A 68-year-old Caucasian female  Patient Background:  The patient is a retired teacher  living with her husband. She is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol. She generally enjoys good health  infrequent complaints of mild hypertension  which is controlled with medication  but has no history of coronary disease  diabetes  or any other significant inherited disorder.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient came into the ER complaining of severe  sudden onset chest pain radiating to her left arm. She described the pain as similar to “a heavy weight on my chest."" She mentions she had been under a lot of stress due to her husband recently being diagnosed with lung cancer.  Evaluation and Physical Examination: Vitals were recorded - BP: 155/95 mmHg  HR: 110 bpm  RR: 20/min  Temp: 98.6 F  Oxygen Saturation: 95% on room air. Physical examination revealed that she was paroxysmally sweaty but not in visible distress. Her lungs were clear on auscultation  and her heart sounds were regular without any murmuring.   The ECG showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads (V1-V4)  indicating a possible heart attack. However  upon conducting the blood tests  her Troponin levels were found only moderately raised  not fitting with a typical myocardial infarction profile.  Further Investigation: A coronary angiogram was subsequently ordered and revealed no significant coronary artery disease to account for the ECG changes. Echocardiogram and left ventriculogram showed apical ballooning with hyperkinesis of the basal segment and hypokinesis of the mid and apical segments of the left ventricle - indicative of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   Diagnosis and Conclusion: From the patient's symptoms  the disparity between the ECG changes and Troponin levels  and the results from the coronary angiogram and echocardiogram - a diagnosis of takotsubo or 'stress' cardiomyopathy was made.  Discussion: The case presents an excellent opportunity for medical students to learn about takotsubo cardiomyopathy  a condition that commonly mimics acute coronary syndrome. Emphasis should be placed on the diagnostic challenges posed by the disease and the importance of considering the emotional/psychological status of the patient  detailed history  examination findings  ECG changes  laboratory values  and results of imaging studies in making the correct diagnosis.

Patient Demographics: Age: 62-years-old; Gender: Female; Race: Caucasian; Occupation: Retired school teacher  Past Medical History: Lives alone  nonsmoker  occasionally drinks. Following her husband's death 5 years ago  the patient has been managing her stress and has no significant history of cardiac disease. She has a history of hypertension controlled with medication. She does not have diabetes or high cholesterol. Her father had coronary artery disease and died of myocardial infarction at the age of 68.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presents to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to her jaw  starting an hour back while she was upset having an argument on the phone with her son. The chest pain is associated with dizziness  nausea  shortness of breath  and feeling of impending doom.  Side note for Medical Educator: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is also called stress cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome.” It is often precipitated by intense emotional or physical stress that leads to severe  but typically reversible  left ventricular dysfunction. It mimics the symptoms of an acute coronary syndrome  but there is absence of obstructive coronary disease. This case presents an excellent opportunity to teach students about the complexity of heart diseases  the mind-heart connection  women's heart health  role of psychological stress in heart diseases  difference between Takotsubo cardiomyopathy and myocardial infarction  and comprehensive cardiovascular examination.

Patient Information: 63-year-old Caucasian female   Past Medical History: No known prior cardiac history. Double mastectomy 8 years prior for stage 2 breast cancer  no recurrence since. Hypertension managed well with antihypertensive medications  free from diabetes  and does not smoke or drink alcohol. Body mass index is 25  with controlled diet and regular mild exercise.  Chief Complaints: She presents with acute onset severe chest pain radiating to the left arm  associated with shortness of breath  palpitations  and lightheadedness. She also reports feeling a heightened sense of stress over the past couple of weeks due to the sudden death of her husband.  Emergency Department Initial Findings: Upon initial assessment  her blood pressure is 168/89 mmHg  heart rate 104 bpm  oxygen saturation 92% on room air  and body temperature 37.1°C. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. A bedside echocardiogram reveals apical ballooning of the left ventricle with basilar hypercontractility.  Summary: This case provides a prototypical presentation of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as broken heart syndrome)  which is a transient cardiac syndrome characterized by severe systolic dysfunction of the apical and/or mid segments of the left ventricle. It is usually triggered by intense emotional or physiological stress. Mostly affecting postmenopausal women  the presentation often mimics an acute coronary syndrome  highlighting the importance of differentiation for appropriate treatment and management.

Patient Demographics: Mrs. A is a 65-year-old Caucasian female of moderate socioeconomic status.  Past Medical History: Mrs. A has a significant past medical history of hypertension and one episode of major depressive disorder. She lost her husband two years ago and lives alone. She does not smoke and occasionally drinks wine. Mrs. A has no known drug allergies  and her medication list includes a daily dose of an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor and a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.  Key Complaints: One week ago  Mrs. A experienced a sudden death in the family  her only son. Following this event  Mrs. A started complaining of severe chest pain radiating to her neck  with associated symptoms including shortness of breath  palpitations and nausea. Despite the pain being similar to angina pectoris  she had not experienced such pain before.   She initially ignored her discomfort  attributing it to her grief. However  the persistence and intensification of symptoms over the next couple of days alarmed her  and she decided to visit the emergency department. Mrs. A’s ECG on arrival showed ST segment elevation  raising a high index of suspicion for acute coronary syndrome. However  the symptoms were inconsistent with her patient history as she had no previous episodes of chest pain.  This case presentation suggests a potential episode of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken-heart syndrome)  which must be confirmed with further investigation  such as an echocardiogram and coronary angiography to validate the presumed diagnosis. Though coronary artery disease is also a consideration  it is less likely due to the acute onset and psychosocial trigger. The recent traumatic event experienced by the patient makes takotsubo cardiomyopathy a leading differential diagnosis. This training case provides medical students with the opportunity to explore the link between emotional stress and cardiovascular health  and navigate the diagnostic steps and management of takotsubo cardiomyopathy especially in a bereaved  elderly patient.

Patient Information: Ms. Nora  a 72-year-old Caucasian female  retired school teacher  living alone  non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumer.  Presenting Complaints: Ms. Nora was brought to the Emergency Department by a neighbor after she reported experiencing intense chest pain following a heated argument with her son. She also complained of shortness of breath  weakness  and lightheadedness.   Past Medical History: She has a history of hypertension controlled with medication and well-managed type II diabetes. She has no known allergies. Despite a past mild myocardial infarction 10 years prior  her regular cardiac check-ups had been normal until now. She was evaluated for a similar episode two years ago  yielding normal results on cardiac work-up. Her father had died of a heart attack in his 60s. Recent stressful events include the death of her close friend and a robbery in her neighborhood.   Social History: She is a widow with two children  a high-ranking executive son and a daughter who is an artist. She enjoys gardening  reading  and stays physically active with yoga and walks. She has a strong social network  yet she reports feeling lonely at times. She follows a balanced diet with controlled sugar and salt.   This case focuses on recognizing the signs and symptoms of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as broken heart syndrome) under stress-induced conditions corroborated with an older age patient with a relevant medical history. This condition often mimics a heart attack and is exacerbated under severe emotional stress. Consequently  healthcare practitioners should exercise keen observation  coupled with a detailed medical history  to provide a differential diagnosis.    In subsequent discussions or activities  students can be tasked to identify relevant diagnostic tests  potential management protocols  and a comprehensive treatment plan for such a patient. Students should understand the importance of providing holistic care that includes adequate psychological and emotional support for the patient.

Patient Information: Age: 64 Sex: Female Race: Asian Occupation: Retired Teacher  Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension for which she is currently under treatment. She has no known allergies.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with acute chest pain  intermittent in nature  and often related to stress. Pain is described as a tight central chest crushing sensation  radiating towards the left shoulder. Furthermore  she complains of shortness of breath following mild exertion  accompanied by mild fatigue  and lightheadedness. No history of recent trauma  weight loss  night sweats  fever  or cough. Denies smoking or alcohol abuse. No family history of coronary artery disease.   The symptoms were notably triggered following the recent death of her husband  causing significant emotional stress.   These findings  coupled with her age and sex  make Takotsubo cardiomyopathy a key suspect for her condition  as it has been often called the ""broken heart syndrome"" reflecting its common association with stressful events. She denies any recent similar episodes.   This training case aims to focus on understanding the pathophysiology  diagnosis  and management of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy and how it differs from acute coronary syndrome.

Patient Profile: Name: Margaret H. Age: 68 Sex: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension controlled with medication (Lisinopril 20mg daily). She also has a diagnosis of osteoporosis and is post-menopausal. There are no known allergies. She has no previous history of any cardiac disease. She does not smoke  consumes alcohol socially  and lives alone. Her husband passed away 5 years ago  and she has been dealing with late-life depression ever since.   Chief Complaints: Patient presents to the emergency department with acute chest pain that started about 2 hours ago  which she describes as ""sharp"" and ""stabbing"" located in the central and left side of the chest  radiating to the left arm along with shortness of breath.   She reports the pain started suddenly whilst she was dealing with a significant emotional distress - a heated argument with her son over the phone. She also feels palpitations  extreme fatigue  and light-headedness. There’s no associated nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis.  She articulates heightened anxiety due to the potential of the pain signifying a myocardial infarction because her late husband had multiple heart attacks. Her immediate self-assumed connection between her symptoms and potential cardiovascular trouble further heightened overall stress.  Additional Notes: She is not on any blood thinners or other significant medications that might complicate a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. A discussion of this potential diagnosis requires presentation of pertinent negatives  such as these  and a thorough examination of her symptoms in light of her recent emotional distress should be undertaken.  Discussions should approach the particularities of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  such as its common triggers  the typical demographic affected (post-menopausal women)  and its usual presentation mimicking acute coronary syndrome. As part of students' differential considerations  they should learn to recognize and diagnose this unique type of stress-induced cardiomyopathy.   This case offers a chance to explore the curious and intricate links between mental health and cardiovascular disease  specifically focusing on the effects that acute emotional stress can have on the heart.

Patient Case:  Demographics: A 67-year-old Asian female  recently retired high school teacher  widow  non-smoker  and regular alcohol consumer (social drinking during weekends).  Past Medical History: She has a controlled hypertension managed by regular medications (Lisinopril once per day). She is prediabetic  controlled with diet. She also has a history of chronic stress and anxiety with occasional panic attacks  managed with cognitive behavioral therapy and occasional use of benzodiazepines. No history of cardiac diseases in family.  Key Complaints: The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden severe chest pain. She described the pain as a ""sharp""  ""crushing"" sensation  radiating to her left arm  which started a few hours ago while she was watching a terrifying scene in a horror film. She now feels lightheaded with associated shortness of breath. She also reports nausea and sweating but no vomiting  fever  cough  or palpitations. There is no prior history of similar episodes  no aggravating or alleviating factors identified. She denied recent travel history or history of osteoporosis  deep vein thrombosis  or estrogen therapy. She denied any kind of illicit drug use or recent trauma.   Please note: This clinical scenario is provided for educational purposes and any findings should be setup for educational progressive discovery from history  examination  clinical reasoning process  investigations  and management to make an accurate diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian female. She works as an elementary school teacher. She lives with her husband and has raised two adult children. She is a non-smoker. She drinks alcohol only socially and she does not use recreational drugs. The patient claims to lead an active  healthy lifestyle. She exercises regularly and eats a balanced diet.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  which is well controlled with medication (Enalapril 10mg daily). The patient is also treated for hyperlipidemia (Atorvastatin 40mg daily). She has no known drug allergies. There is no history of diabetes  thyroid disease or kidney disease. She had a normal cardiac evaluation which included a stress test 3 years ago due to her family history of heart disease. Her father suffered a myocardial infarction at age 56. She has had two uncomplicated pregnancies. Her menstrual history is essentially normal and she is currently in the perimenopause phase. She has no known history of psychologic disorders or stress-related illness.   Key Complaints: The patient was brought to the emergency department experiencing severe chest discomfort  dyspnea and a sense of impending doom. The symptoms occurred suddenly while she was delivering a eulogy at her mother’s funeral. The level of discomfort was so severe that it prompted her to stop speaking and sit down. She described the pain as crushing  located in the substernal area  radiating to her left arm and up to her jaw. She also reported feeling a rapid heartbeat at the onset of her symptoms and faintness. She denied experiencing any prior similar symptom. She also denied any neck  shoulder  back or epigastric pain  nausea  emesis  diaphoresis  cough  wheezing  hemoptysis  fevers  chills  headaches  facial flushing or rash. There is no history of trauma. Her symptoms did not improve with rest. She was brought to the hospital by ambulance.   In conclusion  the unique stressor of the patient’s circumstances  coupled with her symptoms and history  suggests a possible diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  commonly known as broken heart syndrome. Further diagnostic investigations are required to confirm this diagnosis.

Case Study: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy   Patient Demographics Gender: Female  Age: 64 years old Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired school teacher Marital status: Widowed  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She has been on amlodipine and atorvastatin for the past six years. She quit smoking over 20 years ago. Aside from this  she has no significant past medical history. There is no known family history of heart disease.   Presenting Complaints: The patient has presented to the emergency department with sudden-onset  severe chest pain radiating to the left arm. She also reported to feeling a sense of impending doom  along with diaphoresis and shortness of breath that began while she was attending her daughter's wedding. The symptoms had their onset following an emotional speech given by the patient about her late husband.  The pain began suddenly about two hours ago and has increased in intensity since. The pain did not improve with rest. She does not have any common triggers such as exertion or stress. This is her first episode of such kind of pain. She also reports no symptoms of esophageal reflux.  The patient appears visibly distressed and rates her current pain as an 8 on a scale of 0-10.  Conclusion: With the given patient's history and sudden-onset  severe chest pain following an emotional episode  Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (also known as 'broken heart syndrome') should be part of the differential diagnosis. This brief illustrative case could be used as an educational case presentation during training to discuss the process of evaluation  diagnosis including ECG changes  echocardiography findings  treatment options and the future risk of recurrence for Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Gender: Female Age: 63 Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She has been on: Lisinopril 20mg daily for her hypertension and Atorvastatin 20mg daily for her hyperlipidemia. She also has had histories of severe depression and anxiety for which she is on Zoloft 150mg daily and Alprazolam 0.5mg as needed. She has a 30 pack-year smoking history. No known drug allergies.. She has no family history of cardiac disease  and her parents are both alive and well.   Key Complaints: Patient presented to the emergency department experiencing acute severe chest pain radiating to the left arm  along with shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and nausea. She rated her chest pain as 9/10 on the pain scale. Her symptoms started after she received a call informing her of her daughter's sudden inadvertent serious motor vehicle accident.  Based on her sudden onset of symptoms after severe emotional stress (death of a close family member)  physical examination finding  and further evaluation (which should include ECG changes not typically seen in myocardial infarction  elevated cardiac enzymes  and characteristic left ventricular dysfunction on echocardiography) the clinical suspicion for takotsubo cardiomyopathy or the 'broken heart syndrome' should be high.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Ms. Fernandez  a 68-year-old Hispanic woman who has resided in California for most of her life.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents to the emergency department with acute chest pain and shortness of breath. These symptoms initiated soon after she attended her husband’s funeral. Patient denies any injury or trauma. No chest pain radiation  nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis.  Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of hypertensive heart disease  for which she takes a beta-blocker - Metoprolol. Her late husband was her primary caregiver and managed her medications. She has no history of valvular heart disease  myocardial infarction  cigarette smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use.  Examinations and Investigations: Her blood pressure upon arrival: 175/95 mmHg  with a heart rate of 110 bpm  and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Physical examination otherwise unremarkable  chest is clear  and no peripheral edemas noted. EKG reveals slight ST-elevation in anterolateral leads (V3-V6). A subsequent echocardiogram shows apical ballooning of the left ventricle and reduced ejection fraction (around 30%)  while her coronary angiogram results appear normal. The subsequent blood test noted a mild elevation of cardiac markers  Troponin-I of 1.8 ng/mL.  Case Discussion: Based on her emotional stress  EKG changes  characteristic echocardiogram findings  and absence of significant coronary artery disease on angiography  Ms. Fernandez was diagnosed with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (also known as stress cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome).  Education Objective: The purpose of this case is to help medical students understand the etiology  presentation  diagnosis  and treatment of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy. The condition often mimics myocardial infarction and is triggered by severe emotional stress. She had typical ‘apical ballooning’ of the left ventricle on echocardiography  a finding often associated with this condition. It is crucial to recognize the difference between Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy and acute myocardial infarction as the management is different for both disorders. Quick diagnosis and management can help reduce morbidity and mortality.

Patient Background:  Ms. Yuko  a 75-year-old Japanese woman  was taken to the emergency room (ER) by her son after experiencing severe chest pains. The patient is a widow  lives with her son  and is a retired schoolteacher. Her son clarified that she had the onset of chest pain after receiving news about her best friend's unexpected death.  Past Medical History:   Ms. Yuko has a history of hypertension which has been well managed with Lisinopril 20mg daily for the past ten years. She also suffers from osteoporosis and has been on Alendronate for 5 years. There is no history of diabetes or high lipid levels. She has no known drug allergies. She quit smoking 15 years ago and her alcohol consumption is negligible. There is no significant family history of early heart disease or sudden death.  Key Complaints:   The key complaints include severe  abrupt chest pain radiating to the left arm  difficulty in breathing  and lightheadedness. The son noticed his mother also seemed fatigued and pale. He also reported that his mother had been under a lot of stress in recent days due to her friend's sudden illness and subsequent demise.  This scenario presents a potential case of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as Broken Heart Syndrome. This condition often mimics a heart attack  presents almost identical symptoms  but usually has varied underlying causes that distinguish it from typical myocardial infarctions. In this case  the potent emotional stress could be the trigger for Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy. However  this is a clinical diagnosis that should be supported with further diagnostic investigations such as EKG  cardiac enzyme levels  and echocardiogram  which will typically reveal apical ballooning and no coronary occlusion that would indicate heart attack.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Information: Ms. Linda Thompson  a 70-year-old Caucasian female  Past Medical History: No history of cardiovascular disease. She has controlled type 2 diabetes and is a non-smoker with moderate alcohol consumption. Family history of myocardial infarction in paternal grandfather.   Presenting Complaints: Ms. Thompson presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to her jaw and left arm  lasting for 1 hour. The pain began following a family argument  where she experienced severe emotional stress.   Symptoms: - Severe retrosternal chest pain - Nausea - Dizziness - Shortness of breath - Palpitations  Physical Examination: On physical exam  she is diaphoretic and appears in distress due to severe pain. Vital signs show blood pressure of 155/95  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Heart and lung exams are unremarkable apart from a slight irregularity to the rhythm and bilateral basal crepitations.  Clinical Course: Her ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in the anterior precordial leads  and her troponin level is elevated. She was initially managed as an acute coronary syndrome with aspirin  nitroglycerin  and heparin. However  angiogram did not show any occlusive disease to explain her presentation. Echocardiogram revealed left ventricular apical ballooning with preserved function at the base — a pattern consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome"".   Discussion: Patients with takotsubo cardiomyopathy often present similarly to those with acute coronary syndrome. it is often associated with emotional or physical stress  which can be a point of conversation in history taking. The critical diagnostic difference is the lack of significant occlusive disease on angiography  coupled with the distinctive finding of apical ballooning on echocardiography. The condition generally has a good prognosis  although supportive care in the acute phase is crucial as complications can arise.   Educational Objectives: - Recognize presentation similarities between takotsubo cardiomyopathy and acute coronary syndrome - Understand the diagnostic significance of the distinctive echocardiographic findings in takotsubo cardiomyopathy - Learn about stress-related etiological factors and discuss them during patient anamnesis - Understand the importance of supportive care in the acute phase and reassure that the prognosis is generally favourable.   This case will provide valuable interactive learning about the presentation  diagnosis  management  and prognosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Patient Profile: Gender: Female Age: 68 years Ethnicity: Asian Profession: Retired nurse  History: The patient is a nonsmoker  non-alcoholic and has been hypertensive for the past 10 years  consistently controlling it with medication. Her father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 75 and passed away due to subsequent complications. The patient leads a moderately active lifestyle but has been under significant stress due to an ongoing bitter legal dispute over property issues.  Presenting Complaints: The patient reports sudden onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath lasting for about an hour. The chest pain is described as a crushing type  located in the center and radiating to the left arm and the jaw. Patient also reported feeling dizzy and light-headed but denied any fainting spells. She has no previous history of similar instances.  On further inquiry  the patient revealed that she received news of losing her court case just before the symptoms began. She denied any other symptoms like sweating  nausea  vomiting or palpitations. There were no signs of infection like fever  cough or urinary symptoms. No other systemic symptoms like joint pain  rashes or recent weight loss/gain were reported.  This brief summary should give medical students the necessary clinical information to identify the key symptoms of takotsubo cardiomyopathy – chest pain and breathing difficulty  typically after emotional or physical stress. With a hypertensive background and parental history of myocardial infarction  the students should be guided to consider potential heart disease and understand the mimicking nature of cardiomyopathy's signs and symptoms.

Patient Information:  Name: Mary Johnson Age: 65 Race: Caucasian Gender: Female Occupation: Retired Teacher   Presenting Complaints:   Ms. Johnson presents to the emergency room with sudden  severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and associated with shortness of breath. She has been feeling nauseous with a mild headache. There were no symptoms suggestive of a cold or flu prior to the onset of chest pain.   Past Medical History:   She reports no history of heart disease  diabetes or hypertension. She has been generally healthy throughout her lifetime apart from occasional migraines.  She’s a lifelong non-smoker and consumes alcohol only socially. She follows a well-balanced diet and has BMI of 23.  Her mother died of a heart attack at the age of 70.  Recent History:  It's reported that Ms. Johnson lost her husband two weeks back causing severe emotional stress. She has been having difficulties sleeping  and expresses feelings of profound sadness and some anxiety since her husband’s death.  Clinical Examination:  On examination  she appears slightly distressed. Vital signs are: BP 170/90 mmHg  Pulse 110 bpm  Temp 98.6 F  Respiratory rate 22 breaths/min. Her oxygen saturation on pulse oximetry is 96% while breathing ambient air. Cardiac auscultation revealed tachycardia with no added sounds or murmurs. Rest of physical examination is normal.  Routine Investigations:  1. Electrocardiogram (ECG): ST segment elevation in precordial leads. 2. Troponin T level: moderately raised 3. Chest X-ray: Normal cardio-thoracic ratio  no signs of pulmonary congestion.  Based on the above findings  acute coronary syndrome (ACS) is suspected  but her young age  history of severe emotional stress and lack of pre-existing cardiovascular risk factors suggest a possibility of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken-heart syndrome). An urgent echocardiogram and coronary angiogram are needed to confirm this.   Learning Objective:  This case is designed to provide medical students an in-depth discussion on takotsubo cardiomyopathy – its triggers  clinical presentation  diagnostic workup  differentiation from ACS  and management.

Patient Information: Mrs. Y  65-year-old Asian female  retired school teacher.  Past Medical History: Non-smoker and non-alcoholic. Previous episodes of hypertension and mild anxiety for which she was under medication. No history of diabetes or any other chronic illnesses.  Key Complaints: Mrs. Y presented to the emergency department (ED) with complaints of sudden onset chest pain  shortness of breath and mild fainting episodes. This happened a few hours after she received some bad news of her son being severely injured in an accident. The pain was described as ‘crushing’ positioned in the middle of her chest  radiating to her left shoulder and arm. Acute stress-related symptoms were evident when she mentioned about her extreme worry and fear related to her son's condition.  Presentation: The patient appeared anxious  her BP was elevated at 150/90 mmHg with a heart rate of 110 bpm. EKG showed ST-segment elevation in anterior leads  suggesting acute myocardial infarction. The patient was shocked by this given she had a healthy lifestyle with no history of cardiovascular diseases. On probing  she revealed the recent death of her spouse and her son's accident as major stressful life events.  These preliminary details help in giving a clue towards takotsubo cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome  requiring further exploration and examination through diagnostic tests. Further detailed case study can consist of information regarding cardiac enzyme test results  echocardiogram and cardiac MRI results and the management plan.

Patient Profile: Name: Lillian Grant Age: 67 Sex: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Nurse  Background: Lillian is an otherwise healthy  active woman with a past medical history of hypertension and major depressive disorder  both well-managed with medication (Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension and Fluoxetine 20mg for depression).   She had a recent tragic experience with the sudden death of her husband four weeks ago.  Presenting Complaints: Lillian came to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset severe chest pain which started a few hours prior to her visit. The pain was described as a severe 'crushing' feeling in the center of her chest. Lillian rated it as an 8/10 on the pain scale. She also reported shortness of breath  and feeling unusually tired and light-headed. She denied any radiation of the pain or associated symptoms such as nausea  vomiting  or sweating. There was no history of similar pain in the past.   The sudden tragic incident of her husband's passing and the elevated stress levels due to it made us suspect Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome. ECG  echocardiography  and serum levels of cardiac biomarkers were ordered to confirm the diagnosis and manage it accordingly.

Patient Information: - Age: 67 years - Gender: Female - Occupation: Retired - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Marital Status: Widowed  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of mild hypertension  well-controlled on a low dose of single-agent medication (hydrochlorothiazide). She occasionally suffers from gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Her social history is notable for a recent  stressful family incident—passing away of her husband. She leads a reasonably healthy lifestyle  engages in daily walks  and is not known to have either type 1 or type 2 diabetes mellitus. She does not smoke nor has a history of excessive alcohol consumption.  Key Complaints: The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with acute chest pain  which she described as a sudden  sharp  and severe ""crushing"" sensation in the middle of her chest. The onset of pain was sudden with no history of trauma. Pain worsened with deep breathing and posture change  and was associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and sweating.  Subsequently  the patient also reported recent episodes of intense emotional stress and anxiety over her husband’s passing (acute emotional stressor).  This case report sets the stage for teaching about Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as broken heart syndrome) a stress-induced heart condition which often mimics symptoms of a heart attack and is typically triggered by intense emotional or physical stress.

Training Case Report - Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy   Patient Demographics: Mrs. Janet Sanders  a 68-year old Caucasian female  retired  living alone in a suburban community.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Sanders is a non-smoker and mild-alcohol consumer  has a history of hypertension controlled with diet and antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril)  and has been previously diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder managed with cognitive behavioral therapy and occasional Alprazolam. Has no known drug allergies and no family history or previous personal clinically evident heart disease.  Chief Complaint: Mrs. Sanders presented at the emergency department complaining of acute onset severe chest pain  resembling a ""heart attack "" ongoing for approximately 2 hours. The patient also indicated that the pain was triggered by severe emotional stress – she learned about the unexpected passing away of a near friend. The pain started abruptly and reached its peak intensity within minutes.   The pain was associated with shortness of breath  mild dizziness  and nausea. There were no specific factors relieving the pain and deep breathing further aggravated the pain.  Further evaluation will involve electrocardiography  assessment of cardiac enzymes  and possible left ventriculography to determine the diagnosis and management of the patient's condition  suspecting a case of Takotsubo (Stress) Cardiomyopathy also known as ""broken heart syndrome"".   Education Note: This case ideally demonstrates how a severe emotional stressor  especially in post-menopausal women  may precipitate Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The symptoms often mimic those of an acute coronary syndrome; however  the cardiac disturbance often resolves spontaneously with supportive care and management of any precipitating stressors.

Patient Profile:  Patient Initials: M.S. Age: 65 Gender: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired high school teacher  Past Medical History:  1. Occasional bouts of anxiety and depression – Under treatment for the past ten years. 2. Hypertension – Under control with medication for five years. 3. No history of heart diseases. 4. No history of major surgeries or hospitalizations. 5. Non-Smoker  occasional social drinker.  Key Complaints:  M.S. presented to the Emergency Department with severe and sudden onset of chest pain radiating to her left arm. She described the sensation as 'heavy' and 'pressing ' somewhat similar to indigestion. The pain began approximately two hours before her arrival at the hospital. The patient also complained of breathlessness and a heightened sense of anxiety.  Film Note:  This sudden severe pain occurred a day after she tragically lost her spouse to cancer. M.S. has been under significant emotional stress coping with her husband's illness and subsequent loss.  This case is a classic presentation for Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as Broken Heart Syndrome  which is often triggered by severe emotional stress. The main symptoms are chest pain and shortness of breath  which can mimic acute coronary syndrome. It mainly affects postmenopausal women. In this syndrome  the apex of the left ventricle of the heart balloons and dysfunctions. The exact cause is unknown  but it's thought that a surge of stress hormones stuns the heart  causing changes in heart cells or coronary blood vessels.

Case Report  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female  named Mrs. E  who resides in New York City. She is a retired high school teacher with two children and four grandchildren. Her husband passed away three years ago.  Past Medical History: Mrs. E is generally in good health  with no significant past medical problems. She has been diagnosed with controlled stage I hypertension in the past and is taking Lisinopril 10 mg/day. Moreover  she has hyperlipidemia and minor osteoarthritis of the knees. She has no history of tobacco usage or alcohol consumption and maintains a moderately active lifestyle.  Mrs. E was brought to the emergency department by her daughter after reporting sudden and severe chest pain that started at home while she was sorting through some old photos of her recently deceased husband.  Key Complaints: Mrs. E reports intense chest pain  radiating to her left arm  along with accompanying shortness of breath. On the pain scale  she rates the pain as an 8 out of 10. The pain started approximately 1 hour ago and comes in waves; it increases in severity with each peak. She also reports feeling dizzy and has vomited once.  Upon further questioning  Mrs. E admits to increasing episodes of emotional distress over the last few days  mainly due to grief over her late husband's death anniversary. No signs of fever  chills  cough  musculoskeletal pain  abdominal pain  or changes in bowel movements are reported.  This case is designed to illustrate the risk factors  presentation  and management of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as broken heart syndrome)  a condition often triggered by severe stress and presents similarly to a heart attack. It is particularly prevalent in postmenopausal women.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Ms. Julia Marshall is a 64-year-old Caucasian woman who is a recently retired high school principal. She currently lives alone and her only family is a daughter who lives in a different state.  Past Medical History: She has a past medical history of controlled hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. She was diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder 10 years prior for which she received counselling and occasional medication. She does not smoke cigarettes  and only drinks alcohol on occasions. She is physically active regularly participating in a local aerobics group.   Key Complaints: The patient presented to the Emergency Department with acute onset of severe chest pain radiating to the left arm  nausea  and palpitations that started a few hours ago after she received news that her sister had passed away suddenly. The pain is similar to a previous heart attack. The patient explained that the pain was severe and accompanied by a feeling of dread and apprehension. She also mentioned episodes of light-headedness but denied any syncope  shortness of breath  or diaphoresis. The patient was visibly upset and anxious.

Patient Details: Name: Mrs. Elizabeth Watson Age: 65 years old Gender: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Watson has no significant past medical history of note. She does not suffer from any known chronic illnesses such as diabetes or hypertension. She's non-smoker and leads quite an active lifestyle. Her only contributor to cardiac disease is a family history  as her mother suffers from ischemic heart disease.   Presenting Complaints: Mrs. Watson presented to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain  similar to a ""heavy weight pressing on the chest""  that started about an hour ago while she was attending her grandson's birthday party. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  nausea  and a syncopal episode. The patient admits experiencing an increased level of stress lately  primarily linked to her husband's recent terminal cancer diagnosis.   This case of Mrs. Watson was designed with the aim of demonstrating to medical students the typical scenario of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced or ""broken heart"" syndrome. It is especially common in post-menopausal women and often triggered by severe stress. The symptoms often mimic those of a heart attack  but it is not due to a blocked artery. Instead  it appears to be a temporary condition where the heart muscle weakens and balloons out  resembling a Japanese octopus fishing pot  or 'takotsubo'. This highlights the need to consider psychosocial history alongside physical symptoms when making a diagnosis.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  A 68-year-old Asian female with a body weight of 60 kg and a height of 160 cm.  Past Medical History: The patient has been generally healthy with well-controlled hypertension and no previous history of psychiatric conditions  drug use  or alcohol use. Her medications include 5mg amlodipine once daily. She has never smoked  and she has no history of heart disease in the family.   Key Complaints: The patient arrived at the ER reporting an acute onset of severe chest pain. She described the pain as a crushing feeling in the middle of her chest  which was not relieved by rest. The patient's vital signs upon arrival were stable  but she appeared noticeably anxious and distressed. Alongside chest pain  she also reported shortness of breath and profound fatigue.   The patient disclosed that two days ago she got news of her son’s sudden death in a motor accident  following the devastating emotional situation  she started encountering mild chest discomfort that has progressively become severe.   Additional Findings and Diagnosis: The case  which demonstrates symptoms that mimic acute coronary syndrome  might suggest a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  often stimulated by extreme stress. Further diagnosis will be done using imaging studies and other diagnostic workups such as ECG  cardiac biomarkers  echocardiography  and coronary angiography to ensure correct diagnosis  since this condition is generally reversible if promptly identified and treated.

Case Report: ""Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Patient""  Patient Demographic Information: Miss D. is a 68-year-old Caucasian woman  non-smoker  who has been living alone since her husband's death two years ago. She works as a retired school teacher and seeks solace in her books and gardening.   Past Medical History: She has a history of being treated for hypertension for the past ten years  which is under control. She also has hypothyroidism and is on Levothyroxine. She has had intermittent mild gastritis  for which she takes over-the-counter medications when needed. She does not have any known allergies. She is not a diabetic and does not suffer from any other chronic diseases.  Key Complaints: Miss D. presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe crushing chest pain radiating to her left arm. She describes it as ""a heavy weight pressing on her chest."" She also experienced shortness of breath  palpitations  and profuse sweating. The symptoms started when she was reading through old letters and memorabilia  revisiting emotional memories.   It should be mentioned that she denied having any symptoms prior to this event. She does not have any history of drug abuse and follows a pretty healthy lifestyle.  This brief case report illustrates the primary focused encounter where Miss D.'s presenting symptoms suggestive of acute coronary syndrome  commonly seen in myocardial infarction  could in fact be induced by Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  commonly known as ""broken-heart syndrome"". This condition should be considered as a differential diagnosis in the clinical investigation aiming to rule out myocardial infarction. It’s crucial to understand the patient's psychosocial background and the fact that emotional stress could precipitate Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  a rare but significant condition.

Patient Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Demographics Report: The patient  a 70-year-old woman  is Caucasian  retired  married  with two adult children. She formerly worked as a primary school teacher and has a moderate level of physical activity since her retirement.  Past Medical History: The patient's history is significant for hypertension for which she is taking a daily medication (Lisinopril). She also had an episode of depression about ten years prior to her current presentation. She denies past history of ischemic heart disease  angina  myocardial infarction  or stroke. There is no history of chronic kidney disease or diabetes. The patient denies any tobacco use and is a moderate drinker (2-3 standard drinks / week). The family history is significant for a brother who had a heart attack at the age of 80.  Key Complaints: The patient was brought to the Emergency Department (ED) with severe chest pain associated with shortness of breath. She reported that her symptoms started suddenly about two hours earlier and have been persistent since then. The pain was described as severe  started while she was resting  and located in the middle of her chest  radiating to her left arm. The symptoms were not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin.  Upon further questioning  she reveals that she has been under tremendous emotional stress due to the death of her husband a week ago. There was also associated dizziness but no loss of consciousness. She denied experiencing any bouts of nausea or vomiting  but did complain of a feeling of extreme fatigue.  The patient's EKG results revealed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  and echocardiography demonstrated significant left ventricular (LV) dysfunction with apical ballooning  while coronary angiography was negative for significant coronary artery disease  all of which point towards a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Given her presenting symptoms of chest pain associated with significant emotional stress and the loss of a loved one  her physiological findings  and the absence of significant coronary artery disease on angiography  the patient was diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy  often referred to as ""broken heart syndrome"".

Patient Information:   - Gender: Female - Age: 65 years old - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Recently retired teacher  Past Medical History:  - No known cardiac disease - Managed hypertension - Non-smoker - Drinks alcohol minimally  - No known drug allergies - Mother died of a myocardial infarction at age 70  Key Complaints:  The patient presents to the emergency department complaining of a severe chest pain that came on suddenly while she was attending her husband’s funeral. She describes it as a “crushing” sensation  very similar to what is often described in heart attacks.  She also reported shortness of breath  occasional lightheadedness and nausea. Her vitals on arrival were: BP 160/90mmHg  HR 110bpm  RR 18bpm and temperature of 36.8 degrees Celsius.   A 12-lead Electrocardiogram (ECG) was done immediately which showed ST segment elevation in the anterior leads  suspicious for anterior wall myocardial infarction. She was given sublingual nitroglycerin without much relief.   Pending any contraindications  aspirin should be administered  and our hypothetical patient should be rapidly moved to a facility capable of cardiac catheterization.   The severity of her symptoms  her recent stressful event  and the ECG changes are all characteristic clues pointing towards a potential diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Demographics: Ms. G  67-year-old Caucasian female  BMI 22  non-smoker with no alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History: A known case of Type-2 Diabetes  controlled by diet and medication. No history of cardiovascular disease  hypertension or hyperlipidemia. Her mother had hypertension and her father passed away from myocardial infarction at an early age.  Key Complaints: Ms. G presented to the emergency room with sudden-onset chest pain  radiating to the left arm  along with shortness of breath. She also reported mild nausea and profound fatigue. Her pain started after she received the news of her brother's sudden demise  with whom she was very close.  On examination  she was anxious  diaphoretic  and her pulse was erratic. Initial EKG pointed towards ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction.   This hypothetical case provides a starting point to discuss the condition of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken heart syndrome)  its potential triggers  clinical presentation  and approach towards diagnosis and management. The sudden intense stress leading to chest pain and EKG changes mimicking a heart attack signals towards this condition. Discussion around this case will help medical students to differentiate this condition from other cardiovascular diseases and comprehend the effects of stress on cardiovascular health.

Patient Case Report:   Patient Demographics: - Patient Name: Anonymous (for privacy) - Age: 67 years - Gender: Female  - Occupation: Retired nurse - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Marital Status: Widowed   Past Medical History:  - The patient has a history of hypertension  currently managed with beta-blockers and diuretics. - She has no known allergies. - No prior surgeries or significant illnesses such as diabetes  cancer or autoimmune diseases. - Experiences daily mild stress and reports a significant stress event  the death of her spouse  3 months ago. - Non-smoker and occasional alcohol consumption. - Family history of cardiovascular diseases with her mother passing away due to heart failure.  Presenting Complaints:  - Severe chest pain radiating to the back and shortness of breath. - The pain was sudden and severe  unlike anything she’s experienced in the past. - Feels like pressure on her chest along with palpitations. - She rates the pain as 8/10 and describes it as a squeezing sensation in her chest. - Additionally  she also reports feelings of extreme fatigue and episodes of lightheadedness over the past few weeks. - Pre-syncope accompanied by cold clammy skin and a panic attack.  This is a classical case of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as ""broken heart syndrome"")  characterized by the sudden onset of severe chest pain  and left ventricular dysfunction triggered by severe emotional or physical stress. Since the patient's symptoms mimic that of acute coronary syndrome  differentiate the same through diagnostic tests and evaluation.  This case instructs the students to understand the similarities and differences between acute coronary syndrome and Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. They need to understand the role of external stressors in inducing cardiovascular illnesses  understand the necessary investigations for diagnosis  and implement effective management strategies. Moreover  they should provide appropriate emotional and psychological support as part of comprehensive patient care.

Case Report  Patient Demographics: Patient Initials: SM Age: 61 Sex: Female Occupation: Former School Principal  Race: Caucasian Marital Status: Widowed  1 year ago  Past Medical History: SM has a history of hypertension for the last ten years  which has been under control through medication. She is a diagnosed case of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypercholesterolemia. She was also diagnosed with depression following the sudden demise of her husband and has been getting treatment for over a year. She abstained from smoking and alcohol consumption.   Key Complaints: SM presented to the emergency room with severe chest pain radiating to her left arm that started abruptly about 2 hours earlier. The pain was constant  constricting in nature  and her severity score was 8 on a scale of 10.  She had also reported experiencing increased episodes of breathlessness over the past week while doing her routine activities and sudden bouts of severe fatigue. She acknowledged feelings of intense anxiety and occasional palpitations for the last 6 months but has been attributing these symptoms to stress and grief over the loss of her spouse.   Upon examination  she appeared pale and anxious  with cold perspiration. ECG revealed ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V6  I  aVL. Her blood pressure was at 160/90 mmHg  and her heart rate was at 105 beats per minute with irregular rhythm.  Clinical Suspicion: Taking into account SM's age  gender  medical history  and presented symptoms  there is a clinical suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress or broken heart syndrome. An echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis and further management treatment will follow.  Notes: This case is designed to train medical students on how to diagnose and manage takotsubo cardiomyopathy  emphasizing the importance of considering this condition in differential diagnosis  especially in postmenopausal women presenting with symptoms mimicking acute coronary syndrome. Subsequent stressors trigger takotsubo syndrome and it should be considered particularly when patients have recently undergone significant emotional stress or loss.

Patient Information:   Mrs. L  a 63-year-old female  of Asian descent  retired schoolteacher  recently widowed. She is currently living alone.  Past Medical History:   Mrs. L has a history of hyperlipidemia  well-controlled hypothyroidism and does not smoke or drink alcohol. There is no known history of heart disease  hypertension  diabetes mellitus  stroke  or malignancy. She reports being moderately active and maintains a balanced diet.  Chief Complaint:   Having felt well in the morning  Mrs. L visited her husband's grave on the anniversary of his passing. Shortly after returning home  she experienced a sudden onset of severe intense chest pain (like a weight on her chest)  shortness of breath (unable to climb a flight of stairs without panting)  and nausea. She also reported feeling dizzy and lightheaded. The symptoms were not triggered by physical exertion and were not eased by rest or nitroglycerin intake which she had for anginal pain.  The scenario built around the context  should trigger students to explore further the differential diagnosis  including takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as broken heart syndrome)  understand the pathophysiology  order appropriate investigations like chest X-ray  ECG  blood tests  coronary angiography or echocardiogram and advise apt management strategy. They should be also advised about preventive strategies  and the importance of a comprehensive approach that includes psychological interventions to manage emotional stress.

Patient Information:   Mrs. Linh  a 72-year-old Vietnamese woman  was brought to the ED by her family. She has a history of hypertension and is otherwise healthy. She does not have a history of cardiac disease. Mrs. Linh is a widow and has been living alone since her husband passed away 2 years ago. She was a teacher now retired and has no known allergies. She denies any tobacco or ilicit drug usage  and only occasionally drinks alcohol socially.  Chief Complaint:  The patient presented with sudden onset chest pain radiating to the left arm. Symptoms started approximately 90 minutes ago. Mrs Linh also complained of mild shortness of breath  but denied any dizziness  nausea or vomiting.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  she appeared anxious and distressed. Vitals were as follows: BP 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate 90 bpm  respiratory rate 22/minute  oxygen saturation of 95% at room air. Cardiovascular examination showed no murmurs  rubs or gallops. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Investigations:  An EKG showed ST elevation in the precordial leads. However  her troponin levels were only mildly elevated. Immediate concern for coronary artery disease determined a cardiac catheterization  which surprisingly revealed no obstructive coronary disease but apical ballooning and hyperkinesis of the heart base.  Diagnosis:  Based on her symptoms  physical exam  and findings on cardiac catheterization  a diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (Broken Heart Syndrome) was made - a condition often triggered by severe stress  with this case potentially related to her life changes.  Treatment:  The patient was treated with supportive care  including ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers  along with an emphasis on stress management and psychological support.   Course and Prognosis:  Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy is generally reversible  but Mrs. Linh’s age and stress levels could result in a longer recovery timeframe. Close and regular cardiology follow-ups along with psychological counseling was planned for her.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mrs. Michelle Rodriguez Age: 68 years old Gender: Female Race: Hispanic Occupation: Retired school teacher Marital Status: Widowed Location: Urban California  Past Medical History: Mrs. Rodriguez has a history of Hypertension and Type II Diabetes  well managed with medications. She is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. She has had no previous cardiac issues. She lost her husband 3 years ago and has faced significant bouts of anxiety and depression since.   Chief Complaints: Michelle was brought to the emergency department last night after she felt a sudden crushing pain in her chest with radiations to her left arm. Along with this  she also reports experiencing dyspnea  nausea  and a brief episode of syncope.  On examination  continued complaints of chest pain. Her diaphoresis and palpitations were observed  but no signs of fever were present. She appeared anxious but was fully oriented in time  place  and person.   This case train aims to highlight key points in identifying and managing takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Key features to focus on for a heightened index of suspicion include: - Older  postmenopausal women with a sudden onset of severe chest pain and dyspnea mimicking myocardial infarction. - A catalyst event causing emotional or physical stress triggering the cardiomyopathy. - A patient presenting with acute chest pain  with ST-segment elevation on ECG  but no coronary artery occlusion found on angiography.  The case further needs to be explored for confirmation of her condition by utilizing cardiac biomarkers (troponin levels)  Electrocardiogram  Echocardiogram  and a Coronary Angiogram. Treatment can include supportive measures and potentially β-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and anticoagulants in certain circumstances. The emotional triggers leading to this condition should also be addressed.  As a facilitator  you should use this case to discuss the differential diagnosis versus acute coronary syndrome  cardiogenic shock  myocarditis  etc.  and the specific diagnostic evaluations for each.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mrs. Abigail Wilson Age: 61 Gender: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher  Past Medical History: Mrs. Wilson is a moderately active woman with a history of good health. She has controlled hypertension for which she has been taking Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily  for the past six years. She also has a history of depression for which she uses Sertraline 50mg daily.  Key Complaints: Mrs. Wilson presented to the emergency department with acute onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath. She mentioned that she has been facing intense emotional stress following the death of her husband two weeks ago. The pain began suddenly while she was at home and does not radiate. Accompanying symptoms included nausea  fatigue  and mild dizziness. The patient denies any prior occurrences of such symptoms.  Emphasize: During this case  the symptoms may resemble those of a heart attack. However  it's crucial to note the significant emotional stress this patient experienced in recent weeks  which is representative of the demographic specifics of those most likely to experience takotsubo cardiomyopathy. This condition often affects postmenopausal women and is frequently precipitated by severe emotional distress.   Teaching Objective: For medical students to pinpoint takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken heart syndrome)  understand how it differs from myocardial infarction even though they share similar presenting symptoms  to appreciate the role of acute emotional stress in its etiology  and to understand how clinical examinations  EKG  blood tests  echo  and angiogram could help differentiate it from other conditions.

Case Report on Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Demographics:  Mrs. Thomas  68-year-old Caucasian woman.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Thomas is a retired secondary school teacher with a medical history of controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She is currently on metformin and Lisinopril. She is a non-smoker and has a drinking habit of two glasses of wine every evening. Her father died at the age of 70 due to myocardial infarction.   Key Complaints:  Mrs. Thomas presented to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain radiating to the left arm which came on suddenly whilst she was attending the funeral of her former colleague. The pain was described as a ""crushing"" sensation associated with shortness of breath and a sense of impending doom. She also reports that she has been feeling highly stressed and emotionally burdened over the past few weeks due to the sudden death of her close friend. On examining  her blood pressure was 160/90  pulse rate of 100 bpm  respiratory rate of 20 breaths/minute and her oxygen saturation was 95%. On auscultation  there were no abnormal heart sounds and lungs were clear to auscultation.  This is an example of a typical case of takotsubo (or stress) cardiomyopathy. Often referred to as broken heart syndrome  this condition can mimic the symptoms of a heart attack and is often precipitated by emotional or physical stress events. The exact mechanism remains unknown  but it is believed to be due to a surge in stress hormones stunning the heart  causing changes in the heart muscle cells or coronary blood vessels.   In finalizing this case  the further tests  diagnosis  management  and treatment approaches should be discussed. For instance  an ECG will likely show ST-segment elevation  and a coronary angiogram may show ""apical ballooning"". Treatment is usually supportive  with beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors having a central role.
