Patient Information:   - Age: 60-year-old  - Sex: Female  - Occupation: Retired school teacher  - Race: Asian   Key Complaints:   - Sudden severe retrosternal chest pain radiating to left arm  - Shortness of breath  - Dizziness  - Nausea   History:   - Patient reports that she abruptly started feeling chest pain post receiving news about her daughter's accident  - Has a past medical history of hypertension  managed on medication but also known for her irregularity in taking the medication  - Non-smoker  non-alcoholic  - No family history of heart disease  - The last health check-up showed normal cardiac enzymes  ECG and Lipid profile   Physical Exam:   - Vital signs: BP 160/100  Pulse 100/minute irregular  RR 24/minute  Temperature 98.4 F  - Generally appears acutely distressed  - Cardiac auscultation reveals tachycardia  no audible murmurs   Imaging and Lab Tests:   - Recommend ECG  Echocardiogram  Blood tests including Troponin T  CK-MB  D-Dimer  and a possible Coronary Angiogram to rule out possible Coronary Artery Disease given her symptoms and risk factors   Treatment Plan:   - Initial management might include care in a high acuity area like the ICU  Oxygen supply  pain control  and blood pressure management   Learning Points:   - Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as 'Broken Heart Syndrome' often presents similarly to acute coronary syndrome  - It's more common in post-menopausal women  - This condition can often be triggered by intense emotional or physical stress  - An essential distinguishing factor is often Wall-motion abnormalities involving the apical and mid-sections of left ventricle which are not typically found in coronary artery disease  - Management usually includes supportive care since the condition often reverses itself within weeks to months  Disclaimer: This case is for teaching purposes and is not to be used as actual medical advice.

Patient Information:  - Patient's initials: C.T.  - Age: 69  - Sex: Female - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired school teacher  Presenting Complaint:  C.T. was brought to the emergency department by her son after complaining of sudden  severe chest pain  and difficulty breathing  primarily during the day  for the past two days. The onset was sudden  about two days ago right after she received news about the sudden death of her younger sister. The pain is central  radiating to the shoulders and indicative of possible coronary syndrome.   Past Medical History:  C.T. is generally in good health  though she has struggled with untreated anxiety for most of her life. She does not smoke  drinks alcohol socially  and is not known to use any recreational drugs. She gave birth to three children and had no complications during pregnancy or childbirth. She recently was diagnosed with Hashimoto's thyroiditis but is regularly monitored and takes L-Thyroxine. No known drug allergies. She has no known history of heart disease or symptoms prior to this event. Her father had coronary artery disease diagnosed in his late fifties.  Physical Examination:  On arrival  the patient appears distressed and is hyperventilating. Vitals are as follows: heart rate is 112 bpm  irregular  blood pressure is 165/95 mm Hg  respiratory rate is 22 breaths/min  and SpO2 is 92% on room air.  The cardiovascular exam a raised JVP and symmetrical pitting edema. Lung sound is clear  with no obvious rales or wheezing. Cardiac auscultation revealed normal heart sounds without any murmurs  rubs  or gallops.   Key Learning Point:  This case appears to align with the classic presentation of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TCM)  also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome."" This condition often mimics a heart attack and is typically triggered by acute emotional stress. The symptoms include chest pain and shortness of breath. A key aspect to note when diagnosing TCM is the absence of significantly obstructive coronary disease that would be sufficient to cause a transmural myocardial infarction. The initial focus should be on stabilizing the patient  ruling out a heart attack  and managing symptoms. This case can be used to teach about the recognition  differential diagnosis  and early management of TCM in the emergency settings.

Case Report for Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy Training  Patient Demographics: Mrs. Y is a 67-year-old Caucasian female. She is a non-smoker  teetotaler with a BMI within normal range. She is retired and a widow. She has 2 children and lives with her eldest daughter.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and is on medication (Lisinopril 10 mg daily). She was diagnosed with intermittent anxiety disorder 5 years ago  which became severe after her husband passed away a year ago. No history of coronary disease or cardiac risks like dyslipidemia or diabetes mellitus. She has no history of substance abuse.  Presenting Complaints: Mrs. Y arrived at the emergency department complaining of sudden  severe chest pain that started a few hours ago while she was at her husband's one-year memorial service. She describes the pain as a heavy  crushing sensation that radiates to her left shoulder and arm. She is also experiencing shortness of breath  palpitations  nausea  and lightheadedness. She reports feeling extremely anxious during the memorial event before the onset of these symptoms.   This patient description can be used to discuss the clinical presentation  pathophysiology  diagnostic procedures  and treatment approaches for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The case also illustrates the potential role of psychological stress and anxiety as triggering factors for the condition.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Ms. Thompson  a 68-year-old Caucasian female of middle socioeconomic status residing in a suburban community.  Chief Complaint: Presenting with acute onset of severe chest pain that radiates to the shoulders  palpitations  shortness of breath  light-headedness. These symptoms began following a heated argument with her son.  Past Medical History: Recently widowed  she has a history of depression  hypothyroidism for which she takes levothyroxine  osteoporosis managed with weekly alendronate  and occasional gastroesophageal reflux disease managed with h2 blockers as needed. She has no personal or family history of cardiac disease  hypertension  or diabetes. Never smoked or consumed alcohol regularly. Maintains an active lifestyle with moderate-intensity daily exercises and balanced diet.  The purpose of this case would be to highlight the importance of understanding the symptoms and causes of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome."" Symptoms often mimic acute coronary syndrome  but it is usually triggered by severe emotional or physical distress. Teaching points in this specific case would be:  1. The association between emotional stress (e.g.  grief from her husband's death  argument with her son) and takotsubo cardiomyopathy. 2. Understand the differential diagnosis in patients presenting with chest pain  particularly in those without typical risk factors for coronary artery disease.  3. Recognition that despite mimicking symptoms of an acute myocardial infarction  takotsubo cardiomyopathy often involves transient regional systolic dysfunction of the left ventricle  with mid-section and apical ballooning while basal function is preserved.  4. Emphasize the importance of a well-integrated approach to the healthcare  addressing both physiological and psychological needs of the patient for holistic care management.  5. Discuss treatment strategies which are largely symptomatic and supportive  including heart failure medications  and managing triggers such as stress and anxiety.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Demographics: Name: Mrs. Helen Thompson Age: 64 years old Sex: Female Marital Status: Widowed Occupation: Retired School Teacher Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Thompson has a known medical history of hypertension which is well controlled with medication (Lisinopril)  and occasional acid reflux. She is a non-smoker and her alcohol consumption is limited to social situations. Her family history reveals her mother had coronary artery disease. Her recent lipid profiles were within normal limits. She had undergone a hysterectomy at the age of 50 due to uterine fibroids  but there's no other significant past surgical history.   Key Complaints:  Mrs. Thompson was brought into the emergency department (ED) by her daughter. Her daughter reported that she had been witnessing her mother displaying increasing levels of emotional stress as a result of being newly widowed following the recent death of her husband.   The patient complains of sudden-onset chest pain  severe in intensity 7/10  located in the middle of the chest  radiating to the left arm and associated with shortness of breath. She denies palpitations  presyncope or syncope  nausea  or vomiting. She denies feeling any pain between the shoulder blades  discomfort in the neck/jaw/throat  or upper abdomen.  ED vitals on arrival showed blood pressure: 145/90 mmHg  pulse rate: 110/min  respiratory rate: 20/min  and oxygen saturation of 95% in room air.  Physical examination was generally unremarkable  except for tachycardia and a mildly distressing respiratory pattern.   Investigations:  An emergency ECG demonstrates ST elevations in leads V2 to V5. Urgent echocardiography shows apical ballooning of left ventricle with reduced ejection fraction.  On the basis of her clinical presentation  her ECG changes  and echocardiography  a diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (Broken heart syndrome) was made. This condition is often triggered by severe emotional stress  like the grief and emotional pressure that Mrs. Thompson has been experiencing following the death of her husband.   Please note that key findings like ST elevations in ECG and apical ballooning of the left ventricle should lead you to consider Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy among differential diagnoses  particularly when the patient has been subjected to significant emotional stress  as in Mrs. Thompson's case. You should also remember that although Mrs. Thompson complained of chest pain  not all patients with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy would present with this symptom.

Patient Information: A 70-year-old Asian female patient presenting to the emergency department.  Chief Complaint: The patient reports sudden  severe chest pain and shortness of breath which started two hours ago while she was attending her grandson's funeral.  Past Medical History: Patient has a history of hypertension  for which she takes medication. She is also a recent widow with a history of major depressive disorder  managed with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). The patient is a non-smoker and denies alcohol or illicit drug use. There is no history of cardiac disease in the family.   Current Medications: Amlodipine 5mg daily for hypertension  Sertraline 50mg daily for depression.  Physical Exam: In the emergency department  the patient appears distressed and anxious. Her blood pressure is 165/90 mmHg  heart rate is 105 bpm  respiratory rate is 22/min  and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. The cardiovascular exam reveals tachycardia with regular rhythm and no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Pulmonary exam reveals clear lung fields without wheezing  rales  or rhonchi. No peripheral edema or jugular venous distension is noted. Rest of the physical examination is normal.  Context: The patient was under emotional stress due to the death of her grandson. This emotional distress is relevant  as it may have precipitated the onset of the mentioned symptoms.  This case is designed to provide insight into the diagnosis  management  and understanding of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome"".

Patient Information:  Ms. Diane Johnson is a 68-year-old African-American female  recently widowed  with a past medical history of well-controlled hypertension and hypothyroidism living independently in an urban setting.  Chief Complaints: Ms. Johnson arrived at the ER complaining of sudden  intense chest pain and shortness of breath. The pain is described as centrally located  radiating to the left shoulder  and similar to a heavy pressure sensation. She describes the pain as 8/10  with sudden onset while she was at her husband’s funeral earlier in the day. The pain was associated with sudden breathlessness and a brief episode of syncope.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has had many uncontrollable life stressors in the last three months including the death of her husband of 40 years  unexpected financial difficulties  and the selling of her home.  Physical Examination Findings: Upon physical examination  Ms. Johnson appeared visibly distressed. Her blood pressure was elevated at 170/95mmHg  a pulse of 110 beats per minute  and respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute.  Discussion: This case is a typical presentation of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as “broken heart syndrome”)  which is a type of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy in which there is a sudden temporary weakening of the muscular portion of the heart. It can be triggered by severe emotional distress  such as the unexpected death of a loved one  sudden financial difficulties  or any major life changes. Patients often present with chest pain  mimicking myocardial infarction  with EKG changes and cardiac enzyme elevation. Women are more frequently affected than men  and postmenopausal women are at a greater risk such as the patient in this case. Management includes supportive care and addressing the stressors leading to the onset of symptoms.  Learning Objectives: 1. Recognize the clinical presentation of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy. 2. Understand the importance of the relationship between emotional stress and physical disease manifestation. 3. Familiarize with the main symptoms that distinguish Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy from myocardial infarction. 4. Discuss the approach to diagnosis and management of patient with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.

Patient Presentation: Jennifer Harrison  a 62-year-old Caucasian female  is presenting to the emergency department (ED) with severe  left-sided chest pain radiating down her left arm. She describes the pain as ""crushing"" in nature  present for the last two hours and worsened by physical activity. She also reports feeling lightheaded  short of breath  and states she has experienced one episode of vomiting prior to arrival at the ED.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Harrison is a widow. She is a retired elementary school teacher with a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. She is under medication with amlodipine 5mg daily and atorvastatin 10mg daily. She stated that she quit smoking 20 years ago and rarely drinks alcohol. Six months ago  Mrs. Harrison lost her husband in a car accident  after which she had developed symptoms of depression and had been seeing a psychiatrist for the same.  Key Complaints: 1. Severe  left-sided chest pain 2. Radiating pain down the left arm 3. Lightheadedness 4. Shortness of breath 5. One episode of vomiting  Clinical Suspicion:  Given her recent history of severe emotional stress  symptoms  and demographic profile  there is a suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome."" Further history  physical examination  laboratory investigation  and imaging will be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.   Learning Objectives: This case would be an effective teaching tool for highlighting the correlation between emotional stress and heart disease  emphasizing the importance of holistic patient care. The differential diagnosis for chest pain should be discussed  aiming to understand the distinguishing features of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  and underlining the importance of considering less common causes of chest pain  especially when confounding social and psychologic factors are present.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female  recently widowed. She is living alone  is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic  and works as a retired teacher. Her medications include a daily multivitamin and calcium supplement due to a past history of osteoporosis. She does not have a history of substance abuse.  History of Present Illness:  The patient presents herself in the Emergency Department with sudden onset of severe chest pain which she describes as a ""heavy feeling""  radiating to her neck and shoulders. The pain started a couple of hours ago while she was attending her husband's funeral service. She also reports feeling lightheaded and short of breath with a profuse perspiration. She denies any nausea  vomiting  or palpitations.  The patient denies having had similar symptoms before. She does not have a history of coronary artery disease  diabetes  hypertension  or hyperlipidemia. She has had yearly cardiovascular evaluations which have been normal so far. Her last mammogram and pap smear were done a year ago  which were reported as normal.  She does not have any known drug allergies. Her family history is significant for her father having had a heart attack at age 68  and her mother died from stroke at age 71.  Physical Examination:  The patient appears anxious and diaphoretic. Her blood pressure is 165/90 mmHg  pulse rate is 110 per minute  respiratory rate is 22 per minute  and body temperature is 36.6°C. Chest examination reveals no abnormalities. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. The rest of the exam is essentially normal.  Summary:  This case focuses on a 65-year-old woman who presented with severe chest pain  shortness of breath  lightheadedness  and profuse perspiration during a stressful event. There is a suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced or broken-heart syndrome  which often mimics symptoms of a heart attack and is triggered by intense physical or emotional stress. Although it's most often seen in older women  it can affect both men and women of any age. The absence of significant risk factors for cardiovascular disease and the acute emotional stressor could be leading towards this diagnosis. Further investigations (like ECG  blood tests  echocardiogram  or coronary angiography) would be required to confirm this diagnosis.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female  Mrs. A  who is a retired school teacher. She is a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol. She lives alone and has two adult children who stay nearby. She is physically active with regular walks in the park and participates in a book club.  Past Medical History: Mrs. A suffers from well-controlled mild hypertension and has been on Amlodipine 5mg/day for the past five years. Except for occasional migraines  her health has been quite stable. She had a total knee replacement on her left side 10 years ago. She reports having frequent episodes of stress due to her husband's death from lung cancer two years ago. She has no known allergies  and there is no family history of any serious cardiovascular disease.  Presenting Complaints: Mrs. A was brought to the emergency department experiencing severe chest pain at rest  which began suddenly while she was reading. The chest pain is described as a crushing type in her central chest  radiating to her left arm along with profuse sweating. She says it began two hours ago and has been unrelieved since. Mrs. A also mentions she has been feeling unusually stressed over the past week due to the anniversary of her husband's death approaching. She denied any shortness of breath  dizziness  palpitations  or any other associated symptoms. She hasn't experienced any similar pattern of chest pain before.  This scenario sets the stage to continue with a focussed history-taking  performing a relevant examination  ordering necessary investigations  and starting the appropriate therapy envisaging takotsubo cardiomyopathy given the strong emotional stress trigger  her demographic (post-menopausal woman)  and the sudden onset  the severity of the crushing type of chest pain.

Patient Case:   Name: Mrs. Hanna Evans  Demographics: 71-year-old Caucasian female  Past Medical History:   1. No cardiac history 2. Controlled hypertension 3. Non-smoker 4. No history of drug or alcohol abuse 5. No familial history of cardiac disease 6. History of Major Depressive Disorder   Key Complaints:   Mrs. Evans was brought into the Emergency Department accompanied by her daughter following significant exertional dyspnea and acute chest pain resembling angina pectoris. The chest pain was described as a sudden onset  severe  central heavy feeling that did not radiate. The symptoms started shortly after receiving the unexpected and distressing news about the death of a close friend.  Additional Information:  Mrs. Evans leads an active lifestyle  regularly having walks in the park and doing yoga classes. She reports no prior incidents of similar pain or discomfort. She had mild flu-like symptoms a week back but has fully recovered since. She manages her hypertension with medication and has complied well with her medication regimen. She was diagnosed with Major Depressive Disorder 15 years ago and takes anti-depressants regularly. Her daughter mentioned that her mom has been more depressed than usual due to the ongoing pandemic causing isolation.   By choosing this scenario  it allows for students to consider the implications of older age  sudden emotional stress  controlled hypertension  and a history of Major Depressive Disorder in the context of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. They can discuss the importance of patient history  physical exam  and appropriate diagnostic testing in reaching the appropriate diagnosis. It will also enable discussion on differentiating this condition from acute coronary syndromes and appropriate management strategies.

Patient Information: A 63-year-old Caucasian female of moderate socio-economic status.  Presenting Complaints: The patient came in complaining of sharp  severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and feelings of restlessness.  Past Medical History: The patient was in her usual state of health until 2 days ago. She does not have a significant past medical history. She has no history of any chronic illnesses or any long-term medication. The patient has no known drug allergies. She does not smoke or use recreational drugs but occasionally consumes alcohol.  A significant emotional stress event: The patient’s husband died suddenly from an accident a week ago. She has been under severe emotional stress since the event.  Observation and Vitals: The patient was moderately built and nourished  conscious  and cooperative. Temperature: 98.7°F  Heart rate: 102 bpm  Respiratory rate: 24/min  Blood pressure: 148/95 mm Hg  Oxygen saturation: 94% at room air.  Possible Diagnosis: Based on the symptoms  patient history  emotional stress event  and preliminary examination  the patient may be suffering from Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome. Further diagnostic testing (e.g.  ECG  Echo  cardiac enzymes) will be done to confirm.

Case Study: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female named Mary. She is a widow who lives alone and recently relocated to the city to be closer to her only daughter following her husband's death.  Past Medical History: Mary has a history of hypertension  which is controlled with medications  and apart from that  she generally enjoys good health. Mary is a non-smoker  rarely drinks alcohol  and leads an active social life. She had an appendectomy when she was 26 years old  but other than that  her surgical history is unremarkable. Her husband died of a heart attack a year ago.   Key Complaints: Mary came into the emergency room complaining of sudden severe chest pain that started soon after hearing the disturbing news about her grandson's car accident. She describes the pain as intense and crushing  which she's never experienced before. It radiated to her left arm and was associated with shortness of breath and excessive sweating. Mary denies any recent chest infections  respiratory disorders  chronic cough  or significant weight loss. Interestingly  she has no history of the classic risk factors for ischemic heart diseases except for controlled hypertension.  For this case  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (or broken heart syndrome) should be considered as an important differential in patients presenting with chest pain  especially in postmenopausal women with recent significant emotional stress. Management can be challenging in such cases  and the training should focus on the identification  diagnosis  and treatment of this unique heart disorder  as well as teaching students the difference from other more common causes of chest pain.  Please note: this case assumes a setup where the emotionally triggering event (her grandson's car accident) happened a few hours before the onset of symptoms. This assumption highlights the temporal relationship between the stressful incidents and the onset of the symptoms of broken heart syndrome  an important diagnostic criteria for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Subject: Training Case: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Information: Name: Mrs. Ella Patterson Age: 68 years Gender: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History: Mrs. Patterson has a history of hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus that is managed well through medication and dietary changes. She has a family history of cardiovascular diseases as her father died from myocardial infarction at age 75. She does not smoke or consume alcohol and tries to maintain an active lifestyle despite a sedentary job.  Key Complaints: Mrs. Patterson was brought to the emergency department following a stressful ordeal at home - her house was burgled while she was inside. Though not harmed physically  she suffered an episode of severe chest pain mimicking a heart attack not long after the incident took place.  On presentation  she describes her pain as ""sudden and crushing "" akin to a heavy weight crushing her chest. The pain radiates to the left arm and she complains of shortness of breath and light-headedness. She also reports feeling nauseous and anxious and has broken out in a cold sweat.  In conclusion  the aim of this case report is to help medical students understand the relationship between intense emotional stress and some cardiac events  specifically takotsubo cardiomyopathy. This case can be used to reinforce the learning of diagnosis and management of takotsubo cardiomyopathy based on the presenting symptoms and history of the patient.

Patient Demographics:  Ms. A is a 68-year-old Japanese woman with a history of hypertension and no documented history of coronary artery disease. She is a retired mathematics high school teacher currently residing in rural Japan  having migrated from a busy city after her husband passed away 5 years ago. She does not smoke or consume alcohol and maintains a diet of traditional Japanese cuisine. She lives alone and has a network of close neighbors who regularly check on her following her recent bereavement.   Chief Complaint: Ms. A presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain that started a couple of hours ago  which she describes as “a sudden heavy  squeezing pain in the center of her chest."" The pain was associated with shortness of breath. No precipitating events were noted apart from her mentioning having an argument with someone at the local market.  Past Medical History: Ms. A has been hypertensive for ten years  controlled on medication. She has no previous episodes of chest pain  no history of heart failure  or any major hospitalizations. There is no family history of significant cardiovascular disease. She was recently widowed  and has been struggling with chronic stress  grieving  and depression. She has been under treatment for anxiety symptoms for the past 2 years  but she has no known psychiatric illnesses.   Her healthcare maintenance includes annual influenza vaccination and biannual routine physical checkups. The patient is compliant with her medication for hypertension and anxiety. She has never smoked or consumed alcohol in her life.   Physical Findings: On examination  she appeared sweaty and distressed. Her blood pressure was slightly elevated  and her heart rate appeared tachycardic. She was afebrile; her other vital signs were within normal limits. The cardiopulmonary exam revealed slight tachycardia without any murmurs or added sounds. Chest was clear to auscultation bilaterally. The rest of the examination was unremarkable.   Differential Diagnoses: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  Acute coronary syndrome  Anxiety disorder  Pulmonary embolism.   Clinical Course: The chest pain and shortness of breath that Ms. A experienced are highly suggestive of cardiac etiology. Her electrocardiogram and cardiac enzyme levels showed changes consistent with myocardial injury. However  a coronary angiography showed no obstructive coronary artery disease. Echocardiography depicted apical ballooning with a hyperdynamic base  also known as ‘octopus pot' appearance  strongly suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Treatment: Ms. A was managed conservatively with beta-blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  and diuretics as required. She was admitted to the hospital for monitoring and supportive treatment. Fortunately  her symptoms resolved over the following week. In addition to pharmacological treatments  psychological support was added and arranged for a bereavement support group to help her cope with her emotional stress.  Conclusion: This case highlights the diagnosis and management of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  a condition often overlooked as it mimics myocardial infarction. It is crucial for clinicians to be aware of this condition as it is typically precipitated by emotional stress  especially in postmenopausal women. It is typically manageable with conservative treatment and is usually resolved between days to weeks.

Patient Identity: Mrs. Rosa Cantu  Age: 65 years old  Sex: Female  Occupation: Retired Elementary School Teacher  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Cantu has been generally healthy with no significant past medical history until presented with symptoms related to the cardiovascular system. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. She has a body mass index of 24.7 kg/m2. She  however  admits to having considerable levels of stress due to financial and family issues. There is no family history of cardiovascular diseases  diabetes  or early death.  Presenting Complaints:  Mrs. Cantu is presented in the ER complaining of acute chest pain radiating to the jaw and the left arm. The pain begun spontaneously while she was at home  described as severe  squeezing  and similar to a heavy weight placed on her chest. Accompanying symptoms include profuse sweating  shortness of breath  extreme fatigue  and nausea. She states that her symptoms started following a heated argument with her son.   Next Steps: The medical students will use this case to further explore managing a patient with suspected Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome. They would evaluate additional cardiovascular signs through lab tests  electrocardiogram  cardiac imaging techniques and formulate a differential diagnosis  considering other potential causes for acute chest pain like myocardial infarction. The students would also delve into an understanding of the interaction between severe emotional stressors and the manifestation of physical symptoms.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Demographics:   Patient Initials: A.B.   Age: 65 years old    Gender: Female   Race: Caucasian   Occupation: Retired school teacher   Insurance Status: Medicare    Past Medical History:  1. Controlled hypertension on treatment for the past 10 years. 2. Mild neuropsychiatric issues  specifically anxiety.   Presenter’s Concerns:   A.B. was generally fit and well with controlled hypertension for which she is medicated (patient on a usual dose of beta blocker and ACE inhibitor for it). Being a retired school teacher  she leads a very organized and calm lifestyle. In previous routine check-ups no significant abnormalities were noted. Apart from hypertension  she has no family history of cardiovascular diseases but has been dealing with anxiety.  She presented at the emergency department with acute onset chest pain  continuous and severe in nature  not relieved with rest or sublingual nitroglycerin. The pain was sudden after an intense argument with her neighbor which had caused her significant distress.  Her vitals were stable other than a slightly elevated blood pressure. A.B. denied any other symptoms like shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  diaphoresis  or syncope.  Key Complaints:  1. Sudden onset severe chest pain 2. Unrelieved with rest or sublingual nitroglycerin. 3. Psychological distress due to an intense argument.  This case should further include clinical examination findings  investigations (including cardiac marker levels  EKG  echo  cardiac catheterization)  and the eventual diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy. The history of psychological stress  symptoms of chest pain and the absence of major risk factors for conventional heart diseases would guide the students toward the diagnosis.

Patient Case: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Demographics  Patient: Mrs. Patricia Hudson Age: 67 years old Sex: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher  Past Medical History  The patient's past medical history includes hypertension (controlled with medication) and stage II breast cancer  for which she had completed chemotherapy and radiation approximately 5 months prior. She also has a history of generalized anxiety disorder. No previous record of cardiac diseases.  Key Complaints  Mrs. Hudson was rushed to the emergency room due to sudden onset shortness of breath and severe chest pain. She reported the pain as crushing and radiating to her left arm. The pain precipitated while she was at a family event  a few moments after she had received the news of her brother's sudden death. She has no history of chest pain or similar symptoms in the past.  The patient reports a significant amount of emotional stress recently due to the passing away of her brother  in addition to minor symptoms such as tachycardia and episodic faintness over the past few weeks. She denies any recreational drug use or recent increase in alcohol consumption  and denies any recent chest trauma or severe physical exhaustion as well.  Observations on arrival indicate the patient is in mild distress  diaphoretic  and pale. Her vitals reveal tachycardia and elevated blood pressure. EKG shows ST-segment elevation; however  subsequent angiography doesn't show any significant blockages to justify these changes. Lab tests reveal a slight elevation in cardiac enzymes. An echocardiogram shows apical ballooning and reduced ejection fraction indicative of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The distribution of wall motion abnormalities in the patient's ventricle doesn't correlate with a single epicardial coronary artery supplying area  further supporting the diagnosis.  Overall  the presentation and the stress-inducing event she had experienced recently aligns with the diagnosis of takotsubo or stress cardiomyopathy.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Demographics: Female  62 years old  Caucasian; retired English teacher; weight 155 pounds; height 5 feet 6 inches; lives alone; non-smoker  occasional alcohol use; lives a moderately sedentary lifestyle.  Past Medical History: Known Hypertension for 10 years [controlled with medication (Lisinopril 20mg daily)]; no history of diabetes or any other cardiovascular diseases. No surgical history  no allergies known. She takes a multivitamin and calcium supplement daily. Mental health history includes generalized anxiety disorder managed with cognitive behavioral therapy and paroxetine. No family history of heart disease.  Clinical Presentation: Presenting with severe chest pain described as a sudden 'tightness'  started an hour ago at rest while she was watching the news about a tragic incident. Also experiencing shortness of breath  cold sweats  and feelings of impending doom. She describes the pain as being similar to a 'heart attack' she has seen on TV  rating the pain as 8/10. No radiation of pain. She denies nausea  vomiting  palpitations  blurring of vision  or loss of consciousness. There is no correlation of the pain with physical activity and it does not improve with rest.  Physical Examination: Patient appears anxious and distressed. Vital signs: BP 160/90 mmHg  HR 110 bpm  RR 20/min  Temp. 98.6F  Oxygen saturation 95% on room air. Cardiac exam revealed tachycardia  no murmurs. Rest of physical examination is within normal limits.   Impression: Given the patient's symptoms and history  one of the differential diagnoses would be Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy  due to the sudden onset of severe chest pain following emotional stress. Additional testing would include an EKG  cardiac biomarkers  chest x-ray  and potentially  an echocardiogram or cardiac catheterization to confirm the diagnosis and rule out an actual myocardial infarction.  Discussion Points: 1. Pathophysiology and precipitating factors of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. 2. The clinical presentation of takotsubo cardiomyopathy and importantly  how it mimics myocardial infarction. 3. Importance of timely investigation and management. 4. Appropriate use of pharmacological management in managing the condition. 5. The role of stress and mental health in the onset of this condition.

Case Report:   Patient Information: Mrs. G.M.  a 65-year-old Caucasian woman.  Occupation: Recently retired school teacher.  Living situation: Lives alone  recently widowed. She has two grown-up children who live out state.  Past Medical History:  1) Chronic hypertension well controlled with medication (Lisinopril  5mg to be taken orally every day) 2) Anxiety disorder diagnosed five years ago  managed with a combination of cognitive behavioral therapy and medication (Escitalopram  10mg to be taken orally every day). 3) No history of cardiac disorders. She has never smoked and drinks alcohol occasionally.  Current Presentation/Admission:  She presented to the emergency room of the local hospital with sudden onset of severe chest pain  similar to what she heard is experienced in a heart attack. The onset of pain was while she was attending her husband's funeral.  Key Complaints:  Severe chest pain  anxiety  shortness of breath  palpitations  and feeling of impending doom.   Emergency room doctor requested an Electrocardiogram (ECG)  which showed ST-segment elevation  which is typically seen in patients experiencing a myocardial infarction (heart attack). However  her cardiac biomarkers (Troponin levels) were only mildly elevated which didn’t correlate with the degree of ECG changes.   Subsequent emergency coronary angiography showed no significant blockages  ruling out acute coronary syndrome or myocardial infarction.   The left ventriculogram showed the classic 'octopus pot' sign of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy - with apical ballooning and contraction of the base of the heart.   The provisional diagnosis:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome"".   Background for Medical Students:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy can mimic symptoms of a heart attack  and it commonly occurs in postmenopausal women experiencing intense emotional or physical stress. It is key to differentiate it from acute coronary syndrome for appropriate management. The prognosis is generally good if managed properly.

Case Report:   Patient Demographics: Name: Mrs. Johansson Age: 68  Gender: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired primary school teacher  Past Medical History: Mrs. Johansson has a history of hypertension which has been relatively well-controlled with medication (amlodipine 5mg daily). She is moderately overweight (BMI 28.4)  non-smoker  and does not consume alcohol frequently. She does not have any known history of coronary heart disease or any other cardiovascular diseases. She was recently widowed and has been undergoing immense emotional stress following the sudden death of her husband.  Key Complaints: Mrs. Johansson presented to the emergency department with severe chest discomfort accompanied by shortness of breath. She described the pain as a heavy pressing sensation radiating to her arm. She also stated that the pain was similar to that of a previous bout of angina experienced two years ago.   Other associated complaints were generalized weakness  increased anxiety  and transient loss of consciousness. She also reported experiencing emotional distress since recent past due to the loss of her spouse. No history of trauma  fever  cough or other symptoms was noted.  This case is essential for undergraduate and postgraduate medical students as it provides an overview of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as ""broken heart syndrome"") which usually occurs after experiencing severe stress. The affliction is characterized by the sudden temporary weakening of the heart muscles causing the left ventricle to change shape. The scenario will help students understand the importance of taking a comprehensive medical history  including psychological stressors  in forming a differential diagnosis for acute chest pain.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Ms. Emma Walker is a 65-year-old Caucasian female. She is a retired elementary school teacher and resides in a suburban community with her husband. She is a non-smoker and occasionally has a glass of wine during social occasions.  Past Medical History:  Ms. Walker has a history of well-controlled hypertension and is currently on medication (hydrochlorothiazide 25mg daily). She was diagnosed with anxiety after her retirement five years ago and is on low-dose selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). She gets yearly checkups and her last routine check-up six months ago reported good health.  Key Complaints: Ms. Walker has presented to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to her left arm. The pain started while she was attending her grandchild's birthday party. She describes the pain as a pressure-like feeling  rated 8 on a scale of 10. Along with this  she also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  light-headedness  and excessive sweating. She denies the history of similar complaint  trauma  or acute illness. She mentions feeling overwhelmed by the anxiety of hosting the party and managing the children. Her blood pressure upon admission was 150/90 mmHg.  Relevant information: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  or Broken Heart Syndrome  is often triggered by severe stress. The patient's symptoms are very similar to a heart attack. Elderly women post-menopause are typically more susceptible to this condition  particularly if they have a history of a neurological condition or mental health disorders  such as anxiety.

Patient Profile: - Name: Linda Jackson  - Age: 62 years old  - Gender: Female  - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired schoolteacher  Past Medical History:  - No known heart disease or hypertension  - Smoker for 20 years (quit a decade ago) - Moderate alcohol consumption - Family history of Breast Cancer in mother - Has a history of generalized anxiety disorder but not currently on treatment - Latest check-up was six months ago with no remarkable findings.  Key Complaints: Linda arrived at the emergency department with sudden onset  severe chest pain which radiates to her back and left arm. The pain started few hours ago  roughly an hour after receiving the news of her only son's sudden death in a car accident. She describes the pain as a squeezing sensation and rated it as 7 out of 10 on the pain scale. Accompanying symptoms include excessive sweating  dyspnea  and a sense of impending doom. She denies any episodes of loss of consciousness  nausea  or vomiting. She has never experienced a similar kind of pain before.  In the examination  she appears distressed. Vitals are BP: 155/95mmHg  Pulse: 105 BPM  Respiratory rate: 22/minute  Oxygen saturation: 96% on room air and temperature: 37.0C. Auscultation of the chest showed no added sounds or murmurs. The rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.  The key learning objective of the case is to teach students how to identify  diagnose  manage a patient with takotsubo cardiomyopathy  by taking into consideration her emotional stressor and presenting symptoms. The case encourages students to differentiate takotsubo cardiomyopathy from other causes of acute chest pain and understand the role of echocardiography  ECG changes in diagnosis. They also learn to manage acute symptoms and recognize the long-term psychological treatment for such patients.  This case will provide an excellent opportunity for students to learn how emotional factors can potentially trigger a cardiac event and to develop a comprehensive patient management approach that appreciates the complex interplay between psychology and physiology.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Demographics Data  Patient: 64-year-old female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher  Past Medical History  The patient has a prior medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which have been well controlled for the past 20 years. The patient does not have a history of smoking  diabetes  illegal drug use  or alcoholism. She reports her mother died of myocardial infarction at the age of 72 but otherwise  no significant family history of cardiovascular diseases. She recalls a significant stressful event in her life  the death of her spouse  a month ago.  Chief Complaints  The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain radiating to her back  accompanied by dyspnea and palpitations. The symptoms started abruptly while she was preparing to visit her husband's grave  which  as per her interpretation  was an activity associated with severe emotional distress. The pain was alleviated partially by a nitroglycerin tablet. She denied any associated symptoms like nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis. The symptoms have caused her considerable anxiety as she is worried about having a heart attack.   This case report gives a classic presentation for takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as ""broken-heart syndrome"")  which typically occurs in postmenopausal women  often in response to a severe stressor. It can present similarly to acute coronary syndrome  and differentiating the two is essential as the management strategies differ significantly.   The case should further include a discussion of appropriate diagnostic criteria (including EKG findings  serum cardiac markers  and echocardiographic findings) as well as recommended management strategies and potential future patient complications. This case thus offers important learning points about the impact of emotional stress on cardiac health and serves as a comprehensive training tool in understanding the differential diagnosis of chest pain.

Patient Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Demographics:  - Patient name and records: Anonymous  - Gender: Female  - Age: 65 years - Occupation: Retired elementary school teacher - Ethnic Origin: Asian (Japanese)  Past Medical History: - Known hypertensive for past 10 years  well managed on medication. - No known allergies - Previous diagnosis of Generalized Anxiety Disorder 5 years prior  managed with Cognitive Behavioral Therapy and occasional medication. - Routine health screenings all normal. - No history of surgeries or hospitalizations other than normal childbirth. - No prior cardiac history. - Never smoked  occasional alcohol. - Regular physical activity till date.  Key Complaints:  The patient came to the emergency department with acute onset of severe chest pain radiating to the left arm. She describes the pain as “crushing” and rates it as 8/10 in severity. She started experiencing it while giving the eulogy at her husband's funeral and it progressively worsened over 2 hours. Accompanying symptoms include profuse sweating  shortness of breath  and feelings of extreme anxiety. She denies nausea  vomiting or syncope. There were no significant triggers to the chest pain. Her most recent blood tests  echocardiogram and ECG performed six months ago were all within normal limits.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Ms. Jane Smith Age: 62 years Sex: Female  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired high school teacher Marital status: Divorced Primary Language: English Residence: Lives alone in a suburban area   Past Medical History:  Smith has a history of well-controlled hypertension and occasional migraines. Family history reveals her grandmother suffered from coronary artery disease. She is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol socially and occasionally  and does not use recreational drugs. She is compliant with her anti-hypertensive medication but currently isn't on any other regular medication.  Presenting Complaints: Ms. Smith was brought to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset chest pain. She described the pain as a heavy pressure sensation occurring while watching news coverage of a highly stressful event earlier in the day. The pain radiated to her left jaw and was associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and light-headedness. The patient denies any similar episodes in the past. During her stay in the emergency room  she experienced an episode of palpitation but remained alert and oriented throughout.   Note: The case report is primarily designed for takotsubo cardiomyopathy also known as stress cardiomyopathy  which is triggered by severe emotional stress events. It is common amongst post-menopausal women and presents similar to a heart attack but involves no actual heart disease and calls for a different management strategy.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy   Patient Information: A 60-year-old Asian female  Past Medical History: Diagnosed with hypertension and managed by antihypertensive  the patient also has a history of mild anxiety disorder for which she takes occasional benzodiazepines. She is post-menopausal and has no known allergies. No history of smoking or substance abuse. Her family history includes her father who passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 65.  Presenting Complaint: The patient arrived at the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain radiating to the left side of her neck and arm. Described the pain as ""central chest crushing "" resembling her “usual” panic attacks  but significantly more severe than she has previously experienced. Other associated symptoms include dyspnea  profuse sweating  nausea and mild lightheadedness. She denies experiencing any recent trauma or injury  but mentions the recent sudden death of her brother two days prior that has caused her extreme emotional distress.  Clinical findings: Physical Examination was significant for a blood pressure of 155/90 mm Hg  heart rate was rapid and irregular at 120 beats/min  respiratory rate of 20 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. On auscultation  there were normal heart sounds with no murmurs and lung fields were clear. EKG showed signs of ST-segment elevation in anterior leads.   Further diagnostic tests were ordered including complete blood count  troponin levels  lipid profile  and a transthoracic echocardiogram. Laboratory results revealed elevated troponin levels and lipid panel within normal limits. Echocardiogram displayed a reduced ejection fraction (40%) and apical ballooning of the left ventricle with hyperkinesia of the base  indicative of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   These findings in the absence of any or severe obstructive coronary artery disease confirmed the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The patient was managed with supportive care including aspirin  beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and anxiolytic agents.   Key Learning Point: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken-heart syndrome""  often presents like an acute myocardial infarction. It may be triggered by physical or emotional stress and is more common in postmenopausal women. It is crucial to recognize this condition as its management varies from that of other forms of cardiomyopathy.
